content:
Who has the best email data? 

One of every one's favorite features in Clay is the ability to waterfall multiple data providers to find one email.

In the past I've done tests with Findymail, Datagma, Apollo.io, Nymblr - Verified B2B Leads & Custom Audiences for Salespeople & Marketers, People Data Labs, Clearout, Icypeas and Hunter.io. We tested 1,694 contacts from random industries with company sizes ranging from self employed to 10k employees. Of course, you should do your own testing for your Ideal Customer Profile segment to make a decision for you. 

The results are in the picture below. What I thought was interesting is some of the huge drop off rates after validation. (Debounce was the validation provider we used for the whole test.)

Findymail and Datagma both have solutions to try to validate catch all domains which is not accounted for here. (I send to both when they say it's valid and we stay under a 2% bounce rate.) 

Clearout also comes with a confidence score that works pretty reliably with their data (email people with over 90% confidence). 

Hunter.io had the best percent valid from found rate but found the least amount of emails. 

I also ran ANOTHER test to find work emails from a list of 2,103 people that had responded to an email campaign. So we know that the inbox is truly real. 

Findymail and Datagma basically tied for first place (they were within 10 emails of each other). 

My biggest takeaway from the test that it's not about picking one data provider or the other. It's about mixing them all.

content:
Here's 9 data points I see people manually researching that they should really be automating and how to automate it! 

To this day, only one company has ever stumped me for a data request and that was Daria Danilina asking for companies that sell on Google meet which I'm not even sure how you would manually research that! 

Here's some common research categories and how I would automate scraping the data or using AI. 

1. Open Jobs - Jordan Crawford has this data. PredictLeads has this data and Clay just added an integration. This is a very solved problem. 

2. Headcount Growth by Department - Clay has an integration to find people that joined the company by time frame. Harmonic also has this data. 

3. Sub Industry - This one is interesting. No database usually has sales engagement tools as an industry. The way I would tackle this is by making a list of the sub industries that you want to know about and define them to GPT-4. Add a company description to a prompt and ask it if it fits any of the categories. Make sure it only outputs a category if it's 95% sure and it's ok to not include any category if it can't filter it. 

4. What does the company do? Use a GPT-4 prompt with the input being the company description. 

5. Who does the company sell to? Use a GPT-4 prompt with the input being the scraped text from a company website. 

6. Average pricing - Scrape the first result of a google search that is set up like 

site:example(dot)com pricing "$" 

This will return the pricing page as the first result. Scrape the contents of the first page and run it through GPT-4 for the average pricing. 

7. Competitors - Scrape the google preview text of the first 5 links when searching 

example(dot)com {{HQ Country}} competitors

Run the preview snippets through AI and prompt it to only mention competitors that are mentioned multiple times. 

8. Leadership changes in the last 12 months. Use Clay to look at the company LinkedIn page and find anyone in the C-Suite that has joined in the last 12 months. 

9. Technologies the company uses. BuiltWith has great data if the company installs the tech on their site. If you are searching for something like Quickbooks, use PredictLeads to find the technology mentioned in their job descriptions. 

If you want to see another post about the most common messages people send manually and how I would scale them, drop a comment on this post!
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
Here's a workflow to find a company's social media account, use AI to infer what content they post about, and then send them more ideas. 

I'll be going over workflows like this and more with Reply.io at their Cold Email deep dive this Thursday! Comment if you want to join me. 

The goal of this email is to send something like 

"{{First Name}} -- I saw the company TikTok account posting about Steve Madden's latest fashion trends and celebrities representing the brand. 

Have you considered using UGC creators to create content for you. I had some ideas like {{AI Generated Ideas}}. 

Here's what we need for the workflow to work. 

1. Social media accounts of the brand/company
2. Captions from their past posts.
3. AI Magic

For step 1, we will use "Scrape Website" which is an integration inside of Clay. It gets us the social media account of the company and their SEO description which we will use later. 

For step 2, we will actually get this with a Google search. Google has built the best scraper in the world, use it. We will create a search that looks like this site:https://lnkd.in/eZ6vUz33 June 2023. 

Step 3 will use GPT-4 to tie this all together. 

First, we will use the previews of the captions to summarize what the brand's post about. Here's my prompt:

Using the input, summarize what a tiktok account usually posts about and complete my sentence. This is the input: "Google previews" Keep the output under 8 words and use keywords from the input. Make sure to summarize the text with what this tiktok account usually posts about. Complete each output with my prefix. This is my prefix: "I saw your TikTok account and noticed you post about"

Next we will write a prompt to generate the creative ideas based on what they have posted in the past and their SEO description. This is what I used. 

Using the inputs, create 3 video ideas that User generated content creators would be able to build on behalf of the brand. The inputs I'm going to give you include the description of the company and captions of some of their recent posts. This is the description of the company: "SEO description" This is some captions of their recent posts: "Google Previews" Keep the output to just 3 sentences and output creative ideas for the brand to imagine what creators can post on their behalf.


The output for Bodybuilding(dot)com looks like this -- "Content creators could share their personal fitness journey by demonstrating how the exercise programs, supplements and diets offered by the brand have positively impacted their health. There might also be a series of fun and engaging 'Beat the summer heat' workout challenges using bodybuilding.com products. Lastly, content creators can post humorous fitness instructional videos featuring bodybuilding.com workouts, playing off the "Looking for a funny personal trainer!" post.

Let me know if you enjoyed this and I can keep making more workflow ideas for people.

content:
Showing a prospect in an email how you can help them is way better than telling them. Here is one way we are doing it. 

The goal of the email is to show them that we know who their potential customers are and help them find them. 

This is the email I want to fulfill on. 
___________________
{{first_name}} I was taking a look at your website and figured your sell to people like Founders, VPs of Sales, and Directors of Sales Development. It looks like you help them keep their Salesforce updated with real time call notes. 

If you are trying to reach out to these prospects with cold emails like this, are you doing this automatically or still using Sales Nav manually?

We help people build their lead lists automatically and I figured that this LinkedIn profile (linkedin(dot)com/in/example) would be a good prospect for you. Here's their email and direct company phone.

This whole email was generated with AI and automation, if one lead isn't enough, could I show you how we do it?
____________________

My goal here is to show people how we can automatically pull in so much information about their company AND give them a lead that would be a good fit. 

In order to achieve this we need: 
1: A generation of who they sell to
2. A generation of what they help people do
3. A lead that would be good for them. 

If you have been following me for a bit, 1 and 2 is super easy to do by scraping the content of their website and using a GPT Prompt. 
Something like - "Using the input, tell me the job titles or types of people this company sells to. This is the input: "company description". Only return a list of titles or people. An example of an output that is formatted correctly is this "CEO, VP of Sales, and Director of Sales". Only output job titles, do not output anything other than the job titles."

The challenge here lies in getting a lead for the company. Buckle up

1: We have to determine the company's ideal customer profile and companies that fit that. We can use AI to get this done.
2. We take that report and we can do 1 of 3 things. We can either Ask AI to give us a company that fits this criteria (my preference). We can Google for a company. Or we can use Jordan Crawford's job data. In this flow I asked AI. 
3. Now we have 2 things we really need. The title of the person that we are reaching out to and a name of a company that would be a good fit for their product or service. We can create a google search to find the LinkedIn profile of a person. 

So an example Google Search could be "linkedin.com/in/ GTM Manager Brex" and our friend Stockton Huskinson would be the LinkedIn profile we'd be sending in the email. 

We can use data and AI to show potential prospects that we know them and it doesn't have to be manually researched every time. 

This can all be done with some elbow grease and Clay. Jordan Crawford inspired the idea and actually his workflow is more intense.

content:
Here's a workflow I built that analyzes companies for 7 different triggers and why we should reach out to them. 

This automates a methodology called "Why You, Why Now" I learned from John Barrows. 

I will go over the triggers and you can see the process in the video below!

Trigger 1

New Customer support Team lead and past company support tech

Example of first line: "Hey Suchita, noticed you recently were promoted to Principal Customer Success Manager in March. Before working at 6sense, I saw you worked at Yext. Noticed both companies are using Zendesk and Drift right now. How's your experience with them?"

Trigger 2 

Customer support team growth by percentage and looking for those that are in a qualifying range.

Example of first line: I noticed that 6sense added 20 customer support people in the last 3 months. Are your current processes still working with the team growth?

Trigger 3

New Product Launch and leverage AI to discuss what support questions might come up with it.

Example of first line: I figured customers might reach out for support around things like utilizing the new AI Writer tool in their sales process.

Trigger 4 

No Support tech on site. We can even compare this to how many employees the company has and how long they have been in business. 

Example of first line (not for 6sense): Noticed you aren't using any support tech on the site. I'd imagine that since the business was founded in 2014 and you just broke 100 employees that your old processes might not be working any more. 

Trigger 5 

Using competitive support tech on site and have different things to say depending on which competitor they are using. 

Example of first line: Noticed you're using Zoho Support, have you found their multichannel inbox to be useful in support or are things falling through the cracks?

Trigger 6

Hiring for Customer Support and use AI to deduct tasks that are mentioned in the job description that your tool could optimize or replace!

Example of first line: Noticed you're hiring for as Customer Support Associate. Took a look at the job description and it looked like they will need to respond to emails with appropriate answers to customers. Are you thinking about how AI can be leveraged to speed up this process?

Trigger 7 

They have a generic support email and either no support tech on site OR they have support tech on site (which lets us know that they need to have everything in one place).

Example of first line: Noticed on the site you weren't using a support software but I found support@domain.com is up there. Are you finding that you can answer all of your support questions without dropping things with just an inbox?

In a follow up email, we could say something like below to keep the personalization going. 

"I figured customers might reach out for support around things like leveraging 6sense's AI for creating and converting high-quality pipelines."

As always, let me know what you think!

content:
Here's how we created a fully automated 5.1% positive response rate campaign for Clay with Clay. All a human has to do is hit play.

I'll share the copywriting and then a play by play in the video attached of how we got it done. 

Email 1

subject: Outbound edge

{{First Name}}  I was on your site and it looks like you sell to {{job titles}} titles. It looked like you are helping {{AI Generation}}.

I had to assume you are using outbound tactics considering {{Full Name of SDR}} is an {{SDR/BDR}} on the team. 

Are you thinking about how they could be leveraging better data and GPT-4 to do their prospecting?

The reason I ask is because we are helping companies like Rippling and Ramp with our tool that collects the data and writes the messaging for them. 

Would this be worth a chat to build a custom outbound table for you?

Email 2

{{First Name}}  as youre helping people {{Ai generation}}, Id imagine you are using outbound marketing tactics like the following. 

{{Creative Ideas}} 

Have you cracked how to do this persona targeting and data enrichment automatically or is your team still using tools like Sales Nav to do manual research?

If so, would it be worth taking some time to show you how we can automate persona and account research for your outbound team?


Email 3 

Subject: show and tell

{{First Name}}  I sent an email a while back with the subject Outbound edge that probably didnt do a good enough job showing you how we could help your outbound team. 

Our tool combines over 40 databases into one spreadsheet so that your team can see all of the data in front of them instead of manually researching accounts. 

For example at your company

It looks like your sales team has seen a {{percent change}}% change in the past 3 months.Â 
Your LinkedIn Company account has gained {{number of Followers}} in the past 3 months.Â 
The company looks like it has {{Number of sales people}} people with Sales in their title based in the United States today. 

Besides cute things like this, we also monitor for recent news, open job positions, tech on site and mentioned in job descriptions and a lot more. 

On a call, we can build a custom workflow for your team to automate their outbound research. Wanna make it happen?

Email 4

{{First Name}}  Perhaps this is not your area of focus. Should I potentially reach out to {{Other sales/marketing person in the company thats NOT them}} given their role as a {{Job title cleaned with AI}}.
____
Overall, everything was done with data gathered from LinkedIn and AI. No other crazy databases were needed to make this happen. 

This campaign also disqualifies far more people than it puts in. For instance, if we don't detect a BDR/SDR, the workflow ends and we don't reach out to the person. I only wanted this campaign to go out to people that would qualify for every data point. If they don't, I'd find something else to reach out to them with. 

Check out the video below on how I put it all together. #outbound

content:
I used Clay and GPT-4 to write a 4 step email sequence for Taplio where every email is personalized. It got it's first positive response off of the first 25 emails sent. 

I'll share the copy here and how we did everything step by step. If you want to see a YouTube video of how I did it, I can post that as well. 

Taplio is my LinkedIn scheduling tool of choice because of how easy they make content creation. 

Email 1 

{{First name}}  Saw one of your recent LinkedIn posts about {{AI generation}}. Seems like the last time you posted was {{number of days}} days before that though. 

If youre trying to build your brand on LinkedIn, have you considered using a scheduling tool?

Our scheduling tool can help write your posts and help you monitor social trends that you can riff on as well. 

Let me know if this would be useful to you and I can send over access!

____

The way we did this is by scraping their last 3 post results. We need 3 because we are actually calling out their second most recent post and getting the time difference between post 2 and 3 so that we can make that second line happen.

We will use their actual most recent post for the bump which is right here. 
____
Email 2

{{First Name}}  I just saw your post about {{AI generation}}. It reminded me to follow up and see if you saw this!

____

I despise follow ups that don't add value to the sequence. This is on brand and provides some serendipity as to why we are following up. We use their most recent LinkedIn post here so we don't have to double dip for the data. 
____

Email 3

{{First Name}}  I keep seeing your content online so I made some more post ideas considering what your company does and how you promote it. 

{{Creative Ideas}} 

This is just some examples of what our AI can generate for you (and you havent even given it your insights yet!) 

Let me know if I could send over some access for you to try it out. 

____

One of my favorite features of Taplio is that it helps you create content using AI generated suggestions. I took the person's recent posts and their company description to create more creative post ideas that they could bring to LinkedIn with the power of Taplio.

____

Email 4

{{First Name}}  just like how Facebook pages killed their organic reach, it can be expected that LinkedIn will do the same one day.

I saw your LinkedIn company page had {{number of Followers}} followers and you had about {{number of followers}} followers. 

As you are building your following, are you maximizing the platform's organic reach before it gets oversaturated?

We helped companies like Lemlist and Outreach double down on their social content with our analytics, scheduling, and content generation tool.

Could I send you access to try it out?Â 
____

Here we use AI to extract out and normalize their followers so that we can mention in an email. The angle here is to remind them that LinkedIn Organic reach won't be around forever!

Anyone want the YT Video?

content:
If you sell to industries with low LinkedIn presence, steal my framework to still get a positive response. 

If you don't sell into these industries you might not know that getting the email of an owner or founder of a bowling alley or dance studio is very difficult. 

2 reasons for this

1) They often use a contact@bowlingalley.com email address or a free email address for their communication. 

2) Even if you have their email address, often they don't have a LinkedIn profile that you can confirm their identity and seniority with. 

This means that when you are sending emails, you look way more like a spam email than you when sending your other spam emails with just a {{First Name}} variable. (See my other posts to get past just one custom variable)

This is what we have done and gotten much better results. 

First, we start with analyzing their reviews and looking for SEO metadata. Something that can tell us more about what the company does and what people are saying about them. 

Then we create customization based on region to further niche down. 

Finally, I like to pull out more data for a P.S. line to keep the personalization going. 

You could end up with an email like this 

Hey there, 

I was taking a look at {{Company Name}}'s reviews on Yelp and saw Monica loves the attention she gets when she visits Dr. Dave for her chiropractor visits. How does Dr. Dave fill last minute cancellations? 

The reason I ask is because we are helping {{case study name in the area}} fill in last minute cancellations with a waitlist of patients. (And with over 455 google reviews, I'm sure you have a great waitlist). 

Let me know if you want to see an under 3 minute video of how it works!

Signature

P.S. noticed you're based on Main street, do you get a lot of walk in traffic from people passing by? Couldn't tell from Google Maps.

You could create this whole email using Yelp scraping, Google My business scraping, and some light AI prompting. All of which you can of course find automatically using Clay

content:
Even Clickup just promoted an AI prompt template giveaway. You could respond to all of these but it's not going to help you build anything. 

Everyone has their "Use these 305 templates to have perfect prompts" but I'm surprised at how people aren't talking about the foundations of AI prompting. 

Gpt-4 is like a 5 year old at a bowling alley. It has zero chance of making a strike but if you give it enough guard rails, direction and help it roll the ball, it'll get a strike every time.

This is framework I use for making prompts that are ready to be sent in cold emails. 

1. Define what you want the AI to accomplish generally. 
2. Give it all inputs that are necessary for it to make decisions. DO NOT ask it to tell you what a company does based on a website and no other information. It has no clue. 
3. Constrain the creativity of the AI. Give it guard rails like respond in only lower case letters, keep the output under 8 words, use keywords from the input, etc. 
4. Give AI examples of what a good output would look like. 

These 4 steps are what I use to guide my prompting so I don't need to rely on someone on twitter to make it for me.

content:
Most SDRs shouldn't be spending their time sending emails.  
 
A lot to unpack here so I'm going to lay it all out and I do want to note that this is continue trying to understand if I'm wrong.  
 
Am I saying that there's never a reason SDRs should be manually researching and sending emails. No.  
 
From what I've seen at Clay and my agency, 99% of the playbooks that companies can be automated and they just don't know it.  
 
Then you might ask, "Well Eric then they should update their playbooks." 
 
Well, I agree. So then I help them update their playbooks and it still can be automated.  
 
There's so much data in the world now and with the radical changes in GPT-4 to infer data for you (yeah that's right infer, not write) systems can send better emails at scale than SDRs.  
 
And good riddance too right? Now they can spend their time cold calling, building relationships, posting on LinkedIn, video prospecting, etc.  
 
The only playbooks that I have seen so far i that cannot be automated to my knowledge is when there is no clear way to get the data automatically or there could be 35 reasons a person might reach out and it is cost prohibitive for them to check all 35.  
 
I mostly posting this to see if anyone has other perspectives as I flesh this out more. Let me know in the comments if you agree or disagree.

content:
10 reasons to reach out to prospects and how to get that data automatically.  
 
 
- People that have the same investors 
 
Get this one on Crunchbase or Harmonic pretty easily. 
 
- Targets that change roles in the company 
 
Use Clay to monitor for ICP's that change company or hook up your Sales Navigator to your email. Break out the emails into spreadsheets with webhooks and AI. (Maybe I should make a YouTube video on this). 
 
- The company raised funds / went IPO 
 
Again, Crunchbase, Harmonic, Pitchbook 
 
- People that registered for events that talk about your value proposition 
 
Scrape LinkedIn events but I wouldn't call out the event, just use it as general targeting and do other research to be relevant.  
 
- Team growth 
 
Use Clay's team growth integration to find growth in various time intervals.  
 
- Past customers that changed jobs 
 
Use Clay to monitor your CRM for a contact going to a new company.  
 
- People that comment under your LinkedIn posts 
 
Again, you could set up LinkedIn notifications to feed from your inbox to a spreadsheet using Webhooks and AI.  
 
- Uses a complementary/competitor tool 
 
The king of all solo SaaS companies, BuiltWith of course.  
 
- Targets that change company 
 
Reach out to people as they are new to their role using Sales Navigator or again Clay.  
 
- A company is hiring 
 
Target open job roles with the Predict Leads integration in Clay or ping Jordan Crawford! 
 
I'm sure I'm missing a ton but thought this might help some people thinking about their first outbound triggers!

content:
Email deliverability tips from sending 700k+ emails per month.  
 
After you have your SPF, DKIM, DMARC and custom domain tracking set up, nothing matters more than putting a good offer in front of the right people.  
 
I see a lot of talk about turning off open tracking, spintax, no links, no images, etc.  
 
And don't get me wrong, all of these are best practices and you should always try to implement as much as you can.  
 
But I've seen campaigns sending images with calendar links that resonated with the audience like crazy and had tons of responses. We tried turning off open tracking and there wasn't a huge difference.  
 
I've seen campaigns with fresh new inboxes and not a great message market fit burn inbox after inbox.  
 
All the setup is important, but your message and your list are more important. Just keep that in mind.

content:
This is how we resurrected a bad campaign from the dead and pumped out a 3.2% positive response rate. 

One of our customers sells essentially fractional CFO services to CEOs. Great case studies and they were targeting the right people but it was tough to grab the attention of prospects with the copywriting they were using before we came in.

So we turned the relevancy up a notch and scanned each prospects company for finance and accounting team members.  

If they had a CFO already - one message was sent

If they had an accountant on staff - a different message was sent 

If they had a bookkeeper - a whole other message was sent. 

We scanned for essentially 6 different personas and messaged each one differently and kept it relevant to the situation the CEO was in. 

Ultimately resulting in actually getting positive responses. 

To do this, you can simply use the Find People integration in Clay 

Dm me if you want to try something like this as well.

content:
Unpopular opinion: I don't think most SDRs should be sending emails. 

Hear me out. 

Cold email in 2023 has become a task for at minimum a no code expert as and better yet, a low code engineer. 

DNS settings, web scraping, proxies, IP address sending, domain reputation, AI warming, Artificial Intelligence generating text, data vendors, email verification etc make sending emails quite an laborious endeavor. 

This is a cold email I pulled out of my spam folder (improper DMARC Authentication and SPF misalignment). Take a look 

________________________________________________________________________

I hope you dont mind me touching base again Eric.

Its just that I know how valuable the *redacted* platform can be for business owners like us. 

Stop wasting thousands of $$$ on lead data and use their tools instead. You could have +640 million prospects at your fingertips by tomorrow&.
__________________________________________________________________________

Besides this being a spray and pray email, I think about how the SDR that loaded this into a sequence had to think about building the list, (HOPEFULLY) validating the emails, check the custom variables, load all of the copywriting, etc. 

Only to land in my spam folder and send a very very generic message. 

With tools like Clay leads can be auto categorized with AI, I could have even written about types of lists prospects could be building using AI, aligned all of the DNS settings, and sent hundreds of emails in the time an SDR can usually send 50. 

Are the exceptions to this, sure. But for the most part, I've seen far too many reps manually saving 25 leads at a time and putting them into their sequencing tool with no better changes to the messaging than Hey {{first name}}. 

I think SDR's time is spent far better on the phones, sending spears on LinkedIn, managing current relationships, being present in online communities, and posting useful content on LinkedIn.
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
Show, don't tell, your prospects how you can help them. I was just on a call with Bojan MItevski discussing how he could possibly leverage AI in his outbound campaigns. 

He runs an animated video creation agency and has helped awesome growth hacking companies in the past. 

I suggested he could use AI to generate animated video ideas for his outbound prospects so they could imagine what an animated video on their site would look like. 

I whipped up the prompt in 10 minutes and here were some results of AI generated ideas a company can leverage animated video with. 


1. This one is for a company called Compass and they are a 3PL/4PL provider. 

- Animate a video of a small business owner experiencing how easily they can navigate the global market with Compass 4PL's logistical services.
- Create a video for e-commerce businesses showcasing how utilizing Compass 4PL's supply chain management can increase customer satisfaction.
- Have a video on your website showing the benefits of Compass 4PL to enterprise-level companies who want to streamline their logistics in a cost-efficient manner.

2. This is for a company called Sync Energy AI. Sync Energy AI is an energy AI company that allows energy and insurance professionals to run complex simulations in a no-code analytics environment.


- Create a video for energy managers to see how they can save money through risk management using Sync Energy AI.
- Animate a video for insurance adjusters to visualize the potential impacts of climate change and how Sync Energy AI can help.
- Have a video on your website showing how city leaders can ensure their critical infrastructure is protected with Sync Energy AI.

3. This is for a company called Digiphy which helps brands go beyond the label to forge meaningful, contextual connections that convey brand values and promote authenticity.

- Create a video that showcases how grocery shoppers can trust the product they're buying with Digiphy's labeling technology.
- Animate a video for e-commerce businesses on how to increase conversions using Digiphy's storytelling tools.
- Have a video on your website showing small business owners how easy it is to create an immersive online shopping experience using Digiphy.


If your product or service requires any kind of new creativity or new ideas, you can ship these ideas in your outbound emails to help your prospects better imagine what working with you would look like. 

This can be improved by taking more of his actual case studies and what he has done but I think this is a fun way to send relevant emails to prospects to connect the dots on exactly what you do.
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
3 steps we took to increase a clients open rate by 900%. When they came to us, they had a 7% open rate. We brought it up to 72%. 

The sales team reported to us that they had a higher intent than their other paid marketing forms. We sent roughly 2000 emails per day in the campaign.

Here were the top 3 things we did. 

1. Multi inbox, multi domain rotation. If you haven't seen this yet, you need to start researching it. Stop sending from your main domain, start sending from satellite domains. 

2. We knew that the industry would have a higher spam complaint rate. So instead of our usual sending 50 emails per day per inbox, we only sent 25. Allowing us to spread the reputation across even more inboxes and be friendlier to the ESPs. 

3. We used Google Maps location data provided to us by scraping with Clay so that we could personalize the message with a current customer success story in their area AND we personalized the P.S. line to their street address and the Google Traffic data (targeting realtors here).

Obviously, a solid offer and unique selling proposition are important but there are numerous levers for us to pull on if you already have that nailed down. 

Email delivery is one that we see too many people not taking seriously enough and you are basically a YouTube video away from knowing 80% of the information.

content:
I see too many people using AI and Chat GPT incorrectly. They are trying to get it to right their whole email and sometimes I see them trying to write completely "custom" emails.

Here's the problem

1. Chat GPT given too many tasks to do at once, begins to get off track and hallucinate. ex. are you sure it didn't say "I hope this email finds you well" in any of the emails. 

2. When you think about it, you don't actually need it to do all the copy for you. 

You can use it as a tool to help generate the final version but the snippets that actually need to be made for each prospect can be made with higher value and precision when you just focus on that.

3. I know you think it's helping your email delivery, but as of March 30, 2023, I don't think it makes that much of a difference. 

We send 250k emails per month and the highest open rate campaigns do the best job of matching targeted prospects with killer offers. 

The way I like to use Chat GPT is to make inferences on data and then use that data to write AT MOST 8 words. 

Not the whole email, not a whole sequence just 8 highly impactful words for my prospects that will make them understand how our product or service can help them. 

So now the question isn't, "How can I use AI to write my emails" it's "How can I use AI to analyze data and make inferences for my prospect based on the data"

Full video on ideas about this coming soon. Comment below if you want to be one of the first people to know about it.

content:
Let's break down how we got this prospect to respond. 

This particular campaign is selling a SaaS solution. We didn't get this response with any personalization, Chat GPT enrichment, or other dirty tricks. 

We simply targeted companies that all were very similar (employee count, industry, keywords on site etc.) Most importantly, we targeted companies with less than 15 employees, no sales people, and have been in business longer than 2 years. 

We then sent a message with a clearly defined case study about how another company just like them has succeeded with the SaaS solution. 

3 sentences in the whole email. 

Like I said, zero personalization to this person directly. Just a gem of a case study and targeting others that can resonate with that case study.

content:
Last week I launched an automated outbound campaign showing prospects how they could use Clay with 100% personalized tips.

With that in mind, I opened up GPT-4 and got to work. 

The first thing I did is figure out what I want to say. This campaign was for Clay so I knew I wanted to tell people about how they could build incredibly custom lists using the tool. 

I first needed to train the model so I added the company description of 4 companies. I taught Chat GPT that with the inputs of the company description, here are the ideas I would come up with. 

Here's an example of my prompt for Red Bull

__________________________________________________________________________

Using the input, create three bullet points of creative outbound marketing ideas for a company. The ideas have to be possible with cold email marketing. This is the input: "Red Bull | 786,465 followers on LinkedIn. Red Bull Gives Wings to People and Ideas. | Red Bull Gives Wings to People and Ideas.  This drives us - and all we do - since 1987.  Today, Red Bull operates in over 170 countries selling more than 7.9 billion cans annually and growing!" Analyze who their target audience would be by job title and think of creative ways to market to them. Be specific and give unique advice. Keep each bullet under 15 words and use strategies that use outbound marketing. 
__________________________________________________________

The outputs I showed Chat GPT would be answers that I wanted are here. 

- Target event planners: Offer co-branded Red Bull event kits to boost energy during conferences and corporate events.
- Approach sports coaches: Connect to provide Red Bull for team performance enhancement and sponsorship opportunities.
- Target Restaurant Owners: Teach them how to use Red Bull in mixed drinks and what special promotions they could run. 

I repeated that process 4 more times so I knew Chat GPT would understand what I was doing. 

From there, I just inserted the Company description of prospects and automated these lines. Basically saying, not exact copy

"Hey I had a look at your website and I'd bet you're running these outbound campaigns right now"

1
2
3

Do you have a way to build lists of these people automatically? If you don't, I could show you how we build these lists on autopilot with Clay. 

Awesome responses so far and only one person has guessed it was made with AI and they signed up for a free trial the same day. 

I'm going to continue to think more of how this idea of using AI to help prospects envision what life would be like with your product or service so your first touch is highly customized.

title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
I've been on a quest to find follow up emails that actually work. Seeing a 32% increase in Email 3 positive response with this method. 

For anyone that is doing outbound prospecting, we know that follow ups are important but they are not where your money will be made. On most sequences I see, the first emails is responsible for almost all of the positive responses. 

I wanted to put together a sequence that would challenge this. 

So I build a sequence where saved our best data for email 3. My hypothesis here is that someone sees email 1 with an offering and gets email 2 with more detail. 

If they respond to neither, really what are the odds of them being interested now? 

So we broke the thread and sent a completely new email thread for email 3. Used AI to automate the creation of the first line based on LinkedIn company data and PredictLeads data (all done in Clay). 

We taught ChatGPT to analyze open job roles and connect that to the companies mission (probably another post on this soon).

And then instead of using all of our data in Email 1, we just kept it to the open job role we found with Predict Leads and sent a John Barrows "WYWN" type email.

When Email 3 came around, we still sent "WYWN" style, but added the AI personalization. We took an email that had only slightly performed and boosted positive response rates by 32%. 

Why I think this works. 

1. People do need to be followed up with but when they see no good data about their company in anything other than email 1, they roll their eyes.
2. Sending all of your emails in one thread is a little over done in my opinion and we have stopped doing it all together.
3. The lines that we were creating with ChatGPT inside of Clay were borderline unbelievably good. Can't wait to see how GPT - 4 can enable this. 

Thoughts?
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
Here's a story of how I 4x'd conversion on a cold email campaign by personalize nostalgia. 

The offer? Attracting High Net Worth individuals to invest in off market real estate deals. 

What was working before? Messaging CEOs that had recently been through an acquisition or merger. 

We wanted to add a more personal touch to the campaign as there's not a whole lot that can be done on the targeting side that could be changed. 

We used Clay to find the year that the target prospect graduated college and related a financial event that happened around the time that they graduated college. 

We used this event to be able to point out that even back then there was still opportunity for investments and now is not so different. 

The hardest part was just writing the lines for each financial crisis. We used ChatGPT to assist with this creation and called out some recent financial events (maybe we have to add SVB to the list). 

The whole campaign was easy to put into Clay and now we just add more leads to the campaign without any other work. 

Nice experiment in personalized nostalgia to boost reply rates.

I hear this all the time from Sales teams that want to buy one time lists. Basically they are asking for their whole market in one go and want to use that for the next 6-12 months.

At the minimum, the data is decaying by at least 10% per month because of job changers or promotions and this list is missing the most useful information we can search for. Trigger events

You miss every funding round, every open job trigger, every leadership change, market expansion, new product announcement etc. 

While I understand the economics of doing a 1 time refresh. I don't understand how you can really prospect off of this continuously.

This is the job of the modern seller. To understand their ideal customer enough to know what makes a customer the best fit and then to clearly communicate that to the potential customer.

content:
How I 3x'd a cold email campaigns positive response rates over night using AI. Hit see more (or don't)

A company I was working with was using copywriting that had been their tried and true script in cold email. 

It had a lot of good things going for it. Short copy, value based, soft CTA.

Immediately, I thought it was missing some spice, so I rewrote it to show the prospects how much pain they were in. 

The solution is a social media organization/posting tool in an industry where the prospects need to have a good social presence on 8 platforms at the same time. 

So I took to Clay to get some automations going. 

In this industry, the prospects potential customer will Google their name and their company name immediately to do research. If they don't show up in the top 8 social platforms, it hurts their conversion rate. 

I automated a Google search to see if they top 5 links include those Social platforms when I did the search. 

We then used OpenAI to summarize that data and write a different line based on how many social links came up in the top 5 and if there were any other people that were even intruding on their search. 

We mapped this data as a custom variable into the campaign and overnight so a 3x increase in conversion rates. 

The lesson. How can you show your prospects that they have a problem rather than just telling them about it. Here we just happened to use AI to make it happen. 

Tag someone that needs to use a little more AI in their life. 

#coldemail #outbound

We are reaching out to pest control companies (D7 Lead Finder) to companies that have been in business for over 10 years (Apollo.io), have only had one founder (Clay), have over 4.0 google reviews (Google Scraping in Clay) and have between 10-50 employees. (Clay LinkedIn enrichment). 

(the 6th database I mention is to find their email)

And we mention all of this in the copy. Check it below. 

"{{First Name}} Noticed you've been leading {{company name}} since it's founding in {{year}}. 

Dug a little deeper and was awesome to see your {{over 4.0 rating on Google}}. 

Curious if you've thought about selling your business recently because I know a couple people looking to buy companies in your industry. 

Worth a chat?"

So LinkedIn, can you help me decide? Spam or Not?

content:
"Eric what's your favorite copywriting hack for cold email?" 

I get asked this all the time and I really don't think it matters as much as people think. 

The question you should be asking is not how you can "hack" someone's attention. How can you message them about solving a problem. 

As long as they can clearly understand your value proposition and you are talking to people that you know have the problem (through manual research or with automation like Clay) what you say begins to matter less because you are talking to people that need a solution. 

Spend more time on customer insights and talking to the right people and less time on thinking about adding an attention hack to your email.
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
In 2 years, cold email is going to look more like the Facebook Ad network than what it is today. Let me explain.

10 years ago, ads on smartphones were ridiculous and not customized at all. Now I see ads on instagram for skiing equipment I'm actually somewhat interested in. 

Why? because they have the data to back up why they are serving me the ad.

Cold email will have to be come this both out of technical and brand necessity, cold email must change. 

Technically, messaging will need to be innovated to get around spam filters. Every month there's more updates that crack down on cold email and what you can send. 

The same generic message being sent with just a {{First Name}} variable is an obvious flag for unsolicited messages. 

From a brand perspective, companies that spray and pray their market will built negative reputation and trust with their prospects. 

This is where the need for targeting like an ad network will be needed. 

Delivering messages to those that could actually use your product is paramount today but 100% necessary for survival in the future. 

Emailing people based on 

-job openings
-keywords on site
-new product launch
-shared customers
-shared investors
-target customers
-web traffic
-website technology
-intent
- and so many others 

will be the only way to deliver messages and get responses in the future. 

Start thinking today of how you could send a message prospects would thank you for sending vs. hoping they might respond. 

How to do this?

Change your framework.

What's the most valuable thing you can give away for free? (actually valuable)

What's your most valuable insight you know about a company's customer that they don't know?

Message directly to the pain that you can infer from public information ex. job openings etc.
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

I think about all the time how I was sending 200 LinkedIn connections per day back in 2018 and I didn't take advantage on it nearly as much as I should have. 

Today I'm thinking about what strategies could be improved that we don't even think about how to improve them?

What will Google do about blocking email warm up? Should we be prepared to ditch IMAP all together and start thinking about faking a manual email send?

Hey {{First Name}} with no other relevance maybe worked in 2018 but is barely working today and will for sure not work in the future even just because of spam filters. We need to start think about dynamic prospect lists. Filling in a list of 3000 CMOs and scoring them for intelligence based on the account and persona. 

The difficulty to build an audience only goes up over time. How can we better capture eye balls today that will pay off in the future? (The question that reminded me that I should post today)

What other marketing strategies do we not even think to question to improve but are in need of a huge regroup?

content:
People ask me all the time, "Eric, I have a crusty old data set that needs cleaning, how do I clean it" so here's a couple things to think about when cleaning data. 

First, what inputs do you have? First name, Last name, LinkedIn profile, website, emails, phones, etc?

Second, decide what data you want. Same as above.

Here's some quick software and data sources to help get you what you need. 

Got Full Name and Company and need LinkedIn? Use Clay to find LinkedIn profiles.

Got Business email addresses and want Full Names? Validate the emails and use Apollo.io to fill in your data. 

Need to clean those emails? DeBounce is my go to. 

Got websites and want contacts by title at the company? Use Clay, Findymail, or Apollo.io

Got perfect customers and want look alike lists? Ocean.io

Never settle for half baked data. 

Any other data you need cleaning and enriching, let me know in the comments!

content:
If 2022 was the year of cold email switching to a multi domain multi inbox strategy, 2023 is going to be the year of MX record matching. This is what we are doing about it. 

Even the big guys are not trusting each other anymore. Zoho IP addresses are getting automatically bounced off of Outlook inboxes. Google has a slightly difficult time to delivery to some inboxes that are odd selections in other countries. 

This year it will be time to go behind enemy lines and send email within their system. 

What we are doing about this is setting up systems to provision GSuite and Outlook inboxes and utilising MX Record lookups to match our sending. 

GSuite to GSuite
Outlook to Outlook

The IPs are known by the tech giants and they have a full record of our sending reputation as opposed to when we jump off of their IPs and the other company has to guess. 

Next steps will be to even segment all of the admin consoles so that every part of the system is completely separate from the last.

content:
Unpopular opinion: Follow up emails are nowhere near as important as you think they are. 

Let me explain

I sent 9,137 emails to about 2,500 contacts. So a four email sequence across about 45 days. The email sequence was an inquiry if they would be willing to sell their business. 

Most responses came to the first email hands down. That was also where we got most of our positive responses as well. As the sequence goes on, response rates plummet and the proportion of positive responses to overall responses goes with it. 

This was an experiment to help flesh out a hunch I've had that follow ups were far less important than speaking with net new contacts. So if you are in a market with 10s of thousands of contacts, maybe rethink your sequencing and follow up strategy. 

*Disclaimer: I of course know that positive responses come deeper in the funnel and this isn't a perfect test. I am confident though that my point still stands that if you have a wide market, talking to net new people more often is best. Only 8% of people are in a buying window at a time on average.

Reflecting on my biggest lesson of 2022 and I wish it was more exciting than what it is. 

All year, I have been consuming as many resources as I can to get an edge in marketing and sales. 

Every blog, YouTube video, and course I could get my hands on and with all of that I was looking for those silver bullets that would 10X my understanding of marketing. 

Over the year I took courses on copywriting, read blogs about web scraping, and watched videos about LinkedIn optimization. 

Im making this post to say every single course, book and video I watched came down to one sentence. 

Align your product and services messaging to resonate with your potential customers and get as many people to see it as possible. 

I wish it was more complicated than that but thats what it is. No matter how you skin the cat, this is what it comes down to and thats what all of our jobs are as sales and marketing professionals. 

Going into 2023, Im going to stop wasting time looking for silver bullets and just get back to basics. Follow along if youre with me.

content:
10 research tasks you are doing manually that can be done automatically with Clay

When I speak to sales teams, I love seeing how they research accounts to see if a company is a fit to reach out to because often times, their process can be automated because they are looking for the same signals. Here's some thoughts.

1. Know if a company is B2B or B2C. 

Use Clay to scan their site for keywords like "Free trial", "Enterprise", "get a demo" on the company's website.

2. Find open jobs by keyword at a company. 

You can use PredictLeads and their integration with Clay to find open jobs at your target accounts completely automatically.

3. Use BuiltWith to find companies that are using your competitors or products that you integrate well with. 

4. Find if a website mentions a keyword 

Use the Google Search integration in Clay to find keywords mentioned on a page

5. Find if someone mentions a keyword on their LinkedIn profile or company page

Use the LinkedIn integration to find the summary and experience description of your targets and search the descriptions for Keywords. 

6. Find the G2 Ratings of your target accounts, their score, and their total review count. 

7. Find the target company's website traffic, traffic sources, and competitiors using DataForSEO

8. Automatically scrape a the people that like a tweet and enrich with company information

9. Find news events about companies using the PredictLeads integration.

10. And finally, use OpenAI to ask any question about a given form of inputs and have it analyze data for you.

content:
Cold email campaigns need to shift to 7 month long marathons rather than 2 weeks sprints. Let me explain. 

Most cold email campaigns that I see people running are between 3-5 emails sequence to end in around 2-3 weeks. 

The data clearly suggests that most positive responses come from your first two emails. Maybe the third if you use that to change the angle on your offer and this new angle resonates with your prospects. 

The tail end of most cold email campaigns are falling on deaf ears. And maybe it's not even your product's fault. The prospect is just not deep enough into the pain and needing to make a decision. 

Take Apollo.io for an example. For $99/month, they give you access basically to your own copy of LinkedIn that you can sort and filter through prospects and get emails directly from. On top of that, you can send emails directly from the platform. 

What B2B business in the world does not need that solution? 

The ones that don't know any better. 

Sure Apollo can send loads of emails and it will certainly grab the attention of people that know they need a database, but what about Founders that have never sold something in their life and they are operators/builders? They need to be educated. 

That's why I think we need to be making our email campaigns longer, lead with value in the first 2 emails but try to collect the bottom of the funnel people that know they are in pain. 

Use the emails in the later parts of your campaign assuming your speaking to someone that doesn't know the pain they are in. Provide them with resources of how to run a cold email campaign. How to acquire customers on LinkedIn, etc.  

Be in it for the marathon, not the sprint.

Where else can you directly go to your target customers and ask for interest? 

Paid ads would take time to build the creative, run up a budget, and optimize for conversion - even then you're not getting in front of your true ideal customer. 

LinkedIn could take time to cover serious ground.

Cold Calling I may concede would give you slightly better insights but is more expensive and time consuming to get done. 

Email is the best place to test. Grab an Apollo.io account, get some inboxes spun up on Smartlead or Instantly, and run it up.

Way better to put in these reps early than to build and pray you can find your market after.

Invest in your SDR team and tooling. 

Incentivize them to learn new methods and scrape for new triggers. 

Align the incentives for the first person that your prospects experience as your brand.

Immediately I said, "well, stay our of spam..." 
 
It seems so easy but as people go down the email delivery rabbit hole, they forget why they event went down.  
 
If no one is marking you as spam, you could be sending 2000 emails per day from one Gsuite inbox and go nuts.  
 
But no offer is going to resonate with 100% of the people you message which is why steps need to be taken to protect your delivery and your domain reputation.  
 
But there's no way to save a campaign constantly being marked as spam.  
 
Your offer is more important than everything. If things aren't working, start there every time.

content:
If I had to teach someone cold email copywriting, here's the checklist I would give them. I'm putting this out here because I'm definitely missing bullets and anyone can chime in here. 

1. Keep the message short. No one is going to read a wall of text.
2. Tell them why you are reaching out, how you can help, who else have you helped before.
3. Keep your call to action to gauge interest. "book a call on my calendly" is not the way. I much more prefer, "If we could help you solve this problem, would that be useful to you?"
4. Keep your subject line short and punchy but don't give away the whole email.
5. Don't use traditional break up emails. "I've emailed you 5 times and you haven't responded so I'm letting you know I'm stopping." Who even came up with this?
6. Don't put them on a 17 email long sequence. 
7. Lead with value. What can you tell them about their market, customers, or industry that would actually add value to their lives or business. 

What else would you add? 

cc: the best copywriter in the game Patrick William Joyce
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
Bold prediction: Cold email as an regular outbound channel is going to become even harder in the next 6 months. What's happening and what are we going to do about it?

Threats

Spam folders are increasingly getting smarter and more effective at blocking promotional content. 

Sales Engagement platforms are making it continuously easier and cheaper to launch cold email campaigns. Hence creating a further flywheel for more robust spam filtering. 

Companies like Gated are keeping unsolicited mail completely out of the inbox (this is also an opportunity in disguise).

Prospects are increasingly becoming more frustrated with the amount of unsolicited mail they receive and are marking more emails as spam (again, creating a flywheel for more robust spam filtering).

Email sending platforms (Google/Outlook/Zoho) are becoming stricter about how much unsolicited mail they will tolerate in their systems. 

Opportunities

More interesting data sources are becoming increasingly easy to purchase or get your hands on. These data sources help refine your Ideal Customer Profile down to a more perfect fit ICP. Think turning a lake into a pond. 

Tools like Smartlead are helping prospectors escape the spam filter with a robust warm up pool and multi inbox sending powered by Vaibhav 

Apollo.io continues to add robust filtering straight into the platform with a crazy amount of data coverage. They just released intent data straight into the product as well. See Jennifer Rhima for more. 

And of course Clay continues to ship new integrations so that you can build your own databases. Use their Google Integration to find anything about a company you would usually be looking for. 

What would you add to the list?

cc: Jordan Crawford Jesse Ouellette Jared Robin =% Tom Slocum Amelia Taylor

content:
Lets go over how you can automate congratulating your first level connections on LinkedIn when they change jobs and organize this in your CRM.

All you need is Sales Navigator, Phantombuster, and Clay.

Step 1) Create a Sales Navigator List with just two filters. Add your first level connections and add the Changed Jobs in the last 90 days filter. Save this search so you can reference it again.

Step 2) Go to your Phantombuster account and create a Sales Navigator Search extractor phantom. Connect your account and add the search URL that we just created. Make sure you put this phantom on Watcher mode so that when it runs in the future, no duplicates are pulled.

Run this search so that we have data to populate our Clay table with.

Step 3) Once the search is run, we can start a new table from a source in Clay. Authenticate your Phantombuster account and pull the search into your table.

Note that the LinkedIn profile URL extracted from this search is basically worthless. Use the Enrich Person From Search LinkedIn Integration to find their default URL.

Step 4) Enrich the LinkedIn Company so that we have a domain and you can add the Clay Find Work Email Integration to pull their new email address.
Now you are ready to enrich this data with anything you want. 

You have their new company website, their LinkedIn profile URL, their company URL, etc. 

Everything you need to start enriching for your workflow.

Step 5) Push your data anywhere. I ended this workflow by updating my CRM but you can also use the Phantombuster Integration to send them a message on LinkedIn as well.

With this workflow, you should never miss another job change and youll look like a stud with your first level connections.

I will leave the loom video with the full workflow in the comments!

Happy Hunting!

content:
Does your email personalization end at {{First Name}}?

The bar for a successful cold email gets raised every day. As Outreach and SalesLoft onboard more customers, standing out becomes more difficult. Here are 5 personalization ideas that can be created completely automatically that give your outreach more spice.

Some aim to create highly relevant messaging for your prospects. Others just help question whether or not the email was fully automated or not. 

1) Add how long the person has held the role into your outreach.

"Hey Jared Robin, noticed you've been the Co-Founder of RevGenius since June 2020 so I figured you would be the best person to reach out to."

2) Add how many roles the person held before their current one.

P.S. Vaibhav Namburi, noticed you held 21 jobs before you launched Five2One. If we ever connect, I'd like to know which one was the best experience that inspired Five2One.

3) Pull in technology from their website (points for pulling multiple that integrate with yours).

Hey Rohan Suri, noticed Nooks is using Leadfeeder when I pulled up the Builtwith Chrome extension. These tools are usually using their own proprietary data sets and adding another is going to uncover even more site visitors for you. Can I intro you to my friend Jesse Ouellette who runs a similar product that has been able to identify more leads than Leadfeeder for his users?

4) Mention an audit you did of their competitors

Hey Elric Legloire, noticed Calendly just saw a bump in traffic through paid ads and they recently added a TikTok ads pixel. If I made a video of their new strategy, would you want to see it?

5) Mention local facts or hotspots to get their attention. I like to mention the current weather, the top restaurant in the area, or the top attraction.

P.S. Rocco Savage, noticed you're based in Miami, have you ever tried KYU? I've heard amazing things about it!

Keep in mind a RELEVANT email is always more important than a personal one, but these lines for sure help increase reply rates and email delivery. 

Did I mention that all of these can be made completely automatically using Clay? If you want to see how it's done, send me a DM and I can show you!

content:
Here are 3 ways you can exploit Google to speed up your prospecting.


Many people don't know that Google is easily your most powerful prospecting tool because they don't know how to use it. 

Google search operators allow you to use Google to cut through the noise and return a search for exactly what you want. 

My top 3 operators are 

-site:
-inurl:
-intext:

Site: tells Google, "give me everything that you can index but only on a specific site. Really useful for finding information about a specific company

inurl: tells Google, "Make sure this keyword is in the url"

intext: tells Google, "Make sure this keyword is mentioned on the page"

So now if you are looking for companies that mention enterprise pricing on their pricing page. 

You can search for your prospect accounts with something like 

site:gong.io inurl:pricing intext:enterprise and if no results show up you know they don't mention it, but if a result shows up, they do. 

Use Clay to score thousands of companies at once with Google Search operators!

content:
Here are 8 tips to keep your deliverability high. 

1. Ensure that you are verifying emails before you send. 

Many think that this is a step in their process that they can overlook but it has to be done every single time. Even if you verified the list 30 days ago, verify again.

2. Ensure you are not using Spam words

Even saying Oprah Winfrey in an email will trigger spam filters. Hubspot has a whole list of spam words to keep out of your email. Some are unavoidable, others you just should never use.

3. Ensure your DKIM, DMARC, and SPF are properly aligned.

Try sending an email through the tool you are going to be using for cold email to Mail genius and make sure your settings are right. 

4. Get a 95 or higher score on Mail Genius

This is an awesome tool to use and make sure your email is set up perfectly and you are not on any spam blacklists. It is my favorite because it gives you suggestions on how to fix your email if there's a problem

5. Make sure you are targeting the right people that you can create a relevant message for

The amount of email has increased tremendously since 2020. Make sure that when you are making the list of people you want to email, have a reason to reach out other than they are the CEO. 

6. Use tools to augment how much research you're doing on your prospects.

Use tools that allow you to mention something specific in your outreach. The best way to know where a company is going in the next 6 months is by checking who they are hiring for. Jordan Crawford has all of this data. 

Think about what pain your customers have, who do they hire to fix it, and what might they mention in a job posting that you can mention in an email?

7. Warm your domains

Warming your inboxes and domains is done by joining a group of other people that want to warm their domains as well and you send messages back and forth to each other which increases the reputation of the inbox. 

8. Keep your email short and to the point.

content:
Launch a cold email campaign for $6...

If I had to start all over again with a tiny budget, here's the cold email tech stack I would use. 

First, we need to define the problems we need to solve. 

For a cold email campaign we need 5 things. 

- An inbox to send from
- A way to warm the inbox
- Data to send to
- Validation to protect our inbox
- Email sequencing

If I missed any, let me know in the comments. 

For the Inbox, let's use Gsuite so that you can use Gmass to warm up the inbox for free. $6

For the email warming, like I said above, GMass so that we can warm for free. 
$0

For the Data, there are tons of websites that have monthly free trials that never end. It'd be hacky, but you'll get there. 

Data providers with excellent free trials

- Apollo.io
- Seamless.AI
- Icy Leads
- Hunter.io
- SalesQL
- Slintel, a 6sense company
- LeadIQ

Let me know of any others in the comments. You can also reach out to Jesse Ouellette or Aditya Prakash who will definitely help you out. 

Now we need to validate contacts. Arguably, this is the most important thing to purchase and if you are getting data from free sources, you should probably invest in this. 

NeverBounce is $4 for 500 verifications. If that still breaks the bank, you can again use GMass for their free verification tool. 

You can use HubSpot, Airtable, Notion for free CRMs

Hubspot even lets you book meetings for free. 

When you're ready to launch a campaign, send it through the Apollo.io free trial. 

Now you have a 25ish email per day campaign going for $6-$10 per month. 

Did I miss anything?

content:
Are you using spintax to increase your email delivery? 

There are a ton of factors that come into play when looking at email delivery. 

For example, your email service  provider is definitely looking at how youre sending the emails. 

Are you sending the same message with a different first name to 200 people at the same time? Your email service provider might start putting you in promotions or worse spam. 

This is only one piece of the delivery puzzle, but one thing you can do is use spintax to increase delivery. 

Spintax is when you tell your email automation tool to use multiple versions of an email to the same list. This way, your email service provider sees a different message every time. 

Most tools do it like this 

Hi, my name is Eric and I love {{outbound|email}}.

That would result in either 

Hi, my name is Eric and I love email.

OR

Hi, my name is Eric and I love outbound.

You can layer on even more spins to get more variations. 

This tool helps you visualize and keep count of how many variations you have 

sp1n(dot)me 

For email pros that already know this, have you ever tried spinning your signature with motivational quotes?

If the message is too short and doesnt have a lot of good synonyms, Ill throw 6-10 motivational quotes in my signature to keep my variations over 1000.

content:
How can you make a generic offer pop? Show up at the right time...

I was just speaking with a business that at first I didn't think I could help. They resell software that thousands of other consultants are selling. 

When coming in cold, usually this is a tough nut to crack because of how similar the offer sounds on paper. 

However, there are always public pain points that you can track and be the first to talk about in your sales conversation. 

This includes things like...

- Website traffic 
- Social media growth
- Employee headcount growth/attrition
- Employee department growth/attrition
- Job board data (Jordan Crawford has it all)
- What kind of tech is installed in their website
- What activity are they showing up with on LinkedIn
- Does their sales team have Sales Navigator
- Do they have any kind of content led motion
- Did they raise 12 months ago and are probably looking for some dry powder

And the list can go on. 

The best thing we can do is to layer these pain points in outbound motions that not only arm your email sequences, but enable the rest of your sales process.

content:
If you could teach a master class on one thing what would it be? 

I was just asked this in a mastermind application I just filled out and immediately, I said Cold email. 

I have spent so much time and practice learning Cold email. Especially for early stage companies, it is the biggest bang for your buck, most scalable channel that they can lean into.

And I know at these early stage companies, every dollar is irreplaceable. I teach cold email as the beginning of everything because this is where you get your message right. This is where you learn if you have product market fit. 

Can you disturb someone's inbox and compel them to positively respond to your offer?

In the inbox, it's you versus them as far as compelling the conversion.

On Google and Facebook there are thousands of reasons why your campaign didn't perform and startups just don't have time or money to figure that out.Â  

So many people look down on cold email but they don't take note that even Product Led Growth companies understand that it's a great way to target exactly the clients they want and enter them into a conversation.

Taking in all of the excitement and education at the Bitcoin 2022 conference. Here are the top 5 things I learned. 

1) There is so much funding going into these projects, based on rewards alone, you can get your ticket paid for by downloading apps for a day. 

2) The enthusiasm for bitcoin is so much bigger than I had originally thought. The people here truly see it as the future and the community is incredibly open to new people. 

3) Speaking of being open, the people are extremely friendly and I havent seen any gatekeeping. But work needs to be done to bring more women and people form diverse backgrounds into the community. 

From my estimation, the conference is probably 80% men. 

4) Decentralized Finance is definitely the future. So many companies are empowering users to take ownership and control of their own finances. Banks will have a tough time keeping up. 

5) With all the enthusiasm, there are some reminders of the risks. What if the technology does something with a negative externality we havent seen yet? What if manhole countries ban it? Can a major country ban it?

Overall, coming to this conference has me even more enthused for bitcoin and web3 in general!

content:
3 ways to level up your cold outreach today. 

TL;DR: Define your niche, reach out with a trigger backed by data, use an Ai tool like SmartWriter to level up your outreach.

So much of cold outreach feels like spam because your targeting is incorrect, you are reaching out to the wrong people, and you are not personalizing your messaging. 

Targeting

When targeting companies or people for your offer, I find most people are not using a specific enough niche. I think a lot of people are past the "I'll sell to anyone that will buy from me" phase. 

But now, many are still keeping their niche to "Software Tech company that just raised a Series A"

Come on now, we need a lot more targeting finesse than just that. Why not B2B software companies that do not have a VP of Sales in place, have raised anywhere from Pre-Seed-Series A, and do not have a product led growth function. 

Little bit better right?

Now let's talk about who in the organization you should be reaching out to. 

Most of the time, I like to start with the Founder or CEO because the best thing that can happen is to have them delegate me down to the right person. 

Otherwise, if you have customers already, take a look at the roles and responsibilities of your customers. 

What are they responsible for? How is success measured in their job?  How large is their team?

Finally, personalization. For outreach with a contract value between $1,000-$5,000, I like to use 2.5 levels of personalization. (I say 2.5 because the .5 is the person's name. That is more of a requirement than a suggestion)

The other 2 are a trigger event and a personalized line. 

The trigger event is the event, factor, stat, etc. that qualifies this person as a potential buyer for my company. 

Hopefully, you have something much better than a funding round but that still works. This could also include mass hiring, layoffs, product outages, change of pricing, etc. 

I lead the email with this. 

At the end, I use a P.S. line by SmartWriter (Vaibhav Namburi is the founder) to really hit home that this message was meant for that person. My personal favorite is mentioning a restaurant in their area. 

Using even 1 of these will level up your cold outreach for this week. 

Happy prospecting. #b2b #sales #growth

content:
LinkedIn doesn't want you know this. 

95% of databases that provide quality contact information use LinkedIn to source their data. The amount of data that can be connected just by giving a software a LinkedIn URL is amazing. 

So how do you get enough LinkedIn URLs to make it worth your time? Getting them from LinkedIn has limitations and it's pay to play.

I tell everyone, don't get your links from LinkedIn, get them from Google.

There are search parameters that help you get EXACTLY what you want on Google. If you are looking for results that require two inputs like Female Founders. You can modify the search by adding AND to increase the accuracy. 

ex. Female AND Founders

There is a function called site: that allows you to look for results that are only from one site. (I think you know where we are going from here).

search site:www.linkedin.com {{Person Full Name}} {{Company Name}}

99% of the time, the first result on google will be the linkedin URL of the person that you want to contact. 

Bring this process to a Google sheet with some fancy concatenation and combine with a tool to extract the first search result (like botster) and you can untap an infinite amount of LinkedIn urls.

content:
Good marketing always puts people first. 

In 2010, no one would have been caught dead without a gated e-book marketing campaign. Today, I believe most companies need to be focused on building engaging communities in service of their Ideal Customer's. 

Businesses typically have to alter to survive in times of extreme upheaval. Many others, on the other hand, prefer to wait for the tide to change before moving. 

A community-driven transformation may invigorate workers and put them ahead of the competition. It's a horrible plan. A corporation may improve itself through communicating to its consumers, channel partners, workers, government, society, and investors. 

Abolition of non-value-adding products and services allows for fresh project development.

Spending is maintained under control by concentrating all efforts on recognizing and satisfying changing community needs. This assists to promote fresh development and future expansion.

 Lou Gerstner revolutionized IBM precisely like this. To break up the massive corporation, Gerstner devised "Operation Bear Hug," which required everyone in the organization to reach out to their most significant clients and find out their greatest issues. 

This discovery led to IBM's rebranding as the "e-business" corporation, today known as IBM.

In tough circumstances, people want to feel part of a community more than before. 

To develop long-term connections with consumers, organizations must create communities that give both practical and emotional value, and have staff and customers collaborate to solve challenges. 

Good marketing always puts people first. Using a group's combined strength is effective marketing in hard times.

content:
To my newly placed or young professional managers...5 things I wish I focused on as I grew in responsibility in my career

In order to be a successful leader, it is important to establish good management practices right from the start. 

By taking the time to learn and implement the following tips, you can set yourself up for success and help your team achieve their goals.

1. Communicate effectively 

As a new leader, it is crucial to communicate effectively with your team. 

This means sharing information clearly and concisely, listening attentively, and being responsive to questions and concerns. In order to build trust and ensure that everyone is on the same page, regular communication is key.

2. Set clear goals

It is important to set clear and achievable goals for your team. This helps them stay focused and motivated, and makes it easier to track progress.

3. Establish procedures

Establishing procedures gives your team the guidance they need to succeed. 

Even if you think something is obvious, it's worthwhile to take the time to write great guidelines (for example, creating a standard work order or list of tasks). 

It can also help to ask employees what processes they would like established.

4. Create a culture of accountability

When employees are accountable for their actions, you will find it easier to make decisions and respond to challenges. 

If they feel like there aren't consequences for poor performance or mistakes, they may act with impunity. 

Establishing clear guidelines helps your team hold each other responsible without micromanaging or becoming frustrated.

5. Give regular feedback

Regular feedback is key to helping your team improve performance, increasing motivation, and maintaining good morale. 

Employees will feel valued if they can tell you are taking an interest in their careers, accomplishments, and work issues. 

Even informal feedback (such as giving hugs, high-fives or fist bumps) can be appreciated by your team and help to build a strong rapport.
