content:
How many of us are forgetting the most important rule about selling? Buyers buy on emotion and then justify with logic. 

Rob Turley called me out in a slack channel we both interact in run by Justin Michael (it's over 19k now, you should really join ;)

Julia Nimchinski asked what is the most important tactic when selling on social.

I said providing value of course. Forgetting that the feeling and the emotion that your product or service invokes is far more important than the stated and proven ROI benefits of the product. 

Everyone's brain is like an the combination of an elephant and a rider. The elephant is our emotions and the rider is our logical brain. 

The elephant moves left, the rider claims he wanted to do that all along. The elephant stops, the rider justifies that he needed a break. The elephant turns left, the rider says it is where he needed to go. 

Clubhouse invoked feelings of fear of missing out (FOMO) to galvanize users to join their platform. (remember when people were PAYING for clubhouse invites...)

TexAu (founder Vikesh Tiwari) helps me feel relief knowing that I can automate manual tasks and spend my time in better ways. 

Patrick William Joyce helps me feel more confident that the cold email campaigns I write will actual stick. 

Buyers buy on emotion, and justify with logic.

#startups #entrepreneurship #business #leadership

content:
Many first time entrepreneurs are enthusiastic about their idea, but lack the experience necessary to succeed. The three most common mistakes that new entrepreneurs make are not focusing on their customers, spending too much time pitching investors, and they hesitate to build a team. 

These errors can lead to business failure if they are not corrected before it is too late!

-Not Focusing on Customers: Too often, first time entrepreneurs become so wrapped up in their product or service that they forget to focus on their customers. 

It is essential to remember that a business exists to serve its customers, not the other way around! Without customers, there is no business.

Spending Too Much Time Pitching Investors: Another common mistake is spending too much time pitching investors rather than building the business. 

-It is important to remember that investors are not the only ones who can help a business succeed. 

A successful business is built by focusing on customers and product/service development, not by chasing investment dollars.

-Hesitating to Build a Team: One of the biggest mistakes that first time entrepreneurs make is hesitating to build a team. 

Developing the right team will be essential for success, especially if you are an entrepreneur with little business experience or knowledge. #leadership #startups #entrepeneurship

content:
Are you trying to grow your business or Social following? You may have heard of the $1.80 strategy. Let's talk about what $1.80 looks like in 2022.

Gary Vaynerchuk teaches and used this strategy to build authority and social following. 

The idea is to go into a hash tag of the audience you want to break into and leave an insightful comment (or your 2 cents) on 90 posts a day. Thus adding up to $1.80.

This can still be effective, however, with the rise of what some call Dark Social there are much better strategies now. 

BTW I'm glad you asked. Dark Social includes private groups of people that are congregating on Social platforms privately. Think Facebook Groups, Discord channels, Slack Workspaces, etc. 

These people join these groups to trade ideas, learn, and communicate with people around a specific topic. Often times a topic that builds an audience of your Ideal Customer...

Search out these Dark Social Groups and instead of start speaking in the groups. Ask questions, answer questions, build rapport. Leave your .02 cents all over wherever you can add value. 

It's so much better than mindlessly scrolling a hashtag full of garbage when you could be engaging with someone that needs your product or service right now OR they have a question you could answer. 

Try it out, and let me know what you think. #business #leadership #startups

content:
Do you know how to extract unlimited searches out LinkedIn?

LinkedIn is the best B2B database in the world. It has phenomenal self reported data that people are incentivized to keep updated. 

The guards at LinkedIn keep everything under wraps though so that you have to pay to play and it's difficult to take advantage of the platform.

They are always on the lookout for malicious scraping, automation, spamming etc. 

Normal accounts can only view 10 results per page at a time. Pay to Play users get a whopping 25 per page. 

LinkedIn URLs are so powerful that with them, many data platforms allow you to unlock so much information. 

So how can you get as many as you want?

Easy. 

Open up Google sheets, concatenate a search to say "site:linkedin.com (Contact First Name) (Company Name)"

Take it over to a tool like Link Prospector and let it extract all of those search URLs for you.

content:
How much sales tech is too much sales tech?

There are countless amounts of data providers, scrapers, web crawlers, CRMs, document signing platforms, etc. 

At what point is it too much and your data just becomes noise? 

In my high school physics class, we were learning about reducing friction and my teacher asked how much silicon should we use to grease model train tracks. 

She reminded us that you need to put on a perfect amount. Not too much and not too little. Too much and the silicon becomes it's own source of friction. Too little and the object won't overcome the friction. 

It's easy to get lost down the rabbit hole of using too many tools and every company is different. There's no one catch all answer for what is too many tools.

DKIM, SEP, MQL, ICP, SPF, MVP, ICO, CSR, BDR...acronyms are a barrier in your culture

At 10X Incubator, things move incredibly fast. We have calls with farming data integration tools that are currently selling right into Social platform companies that are in product development right into Blockchain company meetings about fundraising.

Hat Tip to our Chief Product Officer Seth Winters, we are banning all acronym usage. Acronyms make it difficult for new hires to get onboarded and feel included. I know our cofounders feel the same way. 

Also, there could be confusion that no one is asking about and we need to get information transferring across our team.
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
How are you formatting your content on LinkedIn?

LinkedIn is an interesting platform because very few people actually post on it. (This is obvious because your newsfeed is still filled with fake activity like the fact that my friends are liking posts.)

LinkedIn rewards users that can post content that retains users on the page. Whatever you can do to stop the scroll will be rewarded by LinkedIn.

Alex Lieberman seems to be taking a twitter approach and using very few characters but staying punchy just like twitter.

Justin Michael is creating long form content that gives away 10% of what he usually shares in his micro-community, "Salesborgs"

Jesse Ouellette is breaking the internet with polls that make you question your beliefs and then you are rewarded with social proof or punished with being outside of the crowd (or vice versa depending on how you look at it)

What other formats for written content are you seeing on LinkedIn and what's the best way to go?

#linkedin #10X #10XIncubator #startups #entrepreneurship #SaaS

content:
Advancement means opportunities but how do we arrive at that advancement?

Take, for example, the issue of switching everyone to electric cars on our current electrical grid. A recent study showed that in NJ if 50% of people switched to electric cars we would have to double the amount of our current electricity. 

Our grid would not be able to support everyone plugging their cars in at the same time every night. But what if AI was able to control who was charging at what time to be able to stop the grid from overloading?

In the interest of Extreme Ownership, I admit I am no expert in electricity or AI technology, but is there anyone watching this that is and has a solution to this issue?

#Innovation #AI #Tech #OnAMission #WorldChange #Entrepreneurship

content:
If everything is your fault, everything can be fixed by you.

This is a philosophy I try to live by, the idea of Extreme Ownership (from the book by the same name). By admitting not only what I know, but what I don't know, I can take control because it is always my fault- I did not provide the resources, I did not listen to my experts, etc. Only by admitting my fault can I begin to take back control and work directly with my team to use everyone's expertise to achieve results.

My question for all of you today is what kind of leader do you want to become?

And do you have a tech idea that will help you become that leader?

content:
3 ways to separate your profile from the flood of requests influencers receive. 

Social Media has given people so many amazing ways to connect. I often reach out to my favorite authors on LinkedIn and can tell them how much I enjoyed their book where as this would have had to happen by fate in the past. 

But how do you stand from the crowd? Social Media has made it so easy to connect with people and this ease has made a tidal wave of requests from followers requesting influencers time and energy. 

Here are 3 ways to separate yourself from the crowd when reaching out to people with a large audience. 

1) Follow and engage with them first
It costs nothing to send a DM. Influencer will take notice if they see you giving positive comments on their posts.

2) Keep your message short

Someone with an audience has many requests at all times, keep your request short and to the point.

3) Target people that have deep engagement with the audience you want to attract. 

Just because Logan Paul has 14 million subscribers doesn't mean that it would be worth your time.

content:
Who should in your top 100 list? 

Yesterday, I spoke about creating a list of 100 people you would like to meet and sharing it with your established and new network which you can find here 

But who should you put on your list? Elon Musk, Tony Robbins, Dave Portnoy, Warren Buffet?? All of these people have immense connections and status but how would they affect your business? 

Unless you have a way to bring thoughts into the world directly, Elon Musk would probably not add too much to your brand and company. 

When adding people to your top 100 list, think of who is in your industry that is missing what you have or has status and expertise with the market that you want to target.

Thoughtful, targeted engagement is far better than lofty wishful, clout. 

#marketing #business #leadership #startup #entrepreneur #network #cilalabs #teamwork

content:
What is Blockchain?

Technology is not unusual in the sense that it goes through fads of explosion and obscurity. One of the ideas that is getting the most traction is blockchain technology. The problem is there seems to be a misunderstanding of how blockchain technology works. For instance, every crypto is a blockchain, but not every blockchain is a crypto.

Then there is the problem of what needs to be a blockchain  Is it important enough to be kept on a database that every change is seen by everyone? How do we decide what is important enough to keep on a secure database and what can we leave out?

Do you have an idea that needs a blockchain to be secured? 

Submit Your Tech Idea Here: www.cilapartner.com #blockchain #crypto #tech #fintech #innovation

My job is to figure out what kinds of guests or events can garner enough interest that people would pay. Something I have been quandering since March.

content:
*If you want to skip straight to the part where I skydive, skip to 2 minutes into the video*

As many people know, I have two brothers in the Army. I have seen up close and personal the positive benefits that come with serving in the military. From College tuition payments to paid technical training, the army has a wide array of benefits that many people can utilize. 

Every year, I send hundreds of students to talk with their local Army recruiting station. If they do not have a set plan to go to college and know exactly what they want to do, I tell them they should seriously consider the Army enough to just hear what they have to offer. 

Yesterday, I was selected among 30 other community influencers around NJ to jump with the Premier Golden Knights Parachuting team. They were an exceptional group of people and were great to jump with. We networked with other Community Influencers to reach one common goal, spreading the information about the Army to as many people as possible. 

Thank you again to the U.S. Army for the opportunity yesterday. Im looking forward to our continued partnership!

 #leadership #business #networking #news #newjersey #community #recruiting #students #team #opportunity #gatewaychamberofcommerce

content:
The first thing we need to realize about influencing and persuading. Humans are not rational. We operate on feelings and then justify with logic. 

In a study, a liquor store played French music or German music in particular days. French wine sales increased with the French music. German beer sales increased with the German music. When people were asked how they made their purchases they responded with perfectly rational comments such as A friend recommended it to me or I wanted to try a new premium beer. 

Be aware that people operate because of their feelings like an Elephant and a Rider. The Elephant is much bigger than the Rider and makes most of the decisions. 

 #newjersey #networking #gatewaychamberofcommerce #salesgrowth
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
Meet Michael Lebovitz from Romark Logistics. Michael was gracious enough to let me take a tour of his warehouse in preparation for our upcoming Gateway Warehouse association meeting on December 4th. 

Romark Logistics slogan is Personalized Service...ALWAYS, and Michael is for sure the right man for this job. He knew every single employees name, their familys name, and what they are working on personally outside of work. To see this level of acute awareness from top management is not only rare, but its also difficult to keep up with. Romark is obviously a leader in the industry because of their care for their workforce, customers, and buildings. Everything is stacked perfectly. Everyone working safely and efficiently. Their warehouse is run like a dream. 

Check out the video to learn more about him and his company. You can also meet him at our meeting next Wednesday. Just ask for more details. Ill see you there.
title: Founder Growth Engine X | Clay Enterprise Partner

content:
To give this article perspective, during the 2016 primary, Google search for Hilary Clinton would follow with suggestions for Hilary Clinton "book" "age" "net worth." Bing, who's algorithm is much closer to overall search queries, would suggest Hilary Clinton "net worth" "emails" "scandal." 

I just checked, even today nothing about the Hilary Clinton email scandal is suggested on Google but it is still suggested on bing. All of my claims here can be backed up by using Google Trends to compare the search queries.

content:

content:
I recently watched The Tetris Movie, and I just wanted to share some sales key takeaways I got from the film. 

1. Vision and Persistence: Henk Rogers was instrumental in securing the rights to distribute Tetris, a game developed in the Soviet Union, internationally. His vision to bring Tetris to a global audience showcases the importance of having a clear vision and the persistence to pursue it, even in the face of rejections and setbacks. 

2. Negotiation Skills: In order to secure the rights to Tetris, Henk Rogers likely had to negotiate with various parties involved. He understood the other party's motivations, finding mutually beneficial solutions, and maintaining strong relationships.

3. Identifying Market Opportunities: Henk Rogers recognized the potential of Tetris and its appeal to a wide audience. This demonstrates the importance of identifying market opportunities and understanding the unique value preposition of your product or service. By recognizing untapped markets or trends, you can position your offerings for success.

4. Building Relationships: Henk really wanted to make things right between him and Pajitnov, firstly because he had a lot of admiration for his work. Alexey Pajitnov and Henk Rogers shared the same vison and thus build a friendship and business partnership. He developed rapport and trust to secure partnership or distribution rights to bring Tetris to various platforms and markets.

5. Resilience: Henk was resilient, and he knew that he couldn't leave the country unless and until he made the deal. Henk faced a lot of challenges. and threats but he handled the situation with a lot of grace finally getting the rights.

Some say the story may be a little too dramatized, but overall Tetris is a fun ride movie, and it's a brilliant retelling of the events. 

#sales #movies #entertainment

content:
Supply Chain Challenges for SMEs and Startup E-Commerce brands:

1. Data Quality - Data like master data, stock levels in actual inventory, and open orders are the backbone of supply chain management. 

Supply chain data availability, data age, and data quality are major symptoms among SMEs. If the data is missing, out of date, or of low quality, the resulting plans will be ineffective. 

2. Inventory Management - Small businesses face a wide range of inventory management issues. Customer expectations are changing all the time, demand is fluctuating, ecommerce is increasing competition, and regulatory compliance is more complicated than ever. It is critical for SMEs to have the proper inventory in place at the right time in order to survive and expand. 

3. System Automation: SMEs usually have limited IT resources, making it difficult to obtain the levels of information necessary for a competitive supply chain. 

Due to significant investments in traditional supply chain systems, most businesses struggle to get complete visibility, many small businesses are operating an inefficient patchwork of disconnected systems and apps. 

4. Shipping Partner Relationship Management: This may be complicated, with possible disputes over problems such as on-time invoicing and payments, late shipments, shipment quality, and so on. 

#supplychainmanagement When compared to bigger organizations, small businesses have minimal control over their shipping partner making it difficult for them to negotiate successfully. When the shipping partner does not have a tracking system in place for their invoices, the issue gets more problematic.

The solution? Locad =â‚¬

Locad is the logistics engine enabling your e-commerce brand to automatically store, pack, ship, & track orders across Asia-Pacific.

Simply sync your inventory and sales channels to our tech platform and access our network of warehouses and shipping partners to experience faster shipping, reduced costs, and exponential growth for your business.

content:
Your product is new, and buyers are confused with it.

This is an issue that practically every startup faces: how can you convince potential clients that your product is the best one for them? 

They don't trust startups and don't care about your company expertise, so why would they purchase your solution?

Furthermore, if it's new, as most solutions are, they'll probably avoid it since they believe you're simply trying to sell them something they don't actually need.

Before you begin any sales attempts, be sure you have the answer to the question "What's in it for them?" 

This is the foundation of every global sales campaign for any product. People purchase the benefit rather than the product.

Then, if you're not confident they'll grasp your explanation, try explaining it in such a way that someone with no expertise of your sector can understand it.

Next, describe your competitive advantage - why they should purchase from you and why your solution is superior to their prior one.

Make the product as simple to use as possible, and provide a trial version to let your prospects understand what they're getting into.

Compatibility with their current systems and databases would also be beneficial. Remember to include this in your value propositions as well.

If this sounds daunting right now, and your team would like to focus on your product first. 

Pointer can help youÂ develop a robust GTM strategyÂ or work with you toÂ find your Product Market Fit.  =H

#startupgrowth #startupstrategies #startupstories

It took me six years to finish my bachelor's degree in industrial engineering.

Moreover, I abandoned my plans to pursue a career in industrial engineering entirely.

For six years, I am gladÂ to have acquired lifeÂ skills than theÂ technical skills I have learned.

Throughout college, I had numerous tests, quizzes, research projects, and deadlines to meet.

During those times, I struggled with self-doubt, was constantly stressed, was always striving to prove myself, and dealt with team disputes.

Years passed by. Despite all of my efforts, I have no regrets in choosing a different path.

I'd finally figured out what I wanted to do, and I'm so glad I did.

content:
I've been using LinkedIn lately, and I just realized I'm not yet good with conversations. 




I'm glad, I have seen Celeste Headlee's TED Talk abour 10 ways to have a better conversation. 

1. Don't multitask
2. Don't pontificate
3. Use open-ended questions
4. Go with the flow
5. If you don't know, say you don't know
6. Don't equate your experience with their experience
7. Don't repeat yourself
8. Stay out of the weeds
9. Listen
10. Be brief

"A good conversation is like a miniskirt, short enough to retain interest but long enough to cover the subject"
-Celeste's sister 

#selfdevelopment #selfimprovement #conversations #tedtalks

content:
Why are people still buying this? Stop. Now. 


Salesloft and Outreach are still the top dogs in the sequencer game. This makes no sense. 

Why? 

1. Horrible buying process. 
Had to go through an SDR and 2 AE calls + 1 SE call to get a 24h trial. For ACV of 1.2k. 

In what world does this make any economic sense?!

Who wants to buy these things after jumping through that many hoops? 

2. Inferior product
Simple emailing basics are just not there. 

- Multiple Inboxes per User? 
- Matching the MX records of the recipient? 
- Email Warmup? 

These tools are built by people who never sent an outbound email. 

And sold to people (managers) who also have not sent an outbound email in a decade

It's the blind leading the blind. 

This is also what keeps them in business. 
They sell to managers who only care about fancy analytics. 

Yes, you can very accurately see that your emails are not performing. Kudos =O  

And then people claim email is dead. 
It's not dead.

The big SEP will be, however. 


Meanwhile: 

For every 100 people we reach out to
we book 10+ meetings. 

With 5Â min of setup work per campaign. 

BDR Teams are just lost.

content:
The role of marketing is not what you think it is. 

Christian Krause had a great post about how buyers are ever more informed before they ever talk to a sales reps. 

70% (or whatever the number exactly is) 
of the buyer journey has already happened. 

This is no news. 

Marketing thought they found the answer

- More blogs
- More whitepapers
- More webinars. 

It worked. 
For some time. 

But when was the last time you got excited about an ad for a whitepaper? 

It's true. 
The answer to more educated buyers is marketing

But not corporate social media posts, white papers 

- I follow you Christian Krause and not Salesforce (when he was still there)
- I follow >Â¾Eric Nowoslawski, not Clay
- follow Lucas Perret , not lemlist. 

Trust is not created through ebooks. 

It's built by connections with people. 

That have a face and voice
share a unique perspective
and are approachable. 

BDRs are the new marketers. 

Marketing needs to enable that.

Peakora dug deeper and analysed over 100 Startups. Turns out the vast majority does not invest in a correct HubSpot Setup. 

They just wing it. 

No wonder only 1/3 of all Startups manage to transition from founder-led sales to a proper Sales org.

Operational issues:

- Failing to automate
- Lack of data quality
- Inaccurate and false reports. 

If you want to scale. 
You know that's crucial. 

So don't be one of them that fails.

content:
3 Outbound Myths you need to stop believing. 

1. One tool can fix everythingÂ 
2. Sales is just a numbers game
3. Personalization is key


=4 Myth - 1 

One tool can't fix everything 

Why?

The question I get asked the most: 

Lanny, what tool should I use for outbound?

Honestly, It does not matter.

Michael Jordan was the greatest basketball player
Baseball? Not so much. 

It's not the tool
It's the player. 

Yes, you need tools
But you need to know how to use them. 

That's where most people fail. 

=4 Myth -2 

Sales is just a numbers game. 

I know companies that send 10x the emails that I do. 
And I book more meetings

Reached out to 83 people
Had meetings with 11

That's a 13.25% booking rate.  
6 turned into opportunities. 

It took me not even 3 hours of work to set it up. 

It's all automated now. 

I can re-run this campaign now. 
With 5min of work. 

Quality > quantity. 

If you efficiently create crap
You just end up with a huge pile of it very quickly. 

Good job =O 


=4 Myth - 3

You need to personalize your outreach. 

No you don't. 

People who never booked a sales email in their life tell you that. 

They are lost. 

You have to be relevant. 
Not talk about how you went to the same high school

Or that you stalked them
And think their dog is cute. 

Relevance > Personalization. 

Answer 3 questions

- Why you.
- Why me. 
- Why now. 


What other myth needs to be busted? =G
title: Using AI to create a Full Sales Pipeline without big BDR teams( Clay Enterprise Partner | Founder @ Enablement.ch

content:
3 Reasons Why AI in SaaS Outbound is Booming and How to Get in on the Action 

=4  Reason 1

Outbound is the most cost-effective marketing channel. 

Clients of mine run campaigns with a click-through-rate of 12.5%

Show how to do this with LinkedIn, Facebook or Google Ads. 

=4  Reason 2

Full control. 

Tracking your ads gets more complicated every day. 
You are at the mercy of Google and Meta, LinkedIn and Apple. 

With outbound all you need is an email address and your creativity. 

=4  Reason 3

Low startup cost. 

Ads cost you a lot of money upfront. 
You don't know if they will work. 

To get 10'000 impressions you pay around $350

Getting 10'000 impressions with emails costs you only around $83.

And I rather send someone an email
than just show up on their timeline. 

And we're not even accounting for the time & effort
you have to put in into creating the ads. 

Want to get started?
Here are 3 steps 

Step 1: Your Message
Fine-tune your positioning and messaging. Clearly communicate how you benefit people. 

Keep it simple. 
Make it tangible. 

Step 2: Targeting
Identify the right people, reach out at the right time and with the right message. 

Step 3: Testing

Getting it right will require some testing

- Start with a clear idea of what should work
- Test that Idea 
- Measure it
- Optimize.

What's your take on this? =G

content:
3 Mistakes You should Avoid While Using AI for your Outbound

1. Failing to Automate the Outbound Process.
2. Neglecting Email Delivery & Technical setupÂ 
3. Hiring more SDRs without a solid setup.

=4 Mistake 1 

Shiny object syndrome: 

You believe that a single tool will solve all problems, 

Reality is: 

it's about how you combine the tools
into an effective engine.

You can give me the best football shoes
and the perfect ball.

I will never be Ronaldo (or Messi) 

It's not the tool
It's how you use it. 

=4 Mistake 2 

Failure to pay attention to technical details of email setup.

Specifically 

i) DNS settings: DKIM, SPF, and DMARC.
ii) Not taking care of email deliverability.
iii) Not rotating your inboxes

=4 Mistake 3 

1. Hiring more SDRs without a good setup.
2. Believing that more SDRs will lead to more meetings.

Invest in a solid outbound setup 
and don't hire more Reps

Get more done
with less. 

What else would you add? =G

Hot Take:- AI won't impact the BDR jobs

It will affect the Sales Manager Jobs.Â  

The BDRs will still have to 

 Cold call their leads.
 Spend time in conversations.
Â  Qualify leads and schedule next steps

However, figuring out things like:-

1. What tactics should we implement?
2. How can we improve our playbook?
3. How do we move upmarket?

Are all Sales Managers Jobs,

Now with GPT-4, you can upload documents to it.
Then ask ChatGPT to interpret the data. 

So now it's way easier to understand data.
Then make decisions based on it 

So as a sales manager, you need to 

1. See what's working and what notÂ 
2. See if the massaging is in place.
3. Formulate new strategies.Â 
4. Leverage AI better.
Â 
Sales Managers who are leveraging AI will have way more advantage over the others who aren't using AI 

And the BDR Jobs? They more or less stay the same 

Discuss =G

content:
Why your meetings don't convert into money in the bank

When I did my first outbound campaigns we made a crucial mistake

We optimized our campaigns to get call bookingsÂ 
And sometimes ended up in calls with people that 

 Had completely wrong expectations.
 Weren't in the right mindset to buy.
 We're not the decision maker.Â 
Â 
As a result, 99% of them came with the show me what you got mindset to the call

Things changed when we made a crucial adjustment. 

If you want to close a deal, your prospect 

1. Needs to admit that they have a problemÂ 
2. Needs to be open for help
Â 
Now, the question is how to find such prospects?.

Here are my 2 tips 

1. Validate the pain in your outreach.Â 
2. Set the expectations in the beginning of the call. 

Also, few things to keep in mind when trying to pre-qualify 

You need to see if you can help them or notÂ 
Ask yourself 

 Do they have an urgency for a solution?
 Do they have the budget?
 Do they have authority?
 Is it timely?

Then finalize that with a 30-second call to the prospect to confirm everything, before finally moving to the discovery call 

This way you can rapidly increase the chance of closing the deals 

How often do you pre-qualify your leads?

content:
4 sales lessons I learned after working for 7 years in the B2B world

1. Structure Testing Approach 

Have a scientific approach to doing things.
If you are:- 

 Running ads
 Running an outbound campaign.

Always formulate hypotheses
Experiment & test
Analyse and implement the learnings

This way you will get better. 
Continuously. 

2. If you can't do it yourself, you can't outsource it 

Hiring an agency is good but 
If you don't have 

 Some success doing it yourself
 A clear idea of what good looks like

Your agency will run circles around you.

You cannot judge their work
And cant give them feedback

You set them up to fail you. 
And its your fault. 

Master it yourself first
Outsource later. 

If you dont know how
Get someone to teach you.  

3. Be the best at something - instead of OK at everything 

I wont help you with
Creating your ads, if I actually could
I will not run outbound campaigns for you.
Drive your social media. 

Ive done all that successfully
But I dont do it. 

I focus on one thing. 

Enable you to build your own outbound engine. 
Using AI & automation. 

And reducing manual work
While getting better results. 

4. Embrace tech even if it is very alien and foreign to you
     
  I still don't know how to code.    
  I can barely read HTML

Yet I can easily

 Configure APIs
 Send webhooks between tools
 Configure low-code automation.

I just learned it all, and you can too  

What's next?

Follow me
Tap the bell icon =
I post about sales, AI & Automation for B2B SaaS companies daily.

The problems with most campaigns are

-- Not having the right tools in place

content:
How I used my Sales skills on Tinder =%

Before I met my beloved fiancÃ© I did an experiment. Could I beat the Tinder odds?

The male-to-female ratio on Tinder is 5:1. That means 80% are guys.

And only the top 1% actually get dates from the platform.

Because most of them are just set up to fail.Â Bad pictures, lame messaging.

What I did instead

I started with some market research
- Created a girl profile to analyse my competition
- Reviewed what makes good profiles stand out
- Got inspiration for my copywriting & conversation scripts

The craziest insight was that a good-looking girl gets over 4k likes in 3 hours. I had no chance to read all messages.

Only the ones that stood out.

I then created my profile accordingly
- Funny joke in the BioÂ 
- High-quality picture of me doing a fun activity
- Conversation script to set a date
- A/B tested the opener messages & script
- Kept track in Excel & optimised

Ive increased my booking rate to almost 50%.

Generated a lot of pipeline but I did not find my love there.

Moral of the story: If you want to get the big deals go out and meet people in person.

I met my future wife in a bar in Zurich.

Where else can you use your sales skills in your day-to-day life? =G




#marketing #sales #hubspot #crm #outbound #Love #Tinder
title: Using AI to create a Full Sales Pipeline without big BDR teams( Clay Enterprise Partner | Founder @ Enablement.ch

content:
Most salespeople don't know how to use ChatGPT. Properly.

Here's why:

How most salespeople and leaders use ChatGPT
- Write a sales email to promote my product to B2B companies
- Write a personalized icebreaker for this contactÂ 
- Summarise my meeting based on this transcript
- How should you structure my outbound process?

How the best sellers use ChatGPT
- Integrated via API into Google Sheets
- Use multiple cells as reference
- Segment companies
- Personalize outreach
- Enrich data
- Ask ChatGPT to rate their prompt from 1-10. Then improve
- Give examples of what good looks like.

content:
Can you imagine cold-calling people that just lost their life savings  and try to sell them credit cards? 

Almost 15 years ago I started my first job at UBS  right after the bank had to be rescued by the Swiss Government. The irony, I know&

You can imagine how happy customers were. And yet we were cold calling them on Tuesday evenings after hours to sell them credit cards. 

Sounds fun right? Or how about when you had your best weekend sales ever as a startup only to have all the revenue stolen by your accountant? 

Or how about joining a new company that just had its biggest loss ever and no VC or Government to fill in the hole? 

All true stories of my work life experience. 

A lot to be learned from these days. About sales, about customer service and how to succeed in a difficult environment. 

Join in for my session at the START Summit in St. Gallen in collaboration with HubSpot. "Lessons from the last recession and how to prepare for the next one. What B2B Companies can do now"

Looking forward to coming home to my alma mater and seeing so many familiar faces!

Thanks for the invitation HubSpot Fabian Hartmann START Global

content:
Companies waste $25'000 per employee due to meetings


We've all been there "This meeting could have been an email..."

So how do you avoid having unproductive meetings with too many people. 

Here's what I do: 

1. Clear agenda: What do we need to achieve in the next 30min? Always answer that question first. 

2. If you set the meeting you're responsible for that 1 is achieved. 

3. If you don't contribute to that goal, leave. It's fine. 

4. Let people hop on and off based on actual need. 

5. Record all meetings. Have chatGPT summarize the transcriptions. 

6. People to be informed only need to know the decision, not how you got there. Send them the summary via email/slack instead.  

7. The more people in a meeting, the less useful it actually is that everyone is there. Do shorter 1:1s instead. 


What else can you do to make it meetings more useful? 


#marketing #sales #hubspot #crm #outbound

content:
My favourite interview questions


5 years ago my former boss Ben Klein interviewed me for a Job as a consultant at BEE. 

As the last question he asked me the best interview question. I'm still using it to this day. 

"Why should I NOT hire you?"

I gave it some thought. "What is a good reason not to hire me?" 

The answer was very clear for me: "I'm a character guy. I will challenge you. If you don't like that - then I'm the wrong guy."

I knew what I'm like, what I wanted out of this role. 

If you don't know what you want - you have to take what you get. 

It's kinda the same in Sales. If you don't know your ICP, what problems you can solve - and which ones not. You are lost. 

And so will be your deals. 
Not won. 
Lost. 


Do you know why someone should NOT hire you or your product?

content:
Outbound is dead. Stop reaching out to people! 
 
People will tell you:  
 
1. Give value first 
 
2. 70% of the buyer's journey is already done before they talk to a vendor.  
 
3. People will come to you when they are ready. 
 
That's all correct and fine. BUT 
 
Yet still, 30% of our 7-figure new-sales revenue comes from ice-cold outbound with meeting booking rates of up to 8.5%  
 
So why do people keep saying that outbound is dead when it's clearly alive. 
 
and it will keep business alive in the coming year during a recession. 
 
I think people mean that outbound like in the old days is dead. 
 
You cannot just go on sales nav and target 10k leads at the same time. With a generic message. And then expect 3% to jump on a call with you.  
 
Do these 4 things instead. Your outbound will be unstoppable =G 
 
1. A very clear understanding of your target accounts & persona. What exactly are their pain points? 
 
2. Use clear triggers & intend data to identify them when they need you. 
 
3. reaching out with clear, short and straightforward messaging. 
 
4. Have the tools in place to do all this at scale without getting blocked, Spam-flagged or ignored. 
 
 
I've created a little self-assessement that tells you if you're reaching your max potential.  
 
How much revenue are you missing out on because you are not hitting the benchmarks?

content:
"Bitcoin is on the road to irrelevance"Â - ECB 2022

That's what the ECB just said in their latest blogpost (see comments for the link). Multiple claims are just plain wrong. Let's see: 

=Â¸ Transfer of money
"Real Bitcoin transactions are cumbersome, slow and expensive." 

BTC can be sent around the globe instantly and basically for free. 

Have you ever wired fiat money to your relatives in another country? Or a business transaction?Â Took longer and was more expensive. 

Also, not a single mention of the lightning network?

=Ã‰ Ponzi Scheme
"Bitcoin investors have the strongest incentives to keep the euphoria going"

Interesting statement coming from an institution that has the strongest incentive to keep the FIAT system going. 

= Energy consumption
"The Bitcoin system is an unprecedented polluter."

The opposite is true. BTC allows for the monetization of before unused energy sources. 

BTC mining cannot compete economically with the electricity sources used to power a city. 

This energy would just be left bare otherwise. It literally makes us more efficient with the resources we have. 

=L Social Impact
"Bitcoin provides no social benefits"

Tell that again to the Lebanese refugees who were able to keep their wealth and escape impoverishing capital controls. 

BTC allows for the censorship-free transfer and store of wealth. 

It allows incredibly easy access to the financial system for the 1.4 Billion unbanked people in the world. 

This is no social benefit? 

=@ Summary
"Bitcoin is on the road to irrelevance". I guess the ECB has evidently a very biased view.

The public deserves to know better.Â  

Personally, I'm looking forward to having this quote hung up on my wall in a large, beautiful typeface in 2,3 years time. 

When the EUR is further inflated and worth less and BTC hits new all-time highs. 

What are your thoughts on this?


#BTC #Bitcoin #crypto

content:
I started a new job as a lumberjack. >â€œ  
 
Imagine the following: The salary is okay, the working conditions tempting, so you want to make a good impression. 
 
On the first day, you report to the foreman, who gave you an axe and assigned you to a specific area in the forest. 
 
Enthusiastically, you set to work. 
In a single day you felled eighteen trees. 
"Congratulations," says the foreman. "Keep it up." 
 
Prompted by the foreman's words, you decide to surpass the result of your work the next day. So you go to bed early that night. 
 
The next morning you get up before everyone else and go into the forest. 
 
But despite all your efforts, efforts do not manage to fell more than fifteen trees. 
 
'I must be tired,' you think and decide to go to sleep just after sunset that day. 
 
You wake up at dawn with a firm resolve to surpass your mark of eighteen trees today. You do not even make it halfway. 
 
The next day it's only seven trees, the day after that five and on the last day you spend almost all of it cutting down a second tree. 
 
Worried about what the foreman would say, you go to him, tell him what happened and swear that you worked until he dropped. 
 
The foreman asks "When was the last time you sharpened your axe?" 
 
"Sharpen the axe? I didn't have time, I was too busy cutting down trees." 
 
As Stephen Covey said, never forget to "Sharpen the saw".  
 
The story reminds me of a lot of sales people. You just do MORE. More calls, more messages, more LinkedIn.  
 
But you never look at how you can become more effective, what tools do I need? 
 
Sometimes less is more.  
 
#salesetech #revops #worksmart #sales

L Incomplete Setups 
L Sold the wrong licence

L simple rookie mistakes. 
 
Example? The CEO of a 5Ã›55Ã¯5Ã¦5Ã½5Ã¼5 5Ã—5Ã¶5Ã®5Ãº5Ã¼5Ã»5Ã± 5Ã£5Ã®5Ã¿55Ã»5Ã²5Ã¿ (=they should know better) created the following property. (see image)  
 
"Number of Employees" as a company property. Single-line Text.  
 
"What's wrong with that?" you ask.  
 
5Ã­. The property already exists as a default one created by HubSpot (=redundant)  
 
5Ã®. The default Property by HubSpot is filled out automatically by HubSpot's Insight Database. --> You don't need to enter the values manually 
 
5Ã¯. The property was created as a free text field. The number of employees can only be a numeric field. Duh.  
 
5Ã°. This newly created property is not used anywhere. Not in forms, list, workflows. Why bother creating it then? 
 
The list could go on and on. I'm not just shocked, I'm angry.  
 
People literally get ripped off by some "HubSpot Experts" out there. It's just not fair to those companies.

content:
Based on recent conversations this needs some repetition. louder for the ones in the back... 
 
L Revenue Operations is not *just* sales operations with a different name. 
 
L Revenue Operations isn't *just* someone who sets up Salesforce or HubSpot for your sales/marketing/cs teams. 
 
L Revenue Operations is not *just* a tactical function. 
 
 Revenue Operations IS tactical AND strategic. (By nature of being operations, there will always be a level of tactical especially if you are a player-coach or a team of 1) 
 
 Revenue Operations IS: process AND systems AND reporting AND enablement that support ALL of the GTM teams, end-to-end. 
 
 Revenue operations IS inclusive of marketing operations AND customer success operations.  
 
I will close with this: 
 
Specialization (salesops, MOPs, etc) is important and certainly shouldn't go away. However, if you are looking to establish a REVENUE operations function you should be aware what you are looking for is a generalist/generalist types and as your company becomes larger you can add in the specialized roles.  
 
If you need to hire a sales ops person, don't just slap a revops title on the JD and call it a day.

content:
Image if you had 4 brains instead of 1. One for each arm and leg. How coordinated would you walk? 

My last post on shitty CRM data got quite some comments and one question popped up. Why?

Why does the average company have a data quality score of 4%? 

My humble 0.02 =Â¸

1Ã£ Most mistakes already happen at the very beginning when the records are created. 

Either through manual imports or ad-hoc records being created without clear standards for what a contact, company, deal should look like

2Ã£ Records not being updated/false information. This is mainly because someone designed a process on a miro board. 

Everybody thought it makes sense and agreed to follow that process. And then reality hit.

People are too busy to follow the process and cut corners. It all looked nice in theory but didn't work in practice. 

3Ã£ Messy data architecture. Marketing, Sales, CSM all working on a different tool stack. 

Even properly integrated it's a huge challenge to get all data accurate. It's just fragile. 

4Ã£  Related to the second point.The end user has no added benefit for entering the data. They don't see why it matters to them. 

Thus, they don't do it manually. If you met any sales rep, you know one thing for sure: We don't like to do manual work. 

Therefore, setting up systems & processes in a way that your reps have to do stuff manually, will not work. They won't follow you processes. 

Tks to Bernd Kuhnle for the questions & inputs on 4.)

While GDPR etc. is one aspect of data privacy we don't talk a lot about privacy in regard to our relationship with the state.

content:
When was the last time you needed motivation to brush your teeth? 




The first month of the year almost over and so are your resilience and discipline to stick to your motivations. 

I know I'm right. Despite the proclaimed (and overused) "new normal" - some things never change... But are you really to blame? Motivation vanishes over time and everyday life sets in. To me, motivation is a luxury I cannot afford to rely on. 

If I'd only allow myself to do my sales calls or go to the gym when I'm motivated to then I'd never get off that next episode of the queen's gambit. 

What works is seeing yourself progressing towards a goal. It puts the large objective within reach and breaks it down into small tasks, small habits. 

They become routines and your everyday life. You just do them. Just like brushing your teeth. 

So to track your progress towards your goals I've further improved my OKR template over the last year and included a daily success tracker that helps you visualize, contemplate and record your daily achievements. 

So, if you're off track right now or want to make sure you stay on it, just comment "tracker" below and I send it over to you.

Without these 7 Tools, your productivity will suffer during home office



Pretty much everybody is home now and some or more productive than ever...while some slag behind. Here are 7 tools that are essential to skyrocket your productivity

For communication:

1. ) loom: Screenrecording for briefings
2. ) Slack: replace emails with instant messaging
3.) Zoom: Only way to have proper meetings now. I had a 6h Workshop and it went as smooth as an in person meeting

Organization:
4. harvestapp: What gets measured gets done: Track you time so you know where you spend it. I review my day each evening. 

5. Asana: manage complex projects across functions, teams and even companies.

6. a dedicated workplace. Separating professionals from private life is crucial as the lines get more and more blurred. Also: Keep it clean to avoid distractions. 

7. Pen + Notebook: Write down the 3-5 things that NEED to get done today. 

All hell may break loose, but they get ticked off that day. Having them physically written down in front of you helps to always focus your mind back to what matters most.

content:
We all know it and yet we still do it anyway >&
B


Don't be that person. I know 100% of the people here on LinkedIn can relate to this. A friendly, unsuspicious connection request. Sure, let's connect. But then you realize it's a trojan horse, a devil in disguise.

After the connection here it comes; the immediate pitch:

"Hey Lanny, I have this amazing thing for you. It can do X and Y & Z....and did I tell you its awesome and it can even cure cancer! Its so awesome. Buy it. Buy it NOW! When are you free to call? Next Tuesday ok? An invite is already sent, looking forward to it! Best regards, Tom"

You're probably smiling now. Because you know it's true.

Honestly, I don't have an issue with people reaching out related to business stuff, that's what we're here for.

But please, take me on a date before we hook up. 

Establish that I even have the problem your awesome product tries to solve.

I don't need the cure for cancer if my arm's broken. As awesome as killing cancer is, I don't need it. So don't sell it to me.

Trust me, you will sell more this way. And annoy the rest of us less. Thanks

What's your approach to reach out to people on here?



#sales #socialselling #linkedin

What do you think guys?

content:
Why I get up at 6am every morningÃ°



 
 
 
I'll never forget watching Kobe's last game. 3 Minutes to and the Lakers are down by 10pts. Kobe losing his very last game? Never! Not on his watch. What happened next?

 
Exhausted, barely able to walk but. He used his secret weapon. By the sheer force of will, he turned that game around and dropped 60 pts! The Mamba Mentality.

 
Playing Basketball as a kid I idolized him. There were many great players but he was the one for one specific reason.

 
His hyper-competitiveness. This guy did not step on the court to win. He went out there to crush his opponents.

 
Hearing stories about him showing up at 4 am on game day to be there before anyone else to practice and staying 2h after the game as well was just >/>/.

 
My Dad always told me: "Lanny, you can have everything you want - IF you are willing to put in the work!" And there was a guy who REALLY put in the work.

 
Every time I feel too tired to get up in the morning I think "Is this your #mambamentality? Do you really want to achieve your goals?" Get's me going like Â¡

 
This is always my Mamba moment =
 It's the one that separates victory from failure 

We all have a #mamba moment. What's yours?

content:
What are 3 things you want to be in 2029? 

A decade ago I wasn't a lot of things. And a lot of things I hadn't experienced. 

- Not finished my apprenticeship in Banking at UBS
- Hadn't finished my degree University of St.Gallen
- Didn't live in another country
- Hadn't started my own event management firm and failed after 1 year
- Didn't have a breakdown because I hated what I was doing
- Didn't know where I was going 
- Didn't realize that time is the most precious thing

And where am I today, 31.12.2019? A bit older, a bit wiser and yet still there are more things that I haven't done yet.

In some sense, we are our past and our present but in a weird sense we are also our future, we are what we are not yet to speak in existential terms. So I wonder what my list in 2029 will look like? There are 3 things i certainly want to be: 

1.) healthy
2.) happy
3.) Impactful 

The first 2 are obvious i guess. What about 3? Just vanity? No, not at all. But being impactful is the side effect of being of value to a lot of people. What better is there to be? 

What are 3 things you want to be in 2029?

content:
"How can you compare LinkedIn and Instagram? They are so different?" - this was a common critique I received to my recent posts. So why is comparable? 

Both posts went trending and reached over 30'000 people I guess I struck a nerve. However, the inputs are more than valid. I actually agree that they are not the same...yet. What people don't see, in the future..literally. 

Chaital Shah pointed it out perfectly as well. I'm a typical millennial and how old was I when Facebook took off in 2010 (the year FB grew the fastest)? mere 17 years old. Did I care about my career? Not really. How about Instagram; how old was I when it took off in 2014? 21 years old. Interested in business relationships? Not that much, I just started uni and exams and parties were the top priority. 

Now in 2019, I'm 26 years old and business relationships became of key importance for me. I want to share learn from others, stay in contact with contacts from other countries and share knowledge to and have a lasting impact together. All of a sudden LinkedIn became interesting to millennials. The first generation that grew up on social media is hitting LinkedIn, a generation that understands the true power of the network and how to build a brand on it.  

#facebook #linkedin #personalbranding #instagram
title: Using AI to create a Full Sales Pipeline without big BDR teams( Clay Enterprise Partner | Founder @ Enablement.ch

content:
Instagram is dying...and why your post on LinkedIn get's 3,5x more views. Even if IG has over 3x the users. 

 
My last post got crazy attention (15k+ views) and even ended up being trending on LinkedIn. Let's continue the series. 

 
The # 1 reason is what I call a social networks maturity. the early stage a new network new users come to the platform and create impressions (they look at content). And users actively create posts (content that can create impressions).  To answer the question "how many people do see my post?" we have to take the ratio of post vs impressions. Basically: how big is the competition for attention? 

 
Because not all people post content that ratio is positive and organic growth is easily possible. That's obviously very attractive for advertisers and big brands. So they join the platform with big $$. Thus, the amount of posted content starts to outgrow the growth of the number of impressions. Therefore, competition increases, organic views get viewer & viewer. Thus, users increase their posting, reinforcing the spiral. Furthermore, the network depends on ad revenue = organic reach is not in the network's interest.

 
This is what happened to Facebook in 2011/12 and is happening now to IG...see the statistics:


 
#instagram #linkedin #trends2020 #growth

content:
Instagram is dying, this is why...

Jup, I just said it Instagram (IG), the world's 2nd biggest network is dying. But Lanny, it has over 1 billion monthly active users, engagement is 10x higher than on Facebook and IG generates $9 bil. in ad revenue?!

Thats all true & I totally agree. IG is still active and alive...yet. But IG is EXACTLY where Facebook was in 2012. What does that mean? Well look at your latest Facebook post how many likes or views did you get? Wow, 1 or 2? Same here. This is what IG is going to look like in 18-24 months. The indicators are clear & there are 3 major reasons:

1.) Maturity & User activity of the network
2.) User Demographics
3.) Monetization

This is based on a quantitative analysis I did. I will go through each of these separately and share them with you next week. For now, let me just show you something very interesting. Here on LinkedIn, I have 600 followers on Instagram I have 10132 followers (pls dont call me an influencer tho). I looked at the stats of my latest posts on LI and IG. Guess where I got more views? content:
How to sell without being annoying? 
In my recent workshop w/ Asendia & Swiss Post for BEE INBOUND AG I talked about exactly that and I wanna share some insights.

1. People want to BUY. Nobody wants to be SOLD. Especially here on LinkedIn. 

Does that sound familiar: "Hey Lanny, we are the most awesome developer team, buy my stuff! I know you need it!" - Me: *cringe* "....ehm, nope" 

2. We forget the most important part of social selling...SOCIAL comes first, SELLING is just an afterthought. 

I get it, connecting with people is tricky. What do I write on my profile? How do I find the right people? What do I even write to them without being salesy?

To answer these questions I've created a Social Selling Guide that provides you with:
- 9 point checklist for the perfect LinkedIn profile 
- 3 proven ways to find your right prospects 
- 4 Step process to successfully connect with them
And a lot of examples directly from our clients and us

I thought I'd share it here. So just drop a comment below SEND GUIDE and I ship it over :)


Special thanks to Patrick Wolf Patrick Schlup Michael MÃ¤kelÃ¤inen Fabio Gianfreda Fabian Baumberger Claudia Patocchi Philipp Hug. Annett LÃ¼pke Looking forward to our Bootcamp

content:
What happens when your branding is just a fad or how to LOSE $8 BILLION? A real-life case study.  

Telling 50% of the population - and basically their customer base - that their moral behaviour is deemed reprehensible and that they are basically all the same misogynistic sexual harassers obviously didn't go too well for Gillette. 

The intent was to capitalize on the social media trend surrounding social justice by jumping on the bandwagon  I guess nobody can disagree with the aims of equality of opportunity and that is not the point I'm making here 

The problem only was that pretty much everybody could see it for it was: A pure charade. And so the customers voted with their pockets. In August Gillette's mother company P&G announced an $8 BILLION devaluation.

CEO Gary Coombe, however, stated that the campaign was "a price worth paying" doubling down on the hypocrisy. Now you might ask: "why am saying that and why in such a rather plain language? " Well, basically their new campaign is proof: It focuses on a hypermasculine firefighter (Is there a more traditionally male stereotype?). 

I've linked the article in the comment section and created a video on how to do branding authentically (see Nike's campaign). Comment "SEND" if you want it.

#branding #marketing #socialmedia

content:
A state of psychological safety is requisite to performing our best; especially if longevity is a focus 

I use the analogy of confident enough to sprint at something regardless of the outcome.

The petrified-of-losing-their-job rep will slog forward like theyre dragging a sled loaded with 500 lbs

Theyll be less creative, with less output, and take away less understanding from their efforts than someone whos confident in their path

Outcomes are rarely certain - but we can know what we can know; and doing so at least gives a clear path forward 

One we can sprint at

That sprint means 10x output in 1/2 the time - it shortens feedback loops while performing them at higher levels of skill which means the information we get back is more representative of the truth ((rather than diluted by negative mindset and low quality actions)).

When you work for yourself you shed some common sales stressors like quota, the ability to be fired, and bosses who are not actual leaders

As a rep - this means youre probably better off in an environment where youre cared for even above one that is ripe for performance UNTIL youre adequately knowledgeable to not need support in your skillset

Founders & other leaders should be mindful of the environment they create - I see countless examples of leadership stifling results out of fear and scarcity.

And please for the love of God - dont let this be HRs job

Yes its a buzzword that may be overused - but millions of years of evolution & blood memory doesnt give a f*** what your attitude is towards it

Psychological safety is a requisite for sustained high level performance

content:
Last summer I hurt my back deadlifting for the first time ever

Truth is - I deserved the injury

I'd actually been on a strong run & was hitting my weekly numbers with ease.

Throughout the program I had built momentum that translated to less and less focus on warm ups as I felt ((accurately)) that I didn't need it to hit my lifts.

This selfish thinking mirrors a lot of what I see with sales reps ((myself included)) at times who rush through their workflows.

One day when I was finally going for a new PR, my laziness caught up to me and ended up costing me 2 months of time training.

In sales this is like when you get terrible results from an outbound campaign & look back realizing the campaign inputs weren't done with care.

A little up front focus, some effort in building a great list, investing in data validation... copy that is deeply contextual & "native" to your target market... 

That's the foundation to a solid campaign - and time spent doing the little things with excellence translates to results improvements similar to what I saw in the gym.

Once I was back to training I deloaded, focused intensely on warm ups & controlled range of motion... I built back to where I'd been and breezed through PRs due to addressing the areas I had been lazy previously

Quick fixes exist. Hacks have an allure to them.

Ignore them.

A slow, stable base provides a stable, consistent future.

In lifts, life and even outbound cold email...

((Tyson included because he's the GOAT))
title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
The "anti-brand" is a concept from YoungMe Moon's book "Different" that highlights companies like Supreme NYC or MINI & shares a fun lens to define a brand through.

At its core the concept is about contrast; of the stark, visceral variety.

For the uninitiated, Supreme NYC is a skate brand turned pseudo-fashion brand known for traits such as:

- Really expensive T shirts
- Difficult shopping experience due to competition w/ bots
- Nearly instantaneous sell outs

How?

They know their audience - and of you scoffed at the prior lines it isn't you.

MINI has done similar leaning into who they are; they're NOT normal & are offended at the concept of being compared to other car experiences

 In B2B you see a lot of mass-appeal branding. Just today I got an email that Reese Witherspoon is keynoting for a well known conference...

Wtf does that have to do with CRM?!?

Same goes for content - mass appeal hits for some but there is often an underserved audience who feels alienated by the mass-appeal stuff.

When I write cold emails I am ALWAYS asking myself NOT how I can resonate with the entirety of an audience, but rather how I can embody the attitude of a hyper-specific segment of it & what would resonate especially strongly with them?

We're metaphysically implanting emotional responses... so it makes sense that going outside "the norm" hits better than trying to be all too tuned into it...

In the same vein of Justin Michael's "B- copy works better than A+" I think that you want to be similarly "off" the default value prop ((in favor of a more interesting, creative one without fundamentally missing what your prospects care most about)) if you want any hope of striking a real conversation from the ice cold abyss....
title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
If you tried to grab your prospect by their shirt and pull them into you, theyd respond by pulling themselves away from you, right?

But if you were talking to them and started lowering your voice as you asked them a question, you very may well cause them to lean in to listen clearer

Visualize these scenarios as your prospect

Are you trying to drag your prospects into your world, or are you showing them you exist in theirs?

Your world consists of the way you see the market, what matters in your eyes, the things you think are compelling, etc&

Youre an expert - but not of what you think you are; solutions start with problems but youve already started with YOU

Instead, try to exist in their world

Their world starts with how the feel. Tired, exhausted, frustrated, confused& whatever it is. 

When you exist in your prospects world, their guard lowers.

They FEEL you as a peer, expert or at least savvy enough to be worth a convo.

If you can learn to label their attitudes well & ask questions more insightful and precise than other vendors - its not impossibly hard to cut through the noise in your market and build real relationships with people

ALWAYS be buyer focused

Dont try to drag people into your world

Prove you exist in theirs
title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
I really think sales team structures limit how earlier stage companies create happy customers

When you have a team of 4 Area Directors ((east, Midwest, south, west)) who own 100% of your total addressable market you naturally split it by territory 

The issue is each territory is a bunch of markets

So all 4 reps need competency in each market segment

I see this a lot where a startup doesnt even know exactly who they sell to yet and they have all these reps runnin around inventing that GTM motion

Grab a blank canvas

Start with the thing that really matters: your target market

Segment it

Create a strategy to approach each segment

Create segment centric reps who get the entire slice of TAM & let them farm it instead&

A lot of top of funnel activities for full cycle reps could be massively consolidated into a few key workflows

One example Im using with a client is we message their entire TAM with compelling copy, and lower the Call to action down to if I sent a loom video explaining more would you watch it?

We got nearly 200 people last month who said yes I would to that

So we send those people over to our client who has their reps film personalized videos to these prospects

Is this a worse approach?

content:
2 tools I've been using lately to do more, faster:

1) Texts. I love this app; it lets me put all of my inboxes in one place and gives me a way to filter by unread for inboxes like twitter that don't offer that filter natively.

I can clear 100+ texts, dozens of LinkedIn DMs, all my slack messages, WhatsApp, Telegram Messenger, and my Discord inbox all from one central UI.

It also let's you "Mark unread" for things easily if I want to come back to it later.

2) The Browser Company's Arc browser.

To start - yes you can use all your chrome plugins with it still...

But this browser lets you easily create "Workspaces" or clusters of tabs that you use together & switch between them effortlessly. Google workspaces sorta does this too, but I've always found the switching clunky & sometimes it signs me out of things based on the profile I log into.

It also blocks 100% of ads & device tracking.

I currently run 3 workspaces: one for casual use, one for my personal "admin", and one for my "job" running my agency.

Anyone got any cool tech they've been using?

content:
Data quality > sales automation technology

Phone Ready Leadsï¿½ & verified email inboxes vs parallel dialers & single domain sequencers&. 

If slow is smooth & smooth is fast, then it makes sense that verified data lets you experience 3 months worth of conversations in a week or so

Multiplying garbage outbound via 13 parallel lines & 12-step multi touch doesnt do you any hood when a lot of that amplification is to non-monitored phone lines and inboxes

Its a lot easier to buy tech than implement a data cleanliness practices - but the latter is how you equip your best reps to do the most

Why isnt data verification more popular with teams of sales reps spending large portions of their time ((overhead $$$)) doing outbound?

Especially since it lowers buy in and morale when youre emailing dead inboxes and calling numbers that dont respond&

content:
3 ways ai is helping my business set meetings with target buyers right now:

1. Using Clay to create personalized snippets to inject into cold outbound emails.

Usually I am starting with a companys web domain, enriching it with LinkedIn data, and then using that to create personalized snippets.

An example might be asking for something starts with was on your LinkedIn profile and saw you  finished with something like <summarize what type of clients they serve and in what ways they uniquely help them>.

Its important to add qualifiers like use 4-8 words to complete the prompt, avoid jargon and buzzwords, or keep the language casual and conversational.

Once you create a prompt that produces the results youre looking for, you can plug it directly into a sequencer and send them off as a personalized field.

2. Notion ai in order to spintax copy.

After a personalized opening, often were using lines that make an observation tied to our CTA or give an example of a problem their persona may face.

Spintaxxing the copy allows us to write it once and send many variations of the same general idea. This keeps domains healthy & emails out of spam filters ((as opposed to sending very similar emails over and over and over)).

3. ChatGPT to interpret and brief us on email replies.

As replies from domains roll in, I have them filter through chatGPT which will categorize them by level of interest and provide context into its thinking and why it suggested that label.

This has made inbox management easier and context switching from email to email faster since we surface key information quickly.



Anyone else using ai to book meetings creatively ?

content:
People behave like learning is linear and that information retention is WAY easier than it is

So we add a large count of learnings without much depth or application; things like reading a book per week, or listening to xyz podcast every day or following these 20 creators.

Not an ideal way to learn if knowledge absorption is your goal& 

Picking the right few resources and going deep is much more impactful, but takes patience and consistency which is hard af

We cope by adding more sources of information to provide an excuse for lack of application.

Ive seen a lot of salespeople scramble when they need to organize

Ive seen lists where people should focus on one thing

Ive seen pivots where people should maintain course

A lot of it comes from uncertainty

Scarcity

All stemming from lack of psychological security which is the word HR pros use to describe the feeling that you can excitedly sprint forward at the simple next step thing you need to do.

It requires clarity, confidence and commitment.

If you lack that, you need leadership: either from peers, managers or coaches

Do you have a system you abide by currently?

Or do you need one?

content:
Ease and effectiveness are two ideas at odds with each other

Its how so many of us sabotage our own success & happiness

Ease is impulse. Its survival. We are wired to use as few resources as necessary to accomplish tasks - energy waste is a threat in the wild.

But its also lazy. It lacks thoroughness. It misses critical details.

Effective is control. Its human. We have the ability to pause and think beyond the face value of a situation to determine best next step actions.

If you believe in the saying anything worth doing is worth doing right, then be mindful of where youre letting ease distract you from excellence

The path to accomplishing your wildest dreams wont be one of ease; so its time to get serious about how effective you are.

content:
Cold call opening Barrett Unger and I are using currently:

"Hey NAME - who at COMPANY is happiest when your yearly sales target gets hit?"

It's hilarious how well it's been working for us - and here's why ((I believe)) it hits...

1. It's a fun question to answer. We transport them briefly to a world where they have succeeded in their yearly goal, and you tend to get a laugh or joking response back... aka prospects get a kick out of it

2. It's a true pattern interrupt. This isn't your average SDR opener, and you WILL cause a legit pause from prospects as they ponder the question you just asked.

3. It's step 1 of Justin Michael's RRM cold call framework. We are essentially asking "who is the CEO of the problem?", which in our case means who owns hitting yearly sales targets ((we are targeting Founders of smaller professional services businesses)).

They almost always answer with "Well I do"...

4. We double down. The response to them usually isn't going into a pitch, but asking "And are you more of a sports car kinda person, or a nice vacation type?".

Again - we are doubling the fun question // pattern interrupt, which also builds tremendous tension & curiosity in what you're calling about.

----

Once there - we'll usually ask what they're doing currently to book meetings, and proceed to identify whether there's reason to set an appointment.

If you wanna hear a little snippet of a cold call using this line - comment "send it" below and I'll get the mp3 sent over...

content:
I've seen a lot less people enthused by sales careers over the last few months

In the community I run, a few have reached out asking if they should pivot

Reminds me of my favorite Jocko Willink video...

"Good."

Life's hard - that's the rules... so if a little bit of turbulence leads you astray, it might mean you weren't doing the right thing for you anyways

The thing you should be doing needs to make sense even in the most difficult moments; not just when things are going smoothly

That's called skin in the game. ((antifragile))

Sales is a contact sport. It WILL test your faith as well.

Now's one of those times for many; between layoffs, underperformance and fear porn bait posts by popular talking heads... people's spirits are being tested

I don't buy it when people pretend you need to be a certain type of person for sales.

All you need is will.

For those who are braving it out - understand that the mere act of continuation despite the current headwinds proves you're built for this.

Sales is a series of experiments - if you iterate while avoiding catastrophic failure... you can find the success you're looking for.

You got this.

content:
A lot of the core principles of sales gets obscured in the LinkedIn saas sales community

Its kinda paradoxical - but the discussions get so focused on the micro, that oftentimes much more meaningful macro principles are missed

Especially for the average or below seller& aka the majority of sellers&((no offense - keep going - youll get thered))

They really suffer from how complicated things are made out to be, how negative discussions can get around what does or doesnt work, and the illusions created of what success looks like as a sales professional 

If you were to bring yourself back to day 1 of selling, would you really find the current environment as useful as back then in terms of leveling yourself up?

It was easier when you could just buy Josh Braun and Kevin Dorseys guides, follow those& payoff

You wouldnt believe the burnout I see on a daily basis of sellers who do perfectly fine work for companies with shotty product market fit, zero leadership, or just no direction 

When I meet with startup founders Ive also found that their issues are never bizarre micro strategies that they needed to have picked up off LinkedIn 

Its usually foundational things that need to be led better, or organized, or explained simply

I believe that theres a lot of over complication of things in order to create a feeling of scarcity that people can then sell things into these people as a solution 

But are the results actually better?

From what Ive heard from the 300+ salespeople Ive helped get SDR roles - not really&

It seems that people are information rich, but knowledge poor

Am I wrong?
title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
Targets -> strategy -> roles -> metrics -> workflows

#1 thing Ive seen businesses & solo operators miss on is this

In all businesses, theres a MAJOR risk of wasting most of your time by being all over the place

This framework Ive used in startups, larger orgs, solo operations, and everything in between&

It starts with targets - define WHY you are even doing whatever it is that youre doing 

Then identify the strategy - WHAT do we need to do to accomplish this? Its crucial here to enable the person owning the strategy to do define this

Next define the roles needed - WHO do we need and WHERE in order to fulfill this strategy that we just defined?

Once we do that, we associate metrics to tell us WHEN we are doing a good job and when we are not; we want to avoid constantly pivoting what we measure & why - so spend time here dialing in the things that matter most

Lastly youll define HOW youll influence these metrics to be successful Aka the workflows you need to follow to win

I cannot tell you how often people start with workflows or people and try to back into targets& or worse&. Instances where there is literally no strategy in place and its a bunch of people doing their own thing trying to hit the target lol

Rome wasnt built in a day; thankfully that had powerful leaders to keep everyone on task >#

Greatest football coach of all time knew identity precedes behaviors - and believing youre a champion before you are is the path to becoming one

Talked to 3 young professionals this weekend struggling to reconcile their vision and goals with their current reality; they felt alone, empty and as if their dreams were crashing down

#1 thing I see killing peoples happiness is scarcity mindset creeping in; where they compare themself to others vs themself, fail to acknowledge their own accomplishments, and lie to themselves saying their goals are far fetched

Adopting a true abundance mindset - putting all self doubt to rest - bravely trudging forward with confidence and belief is the path out

Fulfillment isnt inherent in life - its not going to happen accidentally

Dare to dream - identify goals - SHARE THEM BEFORE THEY HAPPEN - own them as your truth - and get tf after it!

Happy Monday everyone&

And Gm =

content:
Goals are overrated vs core values imo

How you exist tees up what you accomplish; but the inverse isnt true at all

Existing where the means justify the ends sacrifices a lot of beauty in life - such as the opportunity to serve others as a primary focus with faith that doing it well enough, long enough, will bring you everything you want in life

Im a big believer that everything I desire is on the other side of things Ill do for others

But beyond that, spiritually, I only care to succeed if it happens as a byproduct of me doing the things I want to do in life

Its not worth it being miserable in the short run for a theoretical gain at the end of the tunnel

You can be a champion this very instant if you forfeit self-doubt and live with an abundance mindset; theres no urgency to get through life& its something to be experienced and taken in

Sometimes this philosophical stuff can come off as tangential or soft from the outside looking in - but thats peoples own self limiting beliefs affecting the frame they see the world through
 
The most badass football coach of all time wasnt too good to focus on the system first and let the results fall where they may

In fact - according to him thats where the magic happens

Are you goal oriented? Or value oriented?

You can be both - but which one trumps the other when the two are at ends with each other?

Worth a thought Imo

He does a lot of commentary or technical breakdown of amateur events where mistakes are obvious
