Focusing on common mistakes that come up in live application for coaching makes it relatable

Its easy to identify the behaviors being shown

The coaching cues are simple to follow as well

Reminds me of learning anything really

A great coach is a massive benefit

Fighters dont have the opportunity to see their fights from the outside so a coach you can trust makes all the difference in the world

content:
If you get laid off the best thing you can do is quietly run outbound motions to hiring managers

Its the strongest position you can be in - PROVING abilities in the way you contact them

Network intros or social asks are fine - but robs you of the opportunity to land a role for the skills you display

Not saying its wrong to do the other way - but I promise theres a LOT of hiring managers whod resonate with the quiet, precision based approach I describe here

1. Find open roles

2. DO NOT APPLY TO THEM

3. Use Apollo(dot)io free trial to get their email

4. Run multi channel LinkedIn + email approach to close for a convo about the role

5. Ask what their dream candidate looks like

6. Ask disqualifying questions about yourself

7. Close by asking if theres any reasons you wouldnt be an amazing fit for the role

If NOT - then apply & get fast tracked through process

If YES ((objections)) - then use whatever objection handling framework you like ((I use APAC)) to see if have a chance

Either way youre the mf man in the arena

Taking it upon yourself to do what we do

Make deals happen =

Working on your self identity is a fast track to addressing behaviors impeding your success

content:
Being really good at something that doesnt make you happy is a big risk for people with high grit

Heres a simple framework for identifying whats worth applying extreme effort towards:

- What am I ((or could become)) among the best in the world at?

- What can I deliver World class results doing? ((And why can I?))

- What do I love doing?

Checking all three boxes means something is likely a worthy endeavor - bevause anything that does will inherently be high value ((assuming a market exists for it))

Exist with meaning to avoid finding yourself years down the line regretful for coasting through life

Sometimes working hard is a cope to avoid facing your own consciousness

No one else can decide by what measure you are fulfilled - so trying to win based on externally focused metrics is a fat L

Instead - define your own that inherently make you the person you want to be

If that really is just a busy bee then congrats youve made it

But for most that means aiming themselves at something deeper to them

A great system makes success really fkin easy for everyone operating in it

A poor system relies on individuals excellence to create wins

Many place their self worth in their ability to make poor systems suck less, and perform decently ((at great cost in terms of time or other resources ))

Acutely; solving symptoms moves the needle more than addressing the bigger things ((aka short term))

What % of your teams workflows overlap?

A full eclipse means youve designed a system that embodies the core value of your work, and leaves space for individuals to execute however they see fit

content:
Spreading your time thinly between many excellent things often leaves you unfulfilled in all of them

I like a ramped approach

You can only have one main priority

Whatever it is - focus all energy here first

Once you have some sort of routine in place that enables success here, layer on an additional factor

I.e. once I am going to the gym three times every week, I will work on adjusting my diet; but until I am, I wont waste energy thinking about diet

This cures the #1 reason people dont achieve their goals

Lack of focus

If you balance 10 things its easy to give the excuse of why youre dropping the ball; you have a ton to manage!

But if you have ONE single goal - laser focused&

It becomes unacceptable ((and less likely)) that youre totally blowing it

Heres the play:

- zero in on one goal
- share it with those close to you
- check in regularly with progress
- solve the real issue if not making progress
- layer on additional goals as you gain momentum

Ever miss 10 goals at once?

No mï¿½s

content:
Youre looking at the Coordinator of Rapid Rupture", which specifically referred to the propagation of a fast neutron chain reaction in an atomic bomb.

Robert Oppenheimer - whos son was a client of mine back when I ran my own company - changed the course of human existence when he was called upon for the Manhattan Project by President Roosevelt.

This morning a text from a friend got me thinking about energy storage; particularly human excellence - and the energy we wield within us.

A nuclear bomb works by harnessing the forces that hold the nucleus of an atom together by splitting the atom to unleash massive explosive power.

What intrigues me is how this massive reaction starts with the smallest unit of matter - an atom

In an organization, market or any other collection of humans - the atom is the individual.

We can generalize across large groups of them and pretend that creates powerful insights

If Oppenheimer taught me anything, its that the big stuff happens when you take the time to go micro

Inside each one of us, and every human we encounter - forces within are ready to be unleashed in a hellfire of passion and effort

If we want to win in life - I think we need to focus on how we can actualize the individual better o accomplish nuclear successes

Management, capital and control wont be the means of accessing these powers though - which is good because it will be harder for a*shoves to compete in this human-centric approach

No more rounding out the edges

No more monocultural tech industry

Way more friction - a natural occurance of *TRUE* diversity - the kind that *doesnt* actually get invited to the table because it wont stand down when told to

Call me the new coordinator of rapid rupture 

Sometimes it takes a little chaos today to drive towards peace and harmony tomorrow

Welcome aboard

Lets talk iatrogenics - caused by healer 

In medicine this is the downside to intervention - tail risk caused when doctors choose to get involved medically

Despite high success rates - death is a very real outcome for most surgeries.

Similarly - traffic signs or even jaywalking laws - intervention for public good, have arguably made driving habits WORSE believe it or not


The workplace has this too - as does content, and really anything that catches your eye

Pivoting messaging **may** increase results - but it could also rank them, or cause you to forego finishing the current campaign youre running, which may mean never fully understanding the effectiveness of it

We also see iatrogenics occur with coaching or advice giving

In my jiu jitsu gym - white belts arent supposed to coach each other because of this same risk

The idea of telling someone how to do something or what to do may seem without risk - but thats naive

EVERYthing in life comes with a cost

1. People dont know how to build an ROI positive on time business around them, aka they spend too much time to make it worth it

2. They dont know the tools and technologies to make it easy

title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
In submission grappling - the concept of dilemmas is used to convey lose-lose situations for opponents who are stuck choosing between two positions that disadvantage them

Inside of companies - each individually scoped out role comes with a set of dilemmas as well - though these tend not to be lose-lose, but more like perennial tension to be reconciled

Ex:

An SDR wants to book a high volume of calls ((to make money)), but focus on volume erodes quality and may cause a drop in qualification % 

An AE wants calls from SDRs, but if they accept // qualify them and dont close it will be seen as a negative so theyre stuck leaning towards not qualifying iffy meetings 

If Im calling the founder of a HVAC company - their dilemma is they suck at digital marketing but dont trust the droves of cold emails they get speaking digital marketing

This understanding is important for sellers if they want to speak more directly to the reality of their buyers

Calling a founder to ask *if* theyd be interested in learning about how you can grow their lead flow is silly

If they trusted you and believed that you could fulfill that outcome - theyd surely say yes

Yet they ignore dozens of these asks daily

Why?

Theres no trust - and you sound like the pattern they ignore ((easily))

What theyre dilemma?

They need the result - but dont trust anyone so they act slowly or not at all.

When we call or write to these people - we should meet them there; better to ask if theyve decided the entire digital marketing industry is a scam than whether they want leads.

Its a bit shocking - but cuts through the BS

Dave - do you believe digital marketing is a scam industry with no results - or is it possible youve only done business with poor providers?

If they accept it sometimes works&

You can open up the dialogue around what theyd need to see to build trust

But the truth is - you already are

By being the one sales guy in the world to admit that of f*cking course everyone wants the result you promise 

Its jus that few will take the time to prove they arent full of ..it ;)
title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
Sales dev adds complexity where AEs add simplicity&

Like a 1-2 combo in boxing - the former causes disruption for the latter to land solidly

But to speak about these reps - well think from the perspective of buyers

Unless they came inbound, presumably these people arent planning on using your service

Features wont compel them

So an SDR makes contact and stokes the curiosity of a prospect - using open ended questions mixed with direct statements of fact

By not focusing on what we do, how we do it and instead on the prospect, the dilemmas we know they face in their role, and what carrots // sticks exist in their world&

By asking great open ended questions that drive net new thinking&

we shift how prospects think - and earn entry into their world where once they identify us as empathetic and competent& they open up unlike to any other rep running standard disco

You earn the right to ask more challenging, direct questions here

As the status quo thinking erodes in front of you - prospects face a choice:

1. Maintain a poker face and defend status quo - if youre here, its an emotional defense oftentimes and needs to be met accordingly

2. Admit theyre now floating astray in a sea of uncertainty - if youre here and the prospect acknowledges theyll need to make a change - usually theyll ask you what to do next&

If you make it to the latter - youve just teed up an excellent opportunity for your AE to come in and button up into a nice little deal&

By vaporizing status quo thinking - without selling - sales dev can help bring prospects to the conclusion that they CANT just keep doing what they have been if they want to succeed over the next 12 months& 

It might be one of the only roles in the world where bringing up problems without solutions is actually better than solving things

Make it messy - then let the AE come in and do the simplifying of the mess you made them >

After the techniques, the practice, the actual application, the data on performance&

The special sauce

Beyond do as I say, theres a secret underlying truth that all performers know of

It takes courage to harness&

That truth is this: copying what the average person is trying to copy will never get you results above average

Its a low target - and causes massive underperformance vs what is possible

Whats it take to be great then?

Again- the secret juice - but theres a catch ;)

You cant have Paulos& you cant have mine& and even if you did it wouldnt work for you

You need to go out into the world - free yourself from the chains of sameness - and have the bravery to engage the world uniquely through your perspective and skillset

In those adventures, in a time of need where hope seems lost&

Thats where your own secret juice will be revealed

Good luck

content:
Success only exists in the context of the goals that we make for ourselves

How you define success dramatically changes the impact of that success

Imo asking how your goals serve you is underrated

Wanna make a buncha money yah? Who tf doesnt lol&

But is chasing that costing you:

- friendships
- health
- other life events ((marriage, kids, etc))
- sanity

People often pretend its a given that youre chasing the same goals as them

They HATE to see you deviate

They challenge your commitment - they doubt - they run interference

It sounds logical - but who the hell lives a logical life?!

Had a great convo w my brother Daniel Aurelio <) yesterday about where we make choices from

I shared my intention: only make decisions out of what excites me, never what makes the most sense

After a few years of using this heuristic for goal setting, I can attest to how it has served me personally

It has given me strength to forego the scarcity mindset driven chase of life

Being candid - I have full confidence no matter what I do, my financial needs will be met

So no decision can be made for the money purely - only for what feels exciting

When youre doing things that excite you - it doesnt feel like work&

And you end expediting your successes since youre giving discretionary effort and building a positive feedback loop looking forward to your actions instead of dreading them and dreaming for the future

You live lifetimes in the span of what others experience as mere moments

They blink - you experienced a decade&

One life - do with it what you will

Me? I want it all& so I take fun, relaxation, recovery and joy VERY f**king seriously =$

Anyone with me?

content:
Slow down & zoom out to speed up

In my new role I train founders how to lead sales, and I keep seeing something come up:

Reps are trained tons on the micro

A bit on the macro

Nowhere near enough in the middle

Ill explain:

They know we do seo

They know 50938262 little things theyve been told to do or remember

But they rarely are taught how a marketing department functions, the choke points in the flow of marketing teams, or what complaints anyone whos worked with seo firms will have before you even talk with them&

Im a huge fan of proactively bringing up the main objections as fast as possible to disqualify and save everyone time

I tend to get feedback on coming off as knowledgeable - even in fields I know literally nothing about - all because I ask challenging questions

I think a book was written about this - never read it - just bought it for the shelf and astral projected its knowledge into me like all the other sales books Ive read

The chasm between selling as someone in the know Vs repeating what my manager said to say 

Is similar to driving an F1 Ferrari Vs pushing a hot wheel down the track you built with dad&

How well do you know your market?

The last 3 months of being self employed gave me time with my family as we went from 2 -> 3 and welcomed our son into the world.

Its been unreal. Powerfully transformative. Antifragile.

From the get go - I knew I would never ~ not ~ be self employed again, but that the best path forward from my eyes was still developing under someone else.

Ive watched people take jobs for money that laid them off unceremoniously weeks later.

Ive seen people take jobs for category creating products that turned out to just be boosted chrome tabs

I knew there were 2 things that were non negotiables for me if I was going to accept another w2 role:

- leadership that I wanted to become more similar to & model my abilities after

- A canvas to paint the future of my career; somewhere to make a big impact

Today I get that first ask joining JJ Russell as Sr Sales Advisor at ((Closed)) where I plan to deliver on the second in big ways =

In this role I get to work with digital agency founders to build out successful sales teams as they transition from Founder lead selling to a team lead motion.

Additive effort is the difference between a monotonous hell & snowballing forward

It came to be when considering the impact of a rep blind dialing 1000 random numbers a day vs really diving in to understand who // when // what // where // why and how these people might be open to engaging with them

Random dials teaches nothing if youre not getting a minimum viable result out of it

Its like closing your eyes and going to a batting cage

One of the biggest mistakes salespeople make is falling into a pit of blackpills and failing to show up daily doing things to make them a better performer the next

Examples of additive effort:

- calling 10 targeted contacts and asking some questions around their day to day without an ask for meeting to learn your ICP better ((Josh Braun  jobs to be done interview))

- segmenting your lead list further to be more targeted with your messaging & impact stories

- spending the time to enrich your data so that you have decent phone dials and other necessary info

- learning to speak with your targets vs pitching them

- practicing your presentation or call skills with other reps instead of re/inventing the wheel for the 32nd time this fiscal year

Taking a step back from extracting what we want today to better supply what the market needs is always gonna be worth it imo

content:
Common misconception: commissions are taxed at a higher rate than base pay

Truth: commissions ~ may ~ be withhheld at a higher rate, but your tax rate is based on total individual income

At the end of the year - tax season is reconciling your earnings against withholdings; most employers // payroll companies withhold slightly high in order to avoid you owing more at the end of the year

When the check hits it may seem low - but since theres no way to anticipate what tax bracket you will end up in ((and what other sources of income you have outside of your w2)) - thats just how it goes&

content:
Mistakes on learning:

People treat learning as linear and like the lessons last forever; captured somewhere within.

It's easy to add a large count of learnings ((reading new books, downloading new courses, listening to podcasts daily)) - without much depth or application of the "lessons" we allege to carry from them.

Learning is acute - an instance of attained knowledge...

Knowing is chronic - a lasting & engrained understanding ready at our disposal

What's the difference?

Repetitions - Neuroplasticity - the replaying of brainwaves across neural pathways that widens those channels and makes future travel smoother...

Repetitions come from application - real world, full contact usage of knowledge in the scary unknown world outside of us...

I wonder how many reading the nth next book are merely delaying their necessary adjustment from seeing themselves as "incomplete" or "incapable"?

Who may be trapped without belief they are whole as they come today?

Ready to break out?

 Pick the right - FEW - resources and go deep ((much more impactful))

This takes patience and consistency which is hard - and shifts burden of performance gaps from needing more info to looking at ourselves as at fault... it takes a brave someone...

What's one resource you ~ DEEPLY ~ live through today?

content:
Failure is a mental construct related to ego

When I flip a coin and guess heads, but its tails - I didnt fail

Because I knew there was a chance it would be tails

When I write an email cadence - I accept all possible outcomes before sending: even when I do my best, some people wont like it

If youre sending emails or making calls or making attempts at success - how is it a fail to now get the outcome you want most?

What is happening inside you that your ego said you could control that coin hitting heads?

We control our inputs, including our expectations 

Frustration around outcomes often is an expectation issue

Or an effort one

Aka we either didnt do what we knew we should have been doing, or we didnt healthily accept all possible outcomes as reasonable expectations

The universe doesnt reward that sort of behavior in my opinion

Want to get savagely good at the mental game?

Grow up.

Accept all outcomes.

Do things for reasons besides the outcome you hope for.

Become excellent at taking gratitude from your inputs & process

The outcomes become inevitable

And you skip the emotional trauma of calling yourself a failure

Revenue is downstream of impact

Get some

content:
If you've ever wanted to be an award winning storyteller this is literally all you need:

https:((SLASH SLASH))savethecat((DOT))com

If you're still here... let's dig in:

The book "Save the Cat!" is literally a how-to manual for the hero's journey framework that screenplay writers copy paste to write...

Every movie ever.

The 7 core stories are:

1. Overcoming the Monster
2. Rags to Riches
3. The Quest
4. Voyage and Return
5. Rebirth
6. Comedy
7. Tragedy

All of them follow the same "beats", which are:

1. Opening Image
2. Theme Stated
3. Set-Up
4. Catalyst
5. Debate
6. Break Into Two
7. B Story
8. Fun and Games
9. Midpoint
10. Bad Guys Close In
11. All Is Lost
12. Dark Night of the Soul
13. Break into three
14. Finale
15. Final Image

Storytellers should be able to describe each "beat" with just one or two sentences.

This structure is how all your favorite films were made excellent, and also are how your meetings or demos can be excellent.

=K Nick Capozzi is another source of great storytelling info...

// end scene //

content:
Collaboration is a multiplier on excellence

My 6-figures in revenue from my guide would be 5 probably without Barrett Unger 

Welcome to behind the curtain

Early 21 I was spending no less than 10 hours per week on phone calls helping guide people through landing SDR or AE roles from non tech backgrounds

I had racked up a dozen or two wins and wanted to cut my time spent doing so without lowering results

I knew if I could get the same result win hike removing me it would be a big win

So I took student #2 ever, Barrett, and asked for help

You may wonder how someone who hadnt even had a sales role yet could help me write the worlds best guide for landing sales roles, but its easy

He was the market

Smart, hard worker, coachable, gritty and had no f*ckin clue what to do next

The way we worked was almost interview style - and mostly asynchronously 

Id write big chunks of info - send to him - get feedback on clarity and impact - and we iterated on it a few times

Id never have been able to make it as well as I did otherwise

Having fresh perspective and a less expert ((gag)) lens of it made sure I simplified and slowed down where necessary - but also sped up where I got into the weeds

A good collaborator isnt about someone equally talented or better than you - its about having a perspective that strengthens the work process

Its about critique not agreeance

Its antifragile

If youre trying to monetize something youre doing and struggling to create an effortless revenue engine 

Im willing to take on a few clients if I dig your project 

But only if Barrett Unger comes with me

Because 1+1 CAN equal 3

content:
Anti brands are a cool concept from the book different on brand building that you may not have heard before&

Traditional brands: seek to build affinity within markets to drive consumption of products and services

Anti brands: make consumption difficult in order to build affinity with their intended sub-market

Examples&

Supreme - release one-off, expensive drops seasonally. The resale market can be 10x the retail costs the weeks following a drop. The exclusivity increases the perceived value above supply and thus a powerful anti brand is built

Mini Cooper - marketed itself as difficult to fit into and invited people to try to fit themselves into their cars. The sporty rc-esque cars wont be getting any Kevin Durant endorsements, but is a nice choice for the vertically conservative who appreciate MPGs and ease of parking

Sure paywalls, back channels, confusing marketing, memes, gated content, and invite only decreases exposure and may limit growth&

But theres another side of Econ 101 where instead of making a mass available SaaS that is only profitable at crazy scale ((or never most of the time if were bein real&)) you can keep operating costs at near zero and fulfill unique needs of great value at low costs at small scale with huge upside&

Remember that wu tang album that Martin skreli bought ?! >#

Thats what Im talking about =ï¿½

content:
Be careful which of these 2 types of sales roles you accept as your next job to avoid off target earnings & missing your quota&

Not all roles are alike (duh)

This A/B test on what the roles primary day to day life is going to be like will save a ton of headaches

1. The Executor - these roles are for someone who wants to come in and execute. Theyre most appropriate for newer salespeople, though they also have the highest earnings potential so many more senior reps take them.

The distinction here is that the role is filled to place someone into a workflow that ALREADY EXISTS and that is knowingly working to some degree. Its a role player position.

Do x - and youll earn y (mostly)

Being a BDR at salesforce would be like this - no one is reinventing any wheels - show up - run the playbook - execute

2. The Builder - these roles are for someone who wants the challenge of building out and proving a function. It can be a very challenging role with lots of risk, but observationally it seems to stimulate and fulfill sales artists or people with more expertise // experience.

Theyre inappropriate for newer reps oftentimes, because they lack the guard rails to help you through early learning curves that are provided by larger orgs. Its easier to fail. Its harder to understand what is even going on - Ive seen many people burn out in these roles.

Generally, its a company hiring a role to fill a BUSINESS NEED. Uh oh& that means the board is focused on it, the ceo is& and it also likely means no one before you was all too excellent at it either >#

Many such cases of CEOs hiring salespeople to drive revenue when theres fatal flaws in product, marketing or elsewhere that are completely outside of the reps control.

My advice is that newer reps should probably find more of the former, and the latter needs to be scouted out well to know whether theres enough resources behind the project to even work out.

Know whether youre filling a role that exists // taking over a workflow, or whether youre creatine // experimenting with one.

Negotiate pay based on this - builders have a more volatile path to hitting goal - higher base and lower variable as a % might be more appropriate depending on the situation&

I personally prefer builder roles - theyre great for entrepreneurially minded people - I see Erik McKee obviously as another example of someone who is pulled towards building& what great company to be in right?

What do you prefer? Ever think about it this way before ?

Good discussion

Importantly, she didnt focus on her credentials or try to outrank in this discussion - 

Because its a fallacy that one needs the formal expertise to play in the arena

See it all the time in LinkedIn - fall in line& leave it to the pros

Couldnt disagree more

Disrupt the pros is my stance

Innovate

Thats the world we play in - thats the arena&

And we all have a seat at that table :)

content:
When sales reps ask me how an email looks

I usually ask back idk - but how do you think itll make someone feel to read this?

Lotta technical analysis goin on 

Good stuff too

My gut tells me that injecting warmth and literally writing in a way that shifts how your prospect feels in that moment is a good way to land messages with them

Idk how many words it takes

Idk the subject line

I use weird punctuation 

But if you can make someone take a moment to grin

And maybe break their thought patterns a bit from the noise out there

Even an imperfect otherwise message can convert just fine

My big 2 focuses writing email:

- will they care about the substance?
- how would this make them feel?

I see the same with calls and other channels too - technically accurate with low empathy and robotic execution

Be human!

content:
When job descriptions rigidly require something

Oftentimes its not youre not good enough to applicants

It really just means theyre not good at training that aspect of the job

Require experience for entry level? The company might not even know what the difference between good and bad reps are, so they use this as a filter

Require xyz technology? They cant teach you probably - all tech is easy if youre familiar and take time to learn.

Its a massive competitive advantage to be able to consistently train and produce serviceable reps rather than having to rely on hiring people serendipitously prepared to execute your go to market motion&

Im sorry but Im pretty sure my friend Saad Khan could have a fence post closing deals, so I dont see how your SDR role requires more experience than your founders have as founders =

Training is a superpower - Candace Taber is an example of someone in L&D making huge impact for salespeople

I kinda cant believe that any companies dumping payroll into Sales Dev dont have advisors, coaches or other budget for their team to help maximize the effectiveness on those dollars

75% of the spend gets you the rep 

25% gets you quality enablement, management, etc..

I get so many reps hitting me up who are like 4 hours of solid coaching per month away from being leaps improved as a seller&

Especially in this economic climate, maximizing impact per rep and speed to impact will help keep sales teams and people healthy without leaving them dry on the vine

content:
When I look to personalize outreach to someone, I look for their favorite thing that no one ever asks them about...

Personalizing the same way as everyone else makes YOU the pattern

If I went toï¿½Patrick's profile, I might talk about being a Math Teacher

If it'sï¿½Carolynï¿½11/10 times I'm mentioning cheez-itz ((yes...))

If it'sï¿½Danï¿½I'll throw in an analogy to the UFC

The core signal of any given piece of outbound tends to be around problems a prospect may be running into.

The was we deliver that message is through pattern interrupts // "buying" their valuable attention ((competing with TikTok and family time mind you...)).

I doubt that any of the above 3 get as jazzed up about KPIs as they do the things I mentioned...

Especially from a complete stranger // salesperson...

I'm a fan of aligning to the human first -> then the business driver // problem they're facing -> then how you can do anything about it....

Nothing always works - nothing never works - this has served me well and created a ton of warm conversations over the years...

content:
It wasnt until SaaS that I ever saw people regularly identifying themselves as failing

Growing up my parents taught us not to speak to ourselves that way

Maybe this is a little ~ woo woo ~ 

But I think theres a better frame:

When we make an attempt, or step into the arena so to speak, our ego shouldnt necessarily be saying win or you fail because life isnt so black and white

Attribution isnt so simple.

When we win to pretend we know all of what went into that exactly and that we have it all figured out is ignorant&

Its just another data point.

When we miss - whether by committing to a strategy that doesnt achieve our goals, or whether we dont follow through with our own plan of action&

Its just another data point.

What we control is the attempts; the results are inevitabilities of good faith effort mixed with properly strategized approach.

We control inputs.

Data.

We get back outcomes.

Data.

Someone, somewhere is hopefully looking at this data through an analytical lens and helping understand where changes in those 2 inputs ((strategy & good faith attempts)) can lead you to the outcomes you desire.

Your manager depends on it.

Your ceo does. The whole company does.

Its no small privelege to be batting lead off on behalf of your organization trying to win the World fkin Series of SaaS Go-to-market

Someone needs to do it - someone needs to step up to the plate

Each rep matters.

Its all just data.

If your company is closing 20% of leads, the 80% you arent closing werent wastes of time to talk to were they?

Its poor self talk, and cult-like if you ask me. Definitely not humanizing.

No ones failing when theyre putting in earnest effort.

Its all a part of the game <{

content:
Simple way to win the preview text window in cold email >+

Change:

Hey Kellen,

I was listening to B2B Power Hour and heard your episode talking about cold outbound

Into:

Kellen - your episode on B2B Power Hour on cold outbound was great&



This does 2 things for you

1. It gets your personalization closer to the first words, so you are more immediately capturing the benefit of referencing the podcast appearance

2. it uses you phrasing instead of I, which in theory resonates more with readers and imo does help land your personalization better

Bonus is it brings the tonality down from corporate into speaking level& and aligns to how I would talk versus write something formally

Its good for preview because depending on your subject, pushing your personalization too far into the copy might mean its only seen if your email is opened&

People often mistake subject line as the only part factor in opens but it definitely isnt&

The copy after obviously still has to hit and have relevance, but this helps make it feel like its meant for your prospects rather than a cold ask

Deposit > withdrawal

Deposit warmth 

Withdraw quota =ï¿½

content:
I sold these early in my career, just like my dad

Expensive, heavy as hell, not great value&

But people love McIntosh audio gear; why?

Form often *does* take precedent over function, and pretending objective reality matters in terms of value is SELFISH

A valuable lesson my dad taught me early on:

Its not your money, its theirs&

Really important when I was selling pairs of speakers surpassing my yearly earnings.

So when the person with a $3M home goes shopping for in-home audio experiences - youre missing the point if you focus on what your preferences are and what you do yourself

We need to be method actors

When I sold to Hall of Fame athletes as an example, I tapped into the drive to be #1

Look - the best value is these Sony amps& but if you wanna have the system that your friends ask what the heck this beautiful piece of art is&. You can triple the spend and never need to replace it again&

Other times it came down to aesthetics to match the house

What I learned was theres a million reasons not to buy

But a deal can close if you have the one right reason to buy

It can be heavy, expensive and lower value - but win in more important drivers based on what any given client is looking for

it has nothing to do with you

And everything to do with your buyers

content:
Specificity kills creativity

One of the biggest issues I see in companies or teams is silod responsibility

When sales only feels accountable to x

And marketing y

And product z&

Theres TONS of lost opportunities to provide value, align and differentiate that exists between the responsibilities of those functions

I see it constantly with SDR teams being under utilized

Or marketing teams driving metrics that arent driving revenue

Or product building something that sounded good in their jam, but not one customer asked for

The worst situations is when companies rally around goals that dont actually drive desirable outcomes - and it happens all the time

To me, roles like Revops or chiefs of staff are great ways to join these various business units and align them to creative go-to-market strategies

If you hire great people with high creativity but extinguish it all with job descriptions, best practices and rules of engagement that arent build to capture the value that person brings

Youre missing out, theyre miserable& 

It takes trust & faith - but equipping your people to be adaptable in their application of their skill sets is just as important as your company being adaptable to prospect needs& 

The ai and robots will beat the companies using people as cogs in a machine - but those leveraging empathy and humanness will win

I paused - because I know myself

Im about to blurt out some unfiltered truth&

We are all resposonible for our own situations. Life isnt fair, people are dealt different hands, but all we can do is take ownership and do what we can with that hand

Many such cases of people allowing their own excuses to lie between their current misery and future potential for happiness& the most in demand trait is self belief and ownership&

content:
One thing to significantly increase your chances of getting that job you want&

Dont apply

Instead, direct message the hiring manager directly:

Hey Sarah - Saw youre hiring for x, and had a few questions about working at y before I apply - got a few?

Youre going for intrigue more than extensively selling yourself here&

Sometimes theyll jump on a call - so have your questions ready& ((qualify them as a fit for you&))

Other times theyll say hey just go ahead and apply

Thats cool too - imo dont fight it - youll still probably get fast tracked to second round interviews ((just has been what weve seen in The Speakeasy))

The point is - get your name out there before theyre weeding through things&

Ideally you become a top candidate

At worst maybe a slight boost when the applications are being filtered through&

Importantly - youre taking things into your own hands - owning the frame

Good luck <ï¿½

content:
Something ultra impactful that I never see posted on here

Once youre earning above cost of living - invest early & itll change your life

Also save up for a down payment asap imo

Being the first of your peers to buy a home means you cant rent to them at market rate and have a VERY low personal cost of living&

Its cool to buy a nice car with new money

But its really really cool to secure a baseline cost of living for life that wont fluctuate YoY, and depending on your market - make big money on appreciation&

Many of us come from a background where our parents couldnt do this&

They worked so hard - gave us everything& put us here to have a better life than them&

This is an excellent way of doing so imo&

((Dont do this solo or off my advice - if you need a professional to assist you I have a great network of people Id trust&))

- Its not about giving up fun now to set up a future though -

Its about doing the little things to set up the future, so you can enjoy everything else now fully without a worry for the future <{

Dont wait !

content:
Revenue is downstream of impact

What you want is preceded by what you can do for someone else

Josh Braun says deposit before you withdraw

Others say "add value" ((meh))...

Josh wins because "add value" ignores sales 101 which is that NOTHING is valuable until you learn about your prospect first...

Especially when "value" to you is something you whipped up in 34 seconds and your prospects' time is worth $5,000 per hour plus stock...

So back to sales 101 - listen, learn, run discovery before making a "pitch"

When prospecting, folks like Jack Ryan >ï¿½<ï¿½understand if you put your ear to a shell ((or cliff in Yosemite)), you can hear the distant subtle sounds of your prospects already telling you there problems

Knowing your prospect's native language and current problems is Willy Wonka's Golden Ticket into elite tier sales opening - because proprietary "intent data" gives you a pattern interrupt that others don't know yet

If I'm not thirsty, you'd have a hell of a time selling me a bottle of coca cola - no matter how cheap the discount - because there's ZERO impact...

But on a hot sunny day?

See me bent over panting after a hike with jeshua posey in the East Bay?

You bet your ass I'm open to spending $20 on a warm Dasani out of the back of your trunk...

This is super common with SDRs looking to become AEs

Be patient :)

content:
Talking about problems or what doesnt work or complaining are all negative affirmations and will truly f*ck up your mood // thought patterns if you exist in that space too often

Instead&

Try to do what I call affirm the positive

Replace: Bob is always doing whatever he wants and doesnt follow instruction well ((negative))

With: If we could get Bob to follow instructions more closely rather than do whatever he wants, wed get xyz good result ((positive))

The difference is that negative statements tend to be backwards facing and have zero additive benefit // dont solve the problem

Affirming the positive forces one to apply their own thinkin and find the solution to their negative realization - which nudges you to phrase things looking forward as to how you can mitigate whatever youre seeing that needs adjustment&

Affirmations are real

Use empowering language with yourself and your team

Realize your words DO matter

content:
Positive signals (money, praise, title) weaken when repeated over time

Negative signals (annoyance, frustration, anger) strengthen when repeated

This means you need to find variance in positive signal ((aka change things up)) to maintain effectiveness with your praise & rewards

And you need to be attentive to negative signals that may seem insignificant but will derail things for you if left unmitigated

The hard part here is we are often fearful to do anything besides what is tried & true, which leads to even that not working&

Leaders - dont fall into the bad habit of commoditizing praise & reward :)

content:
Patience brings opportunity to exploit, that urgency suffocates&

In jiu jitsu - forcing things doesnt work and tends to lead to undesirable outcomes&

Sales is the same -

Theres 2 things we do:

- open
- close

When opening:

- use naturally occurring triggers ((what others do without your influence)) to engage and redirect energy based on their drivers and your ability to solve their pains

- pattern interrupt HARD; this moment causes as a mental scramble in which you can challenge status quo thinking free of patterns of no

- dont force reasons to talk, know that they WILL occur naturally if you dont burn contacts and read the meta

Imo - opening is about expanding thinking to bring open to new ideas

When Closing:

- focus on their drivers and understand value of solving // cost to ignore

- button things up by identifying black swans and any risks that may threaten your deals

- seek to disqualify and be honest w blockers& this buys a lot of trust

- own the frame ((shoutout bow tied sales guy on twit& hehe))

You cant control what you cant control&

But you can control everything else >

content:
In the middle of coaching, training and stress management lives the question "Who needs what, when... and why?"

Aka diagnostics, solutions, and measurements.

The world of diagnosing "Is there a problem?" is like prescribing Tylenol because someone says "I don't feel well".

Will it help?

Probably.

Does it fix it?

Maybe.

For how long?

God knows... but it definitely isn't the "right" thing so much as a shot in the dark

Whether it be world class managers or those promoted seventeen seconds ago - adding an additional layer of understanding to their team's current needs and capacity helps align managerial styles to needs in a way currently be done by assumption only.

When only a portion of your company will be getting to utilize "x-benefit" (see: above), how do you pick who it is?

HR is stretched thinly as is - and how the hell are they supposed to be measuring stress levels 500 miles away via zoom?

How long are you willing to let alignment issues eat at growth before the quarterly (at best?) engagement survey surfaces that within sales there's an issue under one of your managers that could have been easily fixed earlier on - but has since lead to 2 employees leaving?

Giving managers themself a tool to understand and address needs on the fly makes everything in this ecosystem more impactful.

It adds precision
title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
Not being willing to try is the beginning to the end. Louie Simmons

Yesterday the universe lost a legend.

This quote powerfully aligns the world of lifting to professional performance where oftentimes fear of the next step is our main limiting factor.

Whether Im coaching sellers, discussing strategy with founders, or helping people teams craft feedback loops to understand their next move - its always the right move to do what you can now, next

I say this not from a place of authority so much as reflection.

For those who arent familiar - Louie founded Westside Barbell and developed the conjugate method of strength training to maximize output in strength athletes.

His methodologies focus on max effort ((load)) days and dynamic effort ((volume)) training days in a 4 day split

Heres how youd copy similar methods:

Mon: High Effort (low reps, high intensity)
Tues: High Volume output
Wed: High Effort (low reps, high intensity)
Thurs: high volume again
Fri: flex based on weekly goal being me

Whats great is that this effort schedule is universal to all effort based tasks - and a legitimately good program

For learning guitar Id read tabs Monday, play that off memory Tuesday, read tabs Wednesday, play again off memory Thursday, and then send a drift video of me doing it Friday to Patrick William Joyce for feedback

Rest In Peace Louie - gonna hammer legs later in your memory

content:
How to get an SDR role:

((Literally this easy))

1. List out the traits salespeople need to succeed. 

Justin Michael says Grit, Adaptability and Coachability are the top 3. I would add problem solving, curiosity and communication if I was interviewing as an SDR.

2. Write out a story for each of these traits highlighting the behavior you displayed and the impact it made for interview stories.

3. Write out a resume using a Canva template that displays the above traits and highlights any numerical achievements you have (100%+ attainment, top of team in something, etc)

4. Use Linkedin or Vouris job board to find open sales roles. Usually there are THOUSANDS available remote in the US, so you'll need to organize your data in G-sheets or something like that.

5. Once you find a role, also add to your database the contact (linkedin only works, but adding email by using Seamless.AI will increase win rates) info for the hiring manager ((doesn't have to be perfect, just guess your best)).

6. Now reach out using copy similar to what =ï¿½ Will Allred posts about email, but maybe shorten even further for LinkedIn

7. Open with personalization and relevance, and close for "interest" in next steps like "Hey Kellen, saw you're hiring SDRs - hoping to connect to ask a few questions about what you look for in top performers?"

8. Be genuine, curious, and if there's a fit based on your convo - ask how they recommend you apply for the role. They will tell you, and you're now a stand out talent based on how you engaged them.

Why listen to me?

I have gotten 25+ people hired into their first SDR role since December 21st using the above methodologies.

Hit me with questions if you'd like - happy hunting :)

content:
Many leaders right now are trying to solve capacity problems with capability-centric solutions.

Disastrous.

Capability: what you can ~ do ~

Capacity: what you can ~ endure ~

Capability speaks to information weve already retained and situational problem solving abilities.

Capacity is what we can take in *now* and fluctuates based on environmental factors.

I have the capability to squat 350 lbs, but my capacity to do so is reliant on adequate sleep, diet, warm up, desire, etc.

You are likely accurately identifying capability gaps, but craft trainings or coaching cues with assumptions based on capacity - which is the delta between the changes you want and the changes you get.

Example: learning HOW to write good email wont change the behavior of not sending your daily 30 personalized emails&

My post yesterday had some ideas about measuring capacity if youre interested - or hit me up and we can geek out over this >

I get asked frequently what a Chief of Staff does.

I see it as executive enablement; similar to sales enablement but attached to an executive with a shared goal of execution of a vision.

In my case, I was hired so that (Bryan + Kellen) = 3x Bryan.

It's kinda the best job in the world...

I bring sales expertise and customer buying perspectives to the team that we lack otherwise, but the way I "deploy" those expertise tends to be more like an internal consultant.

Chief of Staff mirrors management roles in that you organize and align people, and look for ways to be the WD40 of what they do.

Chief of Staff is a strategist who takes part in executive decision making.

Chief of Staff carries on certain projects on their own and needs to have TONS of trust between them and their partners so that it becomes EASY to delegate to them rather than difficult.

It works well because I get to put to use the exact types of lessons I "sell" with LEON; how to change the way we do things to improve results and help people happily succeed in them.

If the role interests you, a couple others that I love are Annie Gilbert & Mollie Fleury - both of whom have very unique roles within their org that differ from mine, while encapsulating a lot of the same thematic responsibilities.

My bet is that every company would be better off if they had someone filling a role like this - and it's perfect for us that don't quite fit perfectly into the little boxes that hiring managers want us to fit in...

#Leadership #ChiefOfStaff

content:
Im only eating plain russet potatoes and salt for the next 7 days.

The first question I get is why?! because obviously its a ridiculous thing to do.

But heres the thing:

Ones ability to do challenging things is a skill in of itself.

My why is the same reason I do Murph each Memorial Day to honor Michael P. Murphy, why I train submission grappling weekly, and why I meditate daily.

Doing things that are challenging to me help me adapt and improve.

The benefit is how easy it makes benign things like:

- making cold calls (aint never goin away&)
- prospecting target accounts
- writing great emails (easier w/ Lavender)
- filming personalized videos
- writing blog posts
- running meetings

Aka my job =@

When people respond in shock to things I do, it comes off like they may be doubting their own ability to do similar, which to me is the opposite of feeling empowered.

So if you want to empower yourself, do some hard sh*t (like today& NOW)&

Or just eat some potatoes for a week, which is easy to the strong willed =

title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
Happy, healthy employees perform best.

But what happens when someone inevitably *isn't* happy, or is struggling with something else, and you need them to perform?

First the framework:

"HEALTH" can represent immediate state of being. High happiness means people feel good about facing their work, and are likely to be focused, productive and engaged.

The problem is it is volatile as f**k.

Like, "I was on cloud 9 four minutes ago but just had a deal fall through and now I am miserable but have a call in 12 minutes to close one that I don't feel great about..." volatile.

Nightmare scenario - this person needs to dig deep to show up fully "on" to close this new challenging sale...

Enter "RESILIENCE" - or one's ability to succeed and display effort despite low "HEALTH" or short term volatility.

I refer to this as your "insurance policy" against short term volatility -a highly resilient person will be engaged and productive despite felling poorly, where low resilient people won't be.

I have had exactly ZERO discovery calls where a manager had immediate access to week over week data on Health and Resilience of their people to ensure they coach them to succeed through their CURRENT CAPACITY.

Thankfully, (shoutout the managers out there), y'all do the most trying to support your people how you can.

That's where Bryan Smith and I come in...

Interested in having access to this data on your team, and how tf someone can even measure this???

More on that soon... but if you're anything like me and hate waiting; 

Shoot me a DM and either we'll connect over zoom or I can just make you a loom video :)

content:
3 ways to add value better than 99% of posts // comments on here:

1. When youre leaving a meaningful, engaging comment on someones post, tag some people they may not know well to try to open up the conversation.

Comments expand reach, but engaging discussion expands impact.

A viral post with a platitude that resonates (fine by all means) isnt going to activate prospects and our network like an in-depth analysis a la Carl Ferreira // Refine Labs .

So bringing new, interesting people into discussions to create cross pollination of discussion is a way to truly help that poster.

It also makes you look good when youre bringing productive conversation to two new people.

2. Teach people something specific, that they can use today to improve in their role or life.

Its great to inspire people to want to do things like get healthier but chances are theyd succeed more often if that was adjust diet to be in a caloric balance, increase physical activity, improve self talk, and sleep at least 7.5 hours per night.

Providing value can be defined many ways, but Devin Reed, Sarah Brazier  & Gong took LinkedIn by storm when they blitzed us daily with actionable insights to apply as we read them.

MANY Gong posts were consumed between call blocks, and probably anyone reading this has used one of their subject lines or cold call openers&

Even this post is intended to change the way you operate on LinkedIn starting with this very post (its called we do a little transparency)

Just like anything - SPEED TO VALUE - matters =Q

(Third in comments - if youve enjoyed this do me a solid and tag someone you think would as well)

If they think giving me $5k each year for the next 4 will help them scale from 50 to 500 people with 10% lower attrition, it's a 100x ROI and they'll give me a bunch of referrals too...

Want to close big deals?

Take a page out of Brandon Fluharty newsletter and look to make big impacts first...

When you do, you'll get what you desire as well :)

BUT

Does January yield the best results?

What if you come out the gate sprinting, and by the time "peak season" (in this case, May) comes, you're feeling a little beat up...

So maybe during times where your inputs are LESS effective to making outputs, you focus on deep work // strategic reps (download Lavender and use their email writer to get higher quality reps in).

Then when "peak season" hits and your effort to outcome ratio improves...

LEAVE IT ALL ON THE FIELD.

Then you recover a little before renewal season...

Does anyone know what month they do the least effort in? You can't maximize it every month...

Which do you choose? (Or does it choose for you?)

content:
12 things I learned at LEON in my first 12 months building a startup:

1. Selling products while finding product market fit is WAY different than selling mature products.

2. The people around you probably determine your success levels (but it's up to you who they are).

3. Get humble. Identifying shortcomings and openly addressing them (quickly) creates speed to improvement.

4. Having a "manager" who really understands you is life changing.

5. Listen more.

6. It's really fun getting to work on things outside your normal expertise.

7. Remote doesn't mean alone. I have more, high quality conversations every day today than ever before; shoutout Carolyn Dorricott She/Her, CDSP, Sue Melone, Darren McKee, Dustin Rippetoe, Jack Ryan >ï¿½<ï¿½and honestly so many more for making my 2021 amazing. Love you.

8. You need emotional regulatory ability. There can be months without what feels like a concrete win (especially if you're hard on yourself like I am) - resilience through this is crucial.

9. "Hey it's 8:30PM babe - can you get off your laptop?" <- DO NOT BE THIS PERSON. Manage time appropriately. Thank you Caitlynn Casebeer for your grace <3

10. Avoid monotony.

11. Be BOLD.

12. Team is everything. Bryan Smith Ketan Seetha Elibetsy Herrera Chong Justin Gurtz Pavel Gorin Teija Bean Jocelyn Tsai Braedon Leslie Sagar Parikh, M.D. thank you all for the lessons, challenges and support - it's a blessing to get to share these experiences with you.

2022 - watch out!

content:
The first week after a little break is an interesting one.

Youre recovered and ready to sprint - but should you?

If youve ever played sports, the concept of stretching and warming up before game speed intensity is familiar.

Because even if we are fresh, it doesnt mean we are prepared.

How we transition out of and back into intense work affects our perception of that stress a lot.

Thats why I ALWAYS do a little work on the weekends&

Active recovery

Examples might be:

- catch up with a friend and share the latest on your work efforts

- call a friend and ask for their thoughts on a challenge youve been facing

- clearing out inboxes to 0ish again

- messing around with software tools to see if theres new features worth exploring

- sending some invites on LinkedIn

Point is - it shouldnt feel hard at ALL, but come Monday itll be easier to shift back into work mode.

This is great for people who find themself working too many 10 hour days during the week&

#balance #loadmanagement

content:
It's been a minute since I did one of those "who is Kellen?" posts

So meet.... me =

I grew up in Northern California as the oldest of 3 boys.

My Mom is wicked smart (Master's degree) but got to stay home and raise my brothers and I.

My Father barely graduated high school but started a small business that provided for our family.

When I was 14 I met this girl Caitlynn (more on that later)

At 15 I dropped out of high school.

From then I worked full time and went to junior college part time.

I worked trade jobs and learned work ethic hauling spools of wire and heavy equipment.

I was good, so got promoted from assistant to service tech to lead tech to project manager to sales over 3 years.

But that wasn't enough for me, so I started my own company (at 18) doing the same sort of stuff (home automation systems).

Starting my own business allowed me to pay my way through college, and propose to that Caitlynn girl (she said yes...).

Right before I graduated, my father passed away - it turned my world upside down. I had to dig deep.

I did however, and launched a career in SaaS sales as an enterprise SDR - where I did... okay >#

I met amazing people, failed a ton, but found some success too.

Also Caitlynn and I's wedding happened.

After, I transitioned into an AE for an HR tech company for a few years. It was a great job, but I had the itch to be back in the startup trenches...

During covid lockdowns, I met Bryan Smith arguing with each other (nicely) on the internet.

That lead to me joining LEON with a shared vision for making people happier at work, while helping managers improve team performance.

Besides work and family - I love:

- Helping coach new sales reps (I got a few dozen hired over the last year)
- Lifting weights and training Brazilian jiu jitsu
- Developing people (helping them align their life to what will fulfill them)
- Learning new things

I'm blessed to be on the receiving end from some of the best mentorship and guidance in the world, so I love to pay it forward where I can.

I am happiest serving others.

Nice to (re)meet you everyone =

Did you learn something new?

content:
Momentum can be hard to gain back after some time off (or a period where things are slower than usual, like the holidays).

Heres a huge hack to kick starting 2022 goals:

Start small.

I have nothing against big goals - but only 7% of people succeed on new years resolutions each year.

Instead, I think weight lifting provides a better model for improving ourselves (or a better model for how we progress through those improvements at least).

A new deadlifter may only be able to pull 135 lbs day one, but adding 5 lbs per week for a year (not easy) would get them to 395 lbs (a far more impressive lift).

Much better than being at 135 and exclaiming Id like to get to 395 by end of year

You see, a vague path to excellence will often underperform against a clear system.

So whether you want to grow your company, close more deals, book more meetings, or whatever else it may be for you role in 2022 to be GREAT&

Start small.

Execute relentlessly.

Mean your goals.

Reap the reward.

Cheers to the new year everyone >B

People often start their "new year new me" routine too aggressively.

It's a great way to give ourselves an excuse to fail.

If we pretend that we will maintain 2x output all year, we tell ourselves we will achieve all of our goals...

So that way when we don't keep up the pace, we absolve ourself of the responsibility to do what really matters; hit our goals.

Try coming out the gate at 60-70% pace, and let 2022 be the year that you are relentlessly reasonable with what you can accomplish.

content:
Your CEO and your mother both have power over you, but in different ways...

Understanding the 7 different sources of power will help you leverage yours for the right situations.

The important part is this:

Legitimate and coercive power both make people dislike you when leaned on too much, so it's not great for maintaining working relationships.

Expert, informational, reward and connection power all are ok as well, but still ultimately leave room for better...

Referent power is the most valuable. 

You know that whole "I'm not angry, I'm just disappointed" thing?

That's referent power.

People feel compelled to do as you wish, because your favor means a lot to them!

For managers this is huge; your people will try harder and succeed more often when you take the time to develop this kind of rapport with them.

I've seen enough employee // manager relationships resembling a superhero // supervillain relationship at this point...

Time to align & conquer =

#Management #People

content:
We can manufacture urgency with prospects by creating incentives for them to make decisions quickly.

So when managers of salespeople want added urgency from their team in hitting goals, what are they doing to create it?

"I'll lower the TCV 10% if we can get it signed before EOY" (sound familiar?)

This gives you the chance to reframe the way prospects look at their decision making process to possibly close deals sooner than otherwise.

If this is compelling with buyers, how can it be leveraged to compel sellers?

In theory money is compelling, but in practice that is the case for people already succeeding more than reps who have room to improve.

I think a few "carrots" to provide might be:

- Extra time off once goals are hit i.e. "If we hit 2021's goal, we'll do half-Fridays all of January to help recover from the sprint

- Team incentives for collective 100% attainment i.e. incentivize top performers to help make a difference in those falling short of goal (if they have the capacity/desire)

- Lower the goal temporarily to make attainment "feel" easier and start building back the confidence to hit goals week over week

- Reduce hours now // "cut losses" and focus on recovering to be ready to hit goals come January. Think of this as "recover now to sprint in the new year"

content:
Active recovery is a remote workers best tool to fight burnout while succeeding in their role.

Theres 3 pillars of training that affect load or the strain you feel on a daily/weekly/monthly basis:

Volume - the amount of reps or activities you do. 100 calls is more volume than 50.

Intensity - how difficult or focus intensive each of those reps are. 30 personalized emails using Lavender is more intensity than automating 100 generic ones (and more effective!).

Skills Practice - addition of new skills and practicing components of the real job. Upskilling, L&D, role plays& these should all be layered in strategically when an individual is most ready to receive them

So back to active recovery&

When you are feeling a bit stressed, you can recover usually by lowering volume and leaning on intensity to be effective.

For a weight lifter it means hitting heavy triples for a session instead of 5x5, and for me it means less volume for sales calls but more strategic focus on the ones I do have.

I also like to surround myself with beautiful environments that promote positive emotional responses&

Thanks to a week and a half on the road spanning CA, AZ, NM, CO, UT, and NV - Im back home feeling fresh and ready to close out an incredible year with LEON 

Do you do anything similar?

Need help trying?

DMs are always open! =

title: Helping companies find Message-Market-Fit | Founder @ The Deal Lab | Smartlead Certified Partner | Clay Certified Expert

content:
Today I met with a sales leader concerned with turnover whom felt powerless against the burnout their teams experience.

They basically do the same thing each week and month, with the same goals& its pretty simple yet they still end up feeling stressed out. Im not sure how much simpler it could be

Well as it turns out, that simplicity is part of the problem.

As correctly identified, monotony leads to burnout.

What this sales leader hadnt yet thought about was their ability to affect monotony.

When a rep has the same goals weekly, monthly, yearly& you are framing each day as identical to all others.

The stress signal associated with that day increases over time, like a droplet of water on your forehead. 

Eventually its unbearable.

A way of hacking this is by having dynamic goals and taking a periodized approach to your working schedule.

By having a mix of variable stress levels on a daily/weekly/monthly basis, you can plan sprints or periods of high output around business strategy.

It also lets you place recovery periods where it has the lowest business cost i.e. slow periods during times of lower activity.

In both cases - you are leveraging stress or recovery to come at the greatest benefit to the company at any given time.

The result is a team that feels cared for, hits goals more frequently, and does so at a lower cost or stress level.

Its no surprise that this exact same sort of approach is used by your favorite athletes to put up big numbers while avoiding injury either, since in both cases youre balancing expected load against capacity to perform.

Anyone out there periodizing their goals today? Anyone interested in a discussion of how you can?

Here's a framework borrowed from a US Olympic Team and adapted to help you hit big f**kin' goals.

- Identify a goal for the quarter
- Break into 3 smaller sprints with their own focuses
- Monitor your team to predict negative trends and put them out before they harm performance
- Use that same data to understand when you can step on the gas and increase effort

This helps you mitigate "injury" in your organization (burnout, poor psychological health, misalignment, disengagement in our case) while pushing your people to be their best (happy, health, high performing in an equitable workplace)... all driven by your people's feedback.

content:
For World Mental Health Day (yesterday) I want to share a look at how you can have your cake and eat it too.

Or in this case squeeze that extra 20% out of your team's performance, provide them adequate time to recover from the sprint, and arrive at month's end goal without sacrificing burnout.

The yellow and green line below shows "ok" performance; the team is cruising along hitting about 90% of goal.

The purple line shows how a well timed realignment to a stretch goal, a willingness to sprint extra hard for a week, and then giving some extra recovery opportunity on the back end of that sprint can help you beat your goal without sacrificing your people's health.

The devil is in the details here.

First your team needs to be physiologically prepared to push extra hard. If they're already spent from last month; doing so will run you deeper into a deficit and be even more likely to cause churn or chronic burnout issues.

Then, if you sprint too hard, you may struggle to recover and end up sacrificing performance outside of your focus sprint. This means you could take out so much from your team that they aren't prepared to show up again next month/quarter.

Leaders can also damage their leadership capital by failing to adequately and proportionally support their people after the sprint compared to what people put in. The team will notice.

It's no secret that I'm an advocate for using data to tell you when, why, and in what ways you challenge and support your team; but the most important takeaway is this:

Everything you do comes at a "cost" to people's state of being (see: health // mental health).

As leaders, coaching people through how to balance that "load" is the most impactful thing we can do.

It's one thing to tell someone they can do something, give them the tools to do it, and pray together...

It's another to do everything that you can to win together.

That's who we're here for =

How are you getting out ahead of burnout?

This is your company's alignment.

It gets worse daily when left untouched.

But you're like... really really busy... so you want to neglect it (too much other things to work on...)

Ever felt like this: "We had clear expectations, but new things have come up and I'm not sure if the current path forward is still the right one. But I also don't know if it's worth butting in yet"?

I have.

William M. Ballance posted today about a sales rep from a multi-billion dollar org today who was too embarrassed to directly ask for email coaching from their manager.

Sadly, this lack of confidence to speak up for help is the case across many companies - maybe all...

No matter how hard you try to create an environment of feedback, some % of needs will go unsaid for one reason or another if you don't have easy ways to capture needs anonymously from your people.

"I didn't want to bother them..."

"It didn't seem important..."

Here's a suggestion: LEON

Anonymized, aggregated data for each unique team so managers can give their people what they need, when they need it; all data driven.

This lets people feel their voices being heard, and gives managers the ability to quickly respond to their teams' current needs.

This leads to higher performance and lower turnover, which I think most companies would see as a benefit... ;) 

But while you're here, sign up for =ï¿½ Will Allred & Kristina Finseth >Q's "Sales Email AMA" today at 2PM EST (link below) to ANONYMOUSLY ask your sales emailing questions...

content:
If you havent yet, go check out Bryan Smiths post from today.

Basically he opened up a bit about what our team is facing in terms of stress.

Below Ive included a graphic of an astronaut training to withstand g-force, or the gravity/force created through extreme acceleration.

 Before trying to launch into space, astronauts need to learn to withstand g-force beyond what you and I could handle without training. Without training, they lose consciousness and possibly their life.

Well&

LEON is about to go through similar.

You see, we dream of landing in space ourselves one day =ï¿½, but today we are a small crew who has to withstand stress beyond what we are likely currently capable in order to earn our way to liftoff.

Its scary because the mission is a big one.

Its exciting because it can change the life of everyone working with us.

Its rewarding because it legitimately helps people be happier and perform better.

Im confident because weve aligned to mission at hand, have the tools to achieve, and are captained by a leader wed all follow like Spartans showing up to the front door of the Ottoman Empire and leaving it all on the line&

Basically - this is what we f*cking live for.

So while failure is a possibility, giving up is not an option.

*looks over and nods to the g-force endurance operator that Im ready to turn it up a notch*

<ï¿½ Dont believe me just watch <ï¿½ =

content:
40% of startups are unsure about what the right Go-To-Market Strategy is for their business >Ã  That's what we found in our recent market study.

But having the right GTM Strategy is crucial to build a profitable business and grow successfully as a startup.

Often we work hard to reach Product-Market fit, but then just never take the time to set the right strategy before we launch the next phase.

However, there is a very simple framework that can guide us towards finding the right GTM Strategy and build the right organisation behind.

All you need to consider is your annual contract values.

The video below is a snippet where I share the results of our Scaling Readiness Report at our big afterwork event 2 weeks ago and explain how to use the framework.


 I'm curious to read what others think about the model and learnings that have been drawn from it.

content:
Finally, we can present our latest project: the Scaling Readiness Check and Benchmark Report =â‚¬

After working with 50+ startups over the past two years, we began to recognize the repetitive failure and success patterns in startups within their funding stages. So this February we sat down and thought, what if there was an easy way to spot these mistakes as a startup founder and get practical advice on how to overcome them?

Here's what to expect when you take the 8-minute survey:

=Â¯ An instant score showing your readiness to scale
=Ãˆ Real-time benchmark data to compare with other startups in your stage
>Ã  Best practice advice for how to improve
=Å’ An invitation to the final event where we present all the findings in detail

Please like and comment if you want to receive the link to participate and access the full report. More than 55 startups have already taken part.

We are also giving away a full-funnel business analysis of your startup by the Peakora team among all participants that submitted until 16th June 2023.

Were looking forward to developing this project further and are thankful for the support from LEXR, Pedalix - Automatic Lead Generation & Nurturing, and the Swiss Startup Association and highly value other work already done in this space such as the B2B SaaS Benchmark by Andrea Ratzenberger and Thomas Kessler.

content:
Im so happy to finally share with you our big news and what we have been working on over the past year and months. Say hello to:

Peakora - The very first Startup Enablement Platform <â€°

What the heck is a startup enablement platform? Good question - Watch the video or read below!
___

In 2021 we started with RealGrowthHacking. Clients loved diving into our growth hacking program and the impact they got, but more and more we realized it was not the growth hacking part that they appreciated so much, it was the methodology with which we worked.

We learned that Startups mainly wanted three things when collaborating:

1Ã£ Follow a proven process and work with people that have done this before
2Ã£ Get impact fast
3Ã£ Be hands-on and learn how to do it themselves

And this is exactly what our new methodology delivered:

=Ãˆ A proven roadmap and all collateral needed on this path
>Ã  A knowledge platform to transfer all the valuable skills needed in this stage
=Ã  Hands-on coaching and implementation by true startup veterans

This methodology we call Startup Enablement, and following these principles we teamed up with some of the very best in their domains to create the one go-to platform for enablement programs that cover the most important needs in every startup stage.

With Peakora, we brought this vision under one umbrella and I invite you to:

content:
Does full-remote really work?

Hard to say, so far it does for us.

At RGH, anyone can work from anywhere as long as they work +/- 2 hours in the CET time zone.

Once a quarter the company flies everyone to a city of our choice and we all get together for a week of co-working and alignment.

This quarter it was Lisbon and the timing couldnt have been better. We've been working for months on what we're going to release tomorrow, and the past week in particular has been so intense and time-consuming that I don't think it would have been possible while being remote.

Its especially these highly intense moments I also loved back at Beekeeper, this tremendous startup energy, which unfortunately isn't the same when you're remote.

But with the setup we have now, I feel were making the best out of both.

If you're interested in what we're releasing tomorrow, I invite you to become part of the exclusive inner circle: click the link in the comments below to be among the first to witness the reveal. =@=@=@

Im really thankful for all the support we got so far and share tomorrow what the next stage will look like =O<Ã¼(

content:
While I talk with so many startups about scaling their acquisition, very few approach me to talk about client or user retention.

Achieving solid retention is the #1 proof of Product-Market fit and a necessity before you scale a business.

Most often, this topic only becomes relevant once we started working, and a low awareness suddenly turns into a huge interest.

For this reason, we invested in solving this problem together with the Customer Success expert Linus Haferkemper (former Head of CS at Dropbox) and co-created a brand new program only dedicated to making clients successful, increasing retention, and turning them into advocates to drive more revenue!<

As always, we start a new program by giving tons of value for free and have organized two Masterclass sessions about this topic.

Limited to 30 seats to keep quality high. Signup Link in the comments.
