content:
When was the last time you took a 2 week vacation?

I just got back from 2 weeks vacation in Brazil. It was the first time that I left the company for that long since I founded it.

I have to say I was a little nervous, but I now believe every CEO should do this at least once a year.

And I'm not even talking about mental health reasons. Here's what I learned:

WHEN YOU'RE GONE:

=Ã You identify what processes and ownerships are not clearly defined and thus represent obstacles to the efficient growth of your business

>  Your team is on their own and learns/feels empowered to make more decisions themselves while winning a broader understanding of the business

=i
=Â» You can quickly see which positions are understaffed and what your next hire should be

<Ã It takes 2 weeks to identify the above and also calm down enough to look forward to going back to work


I believe the less you are needed as a CEO, the more valuable is your company. And that's a nice approach to seeing what it takes to get closer to that.

I'm sure there are plenty more CEO learnings that can be shared here?

PS re picture: No good idea to rent a 2-wheel powered car to go through beaches and sand dunes to reach kite spots...

content:
What makes a good team? And what makes a good full remote team? =i<Ã¼
=Â»>Ã‘<Ã»
=Â»

While there are definitely some good answers to the first question, we're also discovering the second.

Last weekend our growing full remote team got together in person for the first time, and we had a blast wakeboarding, eating, drinking, hiking and brainstorming.

While we're still figuring out exactly how full remote work works, here are some of my best take-aways I hope you'll find useful:

=Ã† Structure & Processes:
Done right, every employee knows exactly what their duties and responsibilities are and how to escalate if necessary. Tools we use: RACIs, checklists, and kanban board in notion. Flow charts, strategy, OKRs in Miro. Communication in Slack, 45min efficient team meeting on Monday.

> Trust over control:
There is no room for control. If I have to, its inefficient and I hired the wrong person.

=Âª<Ã¼P Give responsibility, but also authority:
Ownership and KPIs give direction and expectation, but the person also needs to be empowered with the right authority.

>B=Â¬ Remote Culture:
I think the importance here is clear, but even more so in full-remote. It is important that we hire the right people with the right mindset who actually want and appreciate such a lifestyle.

>Ã<Ã»
@>ÃMeet in person:
For me I want to work with friends. And friendships just aren't made remotely. Not at remote coffees or other remote events. So we try to get together every quarter and then really focus on spending time together and having bonding experiences.

There is definitely a lot more to learn and I look forward to some comments that may help! 

But most importantly, I want to thank my amazing team for all their efforts and the journey we've had together. Going from zero in January 2021 to managing up to 27 clients at a time while ensuring the highest quality for our clients and achieving an NPS of 9/10 so far this year!

Onwards and upwards, thank you! Tim Eckert, Lucas Maliczak, Janine, Andrea Ratzenberger and all our other experts and partners supporting us!=

content:
One of my first and biggest mistakes as a young entrepreneur back at university was, that I thought having a business means founding a GmbH or an AG.

So that was what I did, paid a lot of money to institutions and locked up quite some money in this new legal identity, but a business I still did not have.

Today I do things differently. I start any new project as an "Einzelfirma" (sole proprietorship) and once it becomes a real business with customers, then I install the proper legal identity.

That's how I started as well with RealGrowthHacking and I'm happy to announce that since a few days we changed the legal identity to the newly founded RLGH AG that now powers the brand =â‚¬

But honestly, the legal change is not even a milestone, it's only a means to fuel the business further.

The true milestone is, that we started with only an idea in January 2021 and are now well on track to reach half a million in revenues this year - fully bootstrapped and profitable. 

So if the legal change is a milestone or not, I'd like to say thank you to all our customers, our core team with Tim Eckert and Lucas Maliczak as well as other important players that are supporting us Andrea Ratzenberger Boris Manhart Alberto Toledo.=O<Ã½

Much more to come still this year! =â‚¬

title: We scaled 100+ Startups & Tech SMBs with tactics learned at Beekeeper, Dropbox, Tinder, and other high-growth companies.

content:
>Ã  The first steps to take when going Product-Led:

I remember back in 2017 as we made the first steps at Beekeeper towards Product-Led Growth (PLG: a go-to-market strategy where you use your product as the main vehicle to drive acquisition, activation, and retention).

There was very little guideline on how to do it, and it was even harder to convince marketing, sales, and product that this is an important step to take for a B2B SaaS company.

Luckily, today we have the clear proof from many leading companies that it is one of the dominant go-to-market strategies to go after, and also way more experience and guideline in how to do it.

Nevertheless, PLG remains one of the hardest things to implement successfully, so I wanted to share some tips with you:

1. Build a team =o
B:
To go Product-Led you need a cross-functional team. You need to have marketing, sales, and product on board, and make sure you all have a common understanding for PLG and are well educated in this new topic. Without this support, you're not getting anywhere.

2. Define your strategy _:
I see too many companies jump right into implementing something, without actually analysing which PLG Model is the right one for them. There is a clear framework on how to do this, and picking the wrong model can do more harm than good.

3. Identify user success <:
A successful PLG Model is all about bringing the user to the moment where they realise meaningful value in your product. That means 1. you need to attract the right user, 2. understand in detail what they truly want, and 3. deliver an experience that truly solves their pain as fast as possible. Missing on one of these points is missing all of it.

4. Taking first steps before taking a swing â€™:
Another mistake I often see is that over-motivated teams jump full on into building a PLG Model while being completely sales-led at the time. Following iterative steps will allow you to learn, while not hurting your conversion and ultimately build a better experience.

Have you ever thought about going Product-Led or do you just want to freshen up your and your teams knowledge?

Next Thursday, 7. April I'll give a free webinar where I explain the detailed steps to take. Feel free to join and bring your team as well. Link in the comment section.

FYI: Shaili P. Gabriel Riedo Julia Baur Tiziano Nessi Patrick TrÃ¼mpi James Margrove PhD Maximilian Voss

content:
When we work with a startup, one of the first questions is always, "Do you have product market fit?" The two main discoveries that follow this question are not rare:

1. They don't measure it
2. They're already scaling, even though their retention curve isn't flattening

There are qualitative and quantitative frameworks that not only allow you to measure PMF, but also give you a clear structure on how to work on it and improving it.

However, I still see those frameworks rarely used and correctly implemented.

It will be my last reminder and your last chance to register for our free webinar happening today where we dive into the Product Market Fit frameworks with Boris Manhart and the entire Product Market Fit phase that actually begins even before you start your business.

Already more than 60 people registered=â‚¬  Find the link in the comments!

content:
Learn how leading Startups use Outbound to scale their sales:

Doing Outbound Emailing can be a very effective way to scale your business or create initial traction. However, doing this manually is way too costly and time consuming.

The next level would be to use tools that help you scrape data from platforms, find emails addresses and reach out to them. These can be very handy tools and depending on your needs even be the right thing.

But if you really want to scale, even these tools are too manual as the most costly factor in this entire process is YOU doing this manually.

This Thursday Lucas Maliczak is hosting an Ask-me-Anything Session where he will give a quick presentation and then discuss and answer any questions you have regarding the outbound topic. content:
As a startup leader, how much time do you spend setting up Objectives and Key Results?

Its this time of the year again. Strategy, planning, Budgeting. Something that takes quite some time, but if done right is also super important.

One thing I often see missing and can recommend any startup is the proper implementation of Objectives and Key Results:

OKRs are a really good framework to translate your strategic planning into a clear operational plan for your teams and employees.

It makes your strategy tangible and empowers employees to easily understand how they can actively contribute to the overall goal. If done right, the positive impact is substantial:

Through owning clear metrics, employees and teams get more authority in their doing. This often leads to more motivation and also more efficiency, as you can be sure that every human just puts in more energy into reaching their goals, when they also are directly responsible for.

Gained motivation, authority, and efficiency makes your entire company a better oiled engine, and especially also having clear visibility of the mission and priorities of others, helps to find consensus and agreements faster when collaborating in projects.

This year, we start sharing valuable guides and templates such as in this case an OKR Template on our company channel RealGrowthHacking.

So if you're into that, give it a follow. Direct link to the post with the template you can find in the comments.
title: We scaled 100+ Startups & Tech SMBs with tactics learned at Beekeeper, Dropbox, Tinder, and other high-growth companies.

content:
The Mistakes and Habits that led us to success in 2021

2021 has been one of the most decisive years for me so far. I quit my great job at Beekeeper, started my own company and what began as a one-man show with no clear plan grew into a 3 person company by the end of the year, with revenue growing from 0 to 200k+ in the first 12 months since the idea was born.
And all of this somehow happened while living abroad in Egypt, Spain, and South Africa for 8 months.

Now, that all sounds like a smooth run, but of course, all of this was also associated with fears, problems and hiccups.

So I thought about sharing some of my learnings in the hopes that they might be of help to some of you:

<Ã¼ Be aware of what youre up for:
I started with RGH in January. I have already sold a program to 3 individuals and 5 startups started in February. I worked at Beekeeper until March and had to do everything at the same time. For over 3 months I worked like never before and was constantly afraid that I would not deliver the next week.
By the end of March, I had my own running business, but I was also completely burned out and had many of the signs associated with it. Was it worth it? Yes. Would I do it again the same way? Not sure.
But every individual should be aware of the initial intensity when doing the transition from employee to entrepreneur and maybe, taking some more time might not be a bad thing.

=Âª<Ã¼ Bravery: One of the strongest emotions I felt this year was entrepreneurial fear. The existential fear. You don't see it coming and suddenly it hits you. Even if it's just psychological and maybe doesn't even reflect current reality, it shakes you to the bone.
But to be successful as an entrepreneur, there is no room for fear. Writing down the best- and worst-case scenarios helped me a lot. It gives you perspective and allowed me to get back into a fearless state.

< Our customers success is our success: That was our motto from the beginning and it is until today. And I really believe in it. There are so many benefits to running a quality business and making sure each and every customer is successful. I believe this is one of the best ways to grow a business sustainably. In our case, this resulted in an NPS score of 9/10 and a revenue contribution of 33% from our referral channel. But above all, it makes customers happy, and it makes us happy.

Now I could go on and share so much more, but this post is already too long. Hence, feel free to reach out to me if you want to hear more.

Id like to end with a huge thank you to all the people that actively supported RGH in 2021, without them it would never have been possible: Tim Eckert Lucas Maliczak Alberto Toledo Christoph Brenner Boris Manhart Andreas Slotosch Manuel Hartmann Sandro Meyer Luke Szkudlarek Simon G. Soraia Domingues Jevgenija Glazunova Lanny Heiz and to the many more that contributed as well as our customers=O<Ã½

content:
It's crazy how many startups do this wrong: Lifecycle Stages!

I love working with startups because every case is unique and challenges me on a personal level.

Nevertheless, there are still a lot of standard processes and frameworks that are just best practices to follow instead of creating

something custom that will confuse everyone and all your future employees. And one of those things I run over and over into is

implementing proper lifecycle stages. I see so many companies doing this wrong or not at all. And I'm not talking about newly founded 

business, but also well-established scaleups. Sadly, there is also a lot of information on the web which is just wrong.

But implementing this properly is crucial for your entire acquisition engine, for analysing and optimizing it.

Hence, I wanted to share with you a standard with detailed explanations about the stages, and what the conversion rates tell us from stage to stage (most important!)

Lifecycle stages can also differ depending on your GTM Strategy (freemium / free trial). We have also more data around this, if you have any questions or want to check our detailed mir board, reach out.

content:
Going Product-Led as a company is a journey, never a jump - Few tipps below:

This week I had the pleasure to visit the office of beUnity . beUnity joined one of our programs early this year and did an awesome job applying the trained growth frameworks and created stunning results (i.e. +300% Inbound Growth in 3 months).

Equipped with beers and chips we went through their entire PLG process. Here some tipps if you want to go from sales-led to product-led:

â€“ Calculate your contract values, start with your PLG approach for anything below 2k. Remain sales-led with the rest. Start, test, iterate, then open the funnel.

=Ã±Start with sales-assisted trials: In the beginning your product wont be ready to let users experience value by themselves. Give out trials but have the first experience with a sales person. Note down the questions, hick-ups, and aha-moments they have and you will know where to start with building your onboarding. Sales will always remain a key element also in a PLG strategy but you want to automate smaller deals and further qualify higher value deals before bringing in sales.

 Start early: Going PLG forces you to build a good product. Sales-led often does not, cause youre focusing on pleasing the buyer which is not always the actual user. The earlier you start the easier it will be as you have to refacture less of your UX.

Great work by Patrik Elsa Gabriel Riedo Dominik Heusser Quentin Aeberli and team!
And btw, heard theyre fundraising ;-)

content:
When working with startups and scaleups on rapid experimentation frameworks during the past years, I often observed a funny thing:

One kind of person does not want to let go of making gut feel decisions, and the other marks all insights as not statistically significant.

Out of my experience, I'd say the magic is in the middle. The right conclusion will be a mixture of experiences gathered by the team + the quantitative findings from experiments. And if still unsure, never hesitate to gather more qualitative data by using userbrain.com or usabilityhub.com.

As long as you've let go of traditional approaches and started running experiments, I'd stay you're on the right path. And if you want to take a closer look at how significant your experiments are, then don't waste time and just use this amazing calculator by evenmiller: https://lnkd.in/gw-3KuM

content:
WOW>) What could be better than a satisfied customer who writes a LinkedIn post praising your product/service without you asking for it!

Another sign of why it is absolutely vital for any business to focus on a North Star rather than revenue!=%

A north star is a metric that measures the value you offer your customers. While optimizing revenue will result in automatically

squeezing more money out of your customers in the short term, optimizing your North Star leads to providing more and more value in the long run.

This makes happier customers, less churn, more referrals, and ultimately, more revenue, in the long run =â‚¬

Now that I'm a huge fan of the North Star concept for software companies, I have great difficulty finding one for me in a company that sells knowledge, not software.

Any ideas/suggestions from the experts as to what North Stars can make sense for service companies? Sean Ellis Pedro Clivati Jim Huffman Martin Gontovnikas Sandro Meyer Neil Patel

content:
OpenAI's ChatGPT-3 is all the rage these days. And I understand why. It will disrupt almost every industry in the world.

But hey, here's a hot take.

Partnerships might be one of the few areas where AI will have a hard time replacing  us, mere mortals.

The past few Covid-hit years thought us how to work effectively in a remote setting, but I always come back to a cliche which is: "You can't replace a handshake on Zoom"

Sure, AIs can help streamline some tasks and processes, but they currently cannot replace the strategic, creative,  and interpersonal skills you rely on in your day-to-day partnership roles.

What's your take on this? Are you afraid of an AI taking your job? =1

content:
Plenty of tech partnerships are a waste of time and resources.

It's a sad reality, but that's the truth.

Here's how to avoid shipping an integration that no one will use:

- find a partner (product) category that strongly aligns with your own product's core capabilities

- develop a strong mutual use case with your chosen partner(s)

- map your accounts so you identify the potential userbase of your integration (=make sure there's a big enough market to serve, IPC fit & overlap)

- do customer interviews before building anything (=find out if it's actually useful for your customers)

- get internal insights from other GTM functions (sales, CS)

- try to make sure that the partner will equally invest in your go-to-market strategy 

This latter one's usually the tricky part because when you're starting a new partnership, partners sometimes tend to be overly optimistic/enthusiastic and overpromise/underdeliver. I've been guilty of this many times as well.

Hope this helps you launch something that will actually change the life of your customers for the better.

#partnerships #alliances
title: Enterprise Clay Partner agency founder | Sales leaders: I'll help you build a scalable outbound engine that gets meetings booked on autopilot in the next 180 days | DM me "outbound" to learn more

content:
The tables have turned in partnerships

In the earlier days of the channel, partners had to earn the right and privilege to sell vendors' products.

Today, the power is in the partner's hands. 

Vendors have to earn partners' attention. Gone are the days when vendors could dictate what products to sell and when. 

That's why it's more important than ever to focus on not just enabling the partners but engaging  them in a way they prefer.

Monthly partner newsletter filled with irrelevant and outdated company news? 
Won't cut through the noise.

A modern channel communication model needs to be multi-directional.

#partnerships #channel #communications

content:
How do you measure success in your career?

What's the thing that makes you think youre on the right track, growing each day?

In the past few weeks, I had many discussions with friends, colleagues, and recruiters as I was suddenly unemployed. To my surprise, plenty of them was facing some similar challenges as I was. Being let go, facing massive layoffs trends, or already on the job hunt.

In those situations, it's hard to think clearly and make a big career decision that will most likely impact your life in many aspects for years to come.

I showed them something I learned from a Harvard Business Review article years ago that helps you compare two jobs and get clarity on your priorities.

They seemed to gain clarity immediately, so I hope it'll help you as well in some ways. =G

content:
Learn to say no. I think that's really hard for a lot of us - it is for me. I just hate to conflict with people.

But you have to realize you can't do it all on your own. To go far, you need to have a team. And in a great team, everyone has clear priorities and goals. And sometimes they don't align with yours. And that's okay.

And you have to learn to accept a no as well. Either in sales or partnerships, not all customers/partners are created equal. In some cases, things just won't work out. 

Don't sweat over it. Sometimes it just takes time. It might be a better alignment a little bit further down the road. Don't burn bridges.

It's kind of a tradition that we make a State of App Development blogpost at Bitrise every year. We compile some of our biggest learnings as well as follow up on last year's predictions.

Some fun facts and key highlights:

Bitrise users' builds ran for 5,232,196 hours. That is... > ... 597 years.

Native iOS and Android development still reign supreme - cross-platform apps are on the rise, but 70% of apps are built natively either on iOS (40%) or Android (30%).

Our partner program is still in its infancy, we've already got solid proof that - working hand in hand with amazing technology partners - we're building an ecosystem that's able to cover the whole Mobile DevOps lifecycle, filling feature gaps that our core product won't fill on its own.

content:
Life Hack - how to get your focus back

If you're like me, you've probably found yourself at the bottom of a rabbit hole you dug for yourself surfing online. It starts with just one thing. You want to check the news quickly or DM your spouse. And you end up reading weird facts about ant societies and guacamole recipes.

So what's so addictive about social media? >A >A >A  

It's the news feed. Be it Facebook, Twitter, or Linkedin (those are the ones I regularly used), the endless stream of content is what keeps you coming back.

There are upsides to using these platforms, so here's an amazing way to get the good side, while still keeping your sanity and productivity.

Block the news feed.

To do so, I use a browser extension called News Feed Eradicator. It allows you to use the platform, check DMs, search, etc., but it'll eradicate your algorithmically perfected, interesting -  but distracting - news feed by replacing it with inspiring quotes. 

Ever since I started using it, I use social media more purposefully. I can keep in touch with friends and family, but I removed the most addicting part of it.

Getting your attention back SHOULD be a priority. Do you know any other small but effective tricks to boost productivity? =ï¿½

When I got into partnerships ~3 years ago, it wasn't a conscious decision I thoroughly planned. 

I didn't know much about building integrations with tech partners, even less about driving real revenue through the channel.

What made me stick to it was the ability to govern the product to some extent. 

As digital workers, we don't really produce physical stuff that's concrete and tangible. That's something I'd like to get into later, like woodworking or constructing something.

But with building tech integrations, I could influence how a product is built, and if you build something truly useful for your customers, that'll stick around for long. 

You can leave your mark like that and influence your customers' lives for the better.

Do you also get the feeling sometimes that it'd be great to actually build something that's not digital?

content:
We all are creatures of habit. You are what you repeatedly do. 

You drink the same coffee, at the same time, work out, and then you get hungry more or less at the same time every day.

Research shows that those who regularly step outside of their comfort zones are more emotionally resilient and creative.

A few weeks ago, I started something I haven't done before: performing live webinars with Recart. I have to admit, it's been scary at first, as it should be. 

At first, I made tons of notes and prepared 100% for every scenario. Last week, I just made a few bullet points and it was good to go!

As you become more successful, your goals grow too. The more you challenge yourself with new experiences, the greater your comfort zone becomes, meaning what was once scary, becomes your new norm.

This week, I won't host our webinar, but present at it, discovering top Messenger marketing tactics leading Shopify Plus brands use to generate millions of dollars of revenue with Recart.

content:
Is COVID-19 going to disrupt the event industry?

For our company, there are two major industry conferences that are highly recommended every year:

- Shopify Unite
- Facebook Developer Conference: F8

In the timespan of like 2 days, both got canceled. To be more precise, the in-person elements of these events are canceled, and they're trying to turn it into a virtual experience.

Many other large B2B events are pulling the trigger. It's a huge decision, but It's the right thing to do.

But are we at the point already where such an event can be replaced and run 100% virtually?

I tend to think that events are not entirely great because of the keynotes and the content itself, but because it possesses phenomenal networking opportunities. That's hard to replace via Zoom.

What do you think? What would you do if you were to run an in-person event in the next few months?

#marketing #f8 #shopifyunite

content:
Not long ago I was a guest on Steve Hutt's eCommerce Fastlane podcast show and had a great chat about how Recart helps high-growth DTC brands increase revenue, decrease customer acquisition cost and communicate more effectively to their audience using Messenger marketing.

A few takeaways from the episode:
- Brands will go where their customers are. Currently, it's Facebook Messenger. Chat apps have surpassed traditional social media apps.
- Facebook ad CPCs are increasing by 40-50% YoY. If you don't work on diversifying your marketing efforts, you'll go out of business soon.
- Number 1 headache of ecommerce is cart abandonment: 78% of all carts are never purchased. Reminders in Messenger are the most effective way to drive back the almost-buyers and convert them to recurring customers.
Link to the show in the comments.

content:
Heres what Id do if I were building my sales stack from scratch =G

Balancing&
â€™ As lean a sales stack as possible (as few tools as possible)
â€™ Capabilities (data points, enrichment options + AI integrations)
â€™ Ease of implementation (build it today)
â€™ &and that automate as many steps as possible

Start with:

Apollo
Â³ + Clay
Â³ + Smartlead by Vaibhav

1Ã£Â Apollo.io does the initial list building (company size, industries, job titles, geo).
2Ã£Â Clay enriches with more data sources, finds emails and effortlessly lets you leverage AI to personalize your outreach.
3Ã£Â Still within Clay, you can automatically push your contacts to Smartlead.
4Ã£Â Smartlead handles [1] automating your outreach messages and [2] warming up your email addresses.

Then once you want to save $$$ on this workflow, you
â€™ get Datagma (by Raphael Azot) and one-click connect it to Clays through the API
â€™ get DeBounce and one-click connect it to Clays through the API

This way, you dont spend Clay credits for finding or verifying emails&
But youre still doing it inside the tool - which saves lots of (precious!) time.

Finally, youll want to manage all these leads.

At ColdIQ, we love Breakcold >ÃŠ (Arnaud Belinga is going places!!)

What would you do differently?

P.S: 8500+ champions have seen my best sales stack recommendations in the last 90 days at coldiq[dot]com/tools
title: Founder / CEO @ ColdIQ | Scale Outbound with AI & Tech =I coldiq.com

content:
If you speak languages other than English, you should ABSOLUTELY prospect in these!

We're sending long-ass text campaigns with little to no personalization, targeting niches that stopped responding in the US, and they're booking a fair amount of meetings.

My assumptions:
1. Most markets are behind the US/UK.
2. 99% of the spam in the world is in English, so writing in another language gets you out of the spam folder.
3. Prospects worldwide receive outreach in English. Addressing them in their language (almost) IS personalization.

Anyone's seen something similar?

PS: Rumour says that campaigns in Italian perform 2x better when you add this emoji >
title: Founder / CEO @ ColdIQ | Scale Outbound with AI & Tech =I coldiq.com

content:
We shared our top AI prospecting plays with >Â¾Eric & Jed the other day.

For those who couldnt watch it live, heres the replay: https://lnkd.in/dSndrd7k

And if you are still too lazy to sit through it = & here are 4 takeaways:

title: Founder / CEO @ ColdIQ | Scale Outbound with AI & Tech =I coldiq.com

content:
When everyone zigs, you zag =G

Buying triggers have become popular among outbound sellers.

E.g: Companies hiring for SDRs& would suggest theyre:

[1] Looking to expand their sales effort.
[2] have some budget allocated to it.

But if everyone targets companies based on the same triggers&
You now have lots of competition.

Morgan Gebhardt made a great point on Nate Nasrallas Library of Uncommon Sales Practices (highly recommended read btw!).

=I Instead of going for high-performing companies, hed target trainwrecks.

The idea =G
Its easier to make a clear and highly-visible impact in a trainwreck.

So heres a thought =Â­

Whenever you build a hypothesis on why someone would be interested in your solution.

Think about whether the opposite could be true, too.

A company hiring SDRs might be looking to expand their sales efforts&

But a company firing SDRs might be looking for:
- weaker & shorter-term commitments (no need to hire or provide employee benefits)
- a more efficient outbound system (that does more with fewer people)
- specialized knowledge (no need to train junior salespeople)
- (&)

Sounds like a bad idea?

#hiring #sales #people #like

content:
50% of AI researchers believe theres a 10% or greater chance that humans will go extinct from our inability to control AI*

=I This is coming from an hour-long presentation called The A.I Dilemma [https://lnkd.in/dZgDtx5q]


In the presentation, they discussed existing scams where AI tools are used to reproduce the voices of loved ones and ask for money.

This makes me wonder& considering the technology we have at hand:
=IÂ Where should we draw the limits of AI-powered personalization in sales?


â€™ When we use AI copywriting personalization... are we being deceitful to the people were contacting (since were pretending we did more research than we did)?

â€™ When we use AI personalized video and make prospects think we spent time recording a video for them& isnt this outright lying?


Just yesterday, I showed an example of an AI-personalized video by Ubique, and I asked folks to point out which parts had been personalized& offering $50 to a person who would guess everything right.

Nobody did.


To me, this shows how far technology has been. Which is impressive& but also quite scary.

Curious to hear your thoughts on this... do you see an argument against using AI tools in sales?

content:
Yesterday Rob Hoffman posted about giving up cold email&

To focus 100% on content.

Heres why I think you should combine BOTH =G

1. As your audience grows - your brand recognition does too. This has a positive impact on your cold email conversions (because some people will be familiar with you already and the ones who aren't will see you as more credible thanks to your content).

2. You can leverage triggers such as profile views, post interactions, and newsletter subscriptions to create "warm" outreach campaigns.

3. You can leverage the information edge you gain from inbound leads to go after specific cold audiences (e.g: you're getting lots of inbound requests from a particular segment/industry, and you now know that there might be an open market-- and can reach out to similar people/companies).

content:
Spam filters are getting harsher on outbound emails.

Even when sending < 50 emails a day&

Email warm-up & Inboxes rotation&

And proper SPF, DKIM, and DMARC configuration...

There are only so many times you can blast the same messages&

Before it lands in the spam folder.

Want to avoid that?

=I Spintax is an underrated way to improve your deliverability.

Heres how it works (check specific rules in your Sales Engagement Platform)

On Smartlead instead of writing: Hey {{first_name}} 

â€™ Write {Hey | Hi | Hello} {{first_name}} 

Which makes 3 variations of the same message (and will select one randomly).

Then you can write {Regards | Best | Cheers | Kind regards | Thank you} as you finish your email.

(Instead of just: Kind regards")

And youve got 3 times 5 variations = 15 for the same message.

Continue doing so wherever you can&

And you wont send the exact same message twice.


Any other place within the email where youd leverage spintax?

content:
Using your primary domain is the #1 cardinal sin of email outreach.

Everybody tells you to create new domains, but nobody explains how =G

Heres how I set it up in my own prospecting:
â€™ I use Google to buy new domains.
â€™ I forward these new domains to my main domain.
â€™ I create an inbox on top of each new domain.

So, for example if my main domain is coldiq.com, I create:
- coldiq.co
 -coldiq.io
 -coldiq.net

Which all redirect to coldiq.com (they actually do, try it =@).

And each has an email inbox like so =G
- michel@coldiq.co
- michel@coldiq.io
- michel@coldiq.net

I limit my sending to 50 emails per inbox per day. Thus, if I want to send 1000 emails per day at high deliverability rates, I need 20 domains.

How do you guys scale your sending volume?

1/ Type your targeted keywords on Google.

-> How long are the top articles? (How many words)

-> What is the intent behind the research?

-> What subtopics are they covering?
i.e: Is there a common theme among all top results?

-> How are the articles structured?

content:
Want more accurate targeting on LinkedIn Sales Navigator?

Leverage boolean operators.

Heres how =G

â€™ Use Quotation marks when looking for an exact match.

Searching Chief Marketing Offer will return related titles such as Chief Growth Officer & Marketing Director.

Searching Chief Marketing Offer will ensure all these words are included in their current job title.


â€™ Use NOT to exclude unwanted words.

Chief Marketing Officer might return Chief Marketing Officer Assistant profiles.

Chief Marketing Officer NOT Assistant will fix that.


â€™ Use OR to add more options.

Chief Marketing Officer will not return CMOs (except if they include both terms in their title)

CMO will not return Chief Marketing Officers.

Chief Marketing Officer OR CMO will return both.


In short =G

Stop searching: Chief Marketing Officer on Sales Navigator
Start searching: Chief Marketing Officer OR CMO NOT Assistant
